School of Nursing & Public Health, College of Health Sciences, University of KwaZulu-Natal, Durban 4000, South Africa

ab: Antibiotic resistance is an inevitable consequence of selective pressure imposed by antibiotic use in human beings, (food) animals, agriculture, and aquaculture. It generally results from overuse and indiscriminate use of antibiotics in developed countries and underuse and misuse of them in developing countries. When a bacterial population is exposed to an antibiotic, susceptible organisms are eradicated whereas resistant ones persist and pass on their resistant genes to their offspring by replication (vertical transfer) or to other species through conjugation, transformation, and transduction (horizontal gene transfer) via mobile genetic elements such as plasmids, transposons, and integrons.1Essential Drugs MonitorAntimicrobial resistance: a global threat.Ess Drugs Monit. 2000; 28 (29:): 1Google Scholar Antibiotic resistance thus occurs in an individual human being or animal but it is perpetuated by diverse socioeconomic risk factors and maintained within environments as a result of poor hygiene and sanitation and suboptimal infection prevention and control. In The Lancet Planetary Health, Peter Collignon and colleagues2Collignon P Beggs J Walsh T Gandra S Laxminarayan R Antibiotic consumption and other factors contributing to global antimicrobial resistance: a univariate and multivariable analysis.Lancet Planet Health. 2018; 2: e398-e405Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (293) Google Scholar set out to quantify the relationship between antibiotic consumption and antimicrobial resistance and other potential contributing factors using an ecological (aggregated-data design) analysis. The authors make the distinction between antibiotic consumption as a driver for the evolution of resistance and several governance, socioeconomic, and health-systems drivers that facilitate contagion‚Äîie, the dissemination and subsequent maintenance of antibiotic resistance levels in human health. Several epidemiological studies have shown that the type and frequency of resistance mechanisms varies between countries, with such differences commonly attributed to the qualitative and quantitative differences in antibiotic use3Speldooren V Heym B Labia R Nicolas-Chanoine M-H Discriminatory detection of inhibitor-resistant Œ≤-lactamases in Escherichia coli by single-strand conformational polymorphism PCR.Antimicrob Agents and Chemother. 1998; 42: 879-884Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 4Bell BG Schellevis F Stobbering E Goossens H Pringle M A systematic review and meta-analysis of the effects of antibiotic consumption on antibiotic resistance.BMC Infect Dis. 2014; 14: 13Crossref PubMed Scopus (624) Google Scholar and exposure in human beings, animals, fish, plants, and the environment. This well accepted causal relationship is confounded by governance, socioeconomic, and health-systems drivers. The authors noted a counterintuitive finding of an inverse correlation between antibiotic consumption and resistance that was partly attributed to the ecological design of the study (ie, its susceptibility to ecological fallacy), the absence of a temporal lag between exposure and outcome, limitations of data sources, incomplete datasets, aggregated indices of antimicrobial resistance, and limitations in the data processing and statistical methods. Nevertheless, they reiterate the need for the engagement of the whole of society for the prevention and containment of antibiotic resistance, requiring behavioural and organisational changes ranging from national governments and policy makers to individual patients and civil society, as articulated in a global action plan on antimicrobial resistance.5WHOGlobal action plan on antimicrobial resistance. World Health Organization, Geneva2015http://www.wpro.who.int/entity/drug_resistance/resources/global_action_plan_eng.pdfDate accessed: August 5, 2018Google Scholar A conceptual framework is presented in a figure in the appendix that aligns the findings of Collignon and colleagues2Collignon P Beggs J Walsh T Gandra S Laxminarayan R Antibiotic consumption and other factors contributing to global antimicrobial resistance: a univariate and multivariable analysis.Lancet Planet Health. 2018; 2: e398-e405Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (293) Google Scholar to this plan. Comprehensively addressing antibiotic resistance requires more than just financial investment in adequate human, operational, and infrastructure resources; it requires capability, opportunity, and motivation to elicit behavioural or organisational changes6Michie S Atkins L West R The behaviour change wheel: a guide to designing interventions. Silverback Publishing, Surrey2014Google Scholar, 7Michie S van Stralen MM West R The behaviour change wheel: a new method for characterising and designing behaviour change interventions.Implement Sci. 2011; 6: 42Crossref PubMed Scopus (4704) Google Scholar in long-standing government policies and government and individual practices‚Äîas described by the COM-B model. The COM-B model stipulates three pre-conditions for behaviour change: capability (ie, knowledge and skills), opportunity (physical and social), and motivation.6Michie S Atkins L West R The behaviour change wheel: a guide to designing interventions. Silverback Publishing, Surrey2014Google Scholar, 7Michie S van Stralen MM West R The behaviour change wheel: a new method for characterising and designing behaviour change interventions.Implement Sci. 2011; 6: 42Crossref PubMed Scopus (4704) Google Scholar The model covers the behavioural and social sciences, which include, but are not limited to, psychology, anthropology, sociology, economics, and political science;8Lorencatto F Charani E Sevdalis N Tarrant C Daveys P Driving sustainable change in antimicrobial prescribing practice: how can social and behavioural sciences help?.J Antimicrob Chemother. 2018; (published July 17.)doi:10.1093/jac/dky222Crossref PubMed Scopus (74) Google Scholar sociology, economics, and political science are all pertinent to the contagion of antibiotic resistance. Illustrative examples of mitigating governance, socioeconomic, and health-systems confounders in the context of antibiotic resistance, the global action plan on antimicrobial resistance, and the COM-B model are in a table in the appendix. The prevention and containment of antibiotic resistance clearly requires reduced and rational antibiotic use in tandem with mitigating the risk factors for contagion. SYE is a member of the Global Respiratory Infection Partnership sponsored by an unrestricted educational grant from Reckitt and Benckiser, UK. BS declares no competing interests. Download .pdf (.26 MB) Help with pdf files Supplementary appendix Anthropological and socioeconomic factors contributing to global antimicrobial resistance: a univariate and multivariable analysisReduction of antibiotic consumption will not be sufficient to control antimicrobial resistance because contagion‚Äîthe spread of resistant strains and resistance genes‚Äîseems to be the dominant contributing factor. Improving sanitation, increasing access to clean water, and ensuring good governance, as well as increasing public health-care expenditure and better regulating the private health sector are all necessary to reduce global antimicrobial resistance. Full-Text PDF Open Access

title: Sustainable diets are context specific but are they realistic?
display_name: Sustainable diets are context specific but are they realistic?

author.au_affiliation_raw: Department of Public Health, Environments & Society, London School of Hygiene & Tropical Medicine, London WC1H 9SH, UK
author.institution_display_name: London School of Hygiene & Tropical Medicine

author.au_affiliation_raw: Department of Public Health, Environments & Society, London School of Hygiene & Tropical Medicine, London WC1H 9SH, UK
author.institution_display_name: London School of Hygiene & Tropical Medicine

ab: Sustainable diets have long been proposed as a means to improve public health and food security, and to reduce the impact of the food system on the environment.1Macdiarmid JI Kyle J Horgan GW et al.Sustainable diets for the future: can we contribute to reducing greenhouse gas emissions by eating a healthy diet?.Am J Clin Nutr. 2012; 96: 632-639Crossref PubMed Scopus (301) Google Scholar Various sustainable diets have been suggested, which generally encourage reduced consumption of animal-source foods and replacement with foods from plant-based sources.2Pimentel D Pimentel M Sustainability of meat-based and plant-based diets and the environment.Am J Clin Nutr. 2003; 78: 660S-663SCrossref PubMed Google Scholar But it is not so simple. A diet might be sustainable, healthy, economically fair, and culturally acceptable in one region and not in another.3Perignon M Masset G Ferrari G et al.How low can dietary greenhouse gas emissions be reduced without impairing nutritional adequacy, affordability and acceptability of the diet? A modelling study to guide sustainable food choices.Public Health Nutr. 2016; 19: 2662-2674Crossref PubMed Scopus (106) Google Scholar For example, although reducing consumption of animal-source foods in high-income countries might bring sustainability benefits, this might not be an equitable or ethical approach in low-income country settings where undernutrition remains prevalent. To date, research on sustainable diets has not made cross-country comparisons and has been largely focused on high-income settings and with greenhouse gas emissions as the single measure of environmental impact.4Aleksandrowicz L Green R Joy EJM et al.The impacts of dietary change on greenhouse gas emissions, land use, water use, and health: a systematic review.PLoS One. 2016; 11: e0165797Crossref PubMed Scopus (451) Google Scholar, 5Jones AD Hoey L Blesh J et al.A systematic review of the measurement of sustainable diets.Adv Nutr. 2016; 7: 641-664Crossref PubMed Scopus (167) Google Scholar In The Lancet Planetary Health, Marco Springmann and colleagues6Springmann M Wiebe K Mason-D'Croz D Rayner M Scarborough P Health and nutritional aspects of sustainable diet strategies and their association with environmental impacts: a global modelling analysis with country-level detail.Lancet Planet Health. 2018; 2: 451-461Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (323) Google Scholar report a global analysis of the health and environmental impacts of a variety of sustainable diets. The authors modelled nutrient levels, chronic disease mortality due to nine diet-related risk factors, and a range of environmental impacts for 158 countries. Three approaches to designing sustainable diets were considered, motivated by environmental, food security, and public health objectives. The results show that the different approaches to sustainable diets might not have the same implications in different regions. Following environmental objectives by substituting animal-source foods with plant-based foods brought benefits for health along with reductions in emissions of greenhouse gases, but these benefits were greatest in high-income countries and, on a global level, the benefits were somewhat negated by increases in water use. Approaches that sought to redress dietary energy imbalances reduced premature mortality globally but had minimal environmental benefits. Adopting nutritionally balanced, low animal-source food diets in line with dietary guidelines provided the greatest benefits for health and the environment in general, with greater reductions in mortality than from changes in energy balance alone in addition to larger reductions in emissions, although these were somewhat reduced by some increased resource use (eg, water, cropland, nitrogen, and phosphorus), especially in low-income countries. This approach might also be more equitable, since it allows for some increased dietary diversity and consumption of animal-source foods in low-income countries. The analysis by Springmann and colleagues6Springmann M Wiebe K Mason-D'Croz D Rayner M Scarborough P Health and nutritional aspects of sustainable diet strategies and their association with environmental impacts: a global modelling analysis with country-level detail.Lancet Planet Health. 2018; 2: 451-461Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (323) Google Scholar provides context-specific guidance on the composition of sustainable diets. Although necessarily involving some important simplifications (eg, it did not account for impacts on biodiversity), it adds to the literature in the field of sustainable diet research by using a consistent global modelling framework and accounting for a range of health outcomes and environmental impacts related to diets. The study suggests that dietary patterns broadly in line with available evidence on healthy eating are most beneficial to both the environment and health. This conclusion reinforces the results of single-country studies showing that following dietary guidelines (eg, eating a diet with balanced energy intake rich in fruits and vegetables) will help improve health as well as reduce the negative environmental impacts of diets.7Milner J Green R Dangour AD et al.Health effects of adopting low greenhouse gas emission diets in the UK.BMJ Open. 2015; 5: e007364Crossref PubMed Scopus (89) Google Scholar Not all sustainable diets are equal. Rather, their impacts on health and environmental sustainability will depend crucially on the local context, with large differences across regions demonstrated through this study and others.6Springmann M Wiebe K Mason-D'Croz D Rayner M Scarborough P Health and nutritional aspects of sustainable diet strategies and their association with environmental impacts: a global modelling analysis with country-level detail.Lancet Planet Health. 2018; 2: 451-461Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (323) Google Scholar, 8Vieux F Perignon M Gazan R Darmon N Dietary changes needed to improve diet sustainability: are they similar across Europe?.Eur J Clin Nutr. 2018; 72: 951-960Crossref PubMed Scopus (57) Google Scholar The analysis by Springmann and colleagues6Springmann M Wiebe K Mason-D'Croz D Rayner M Scarborough P Health and nutritional aspects of sustainable diet strategies and their association with environmental impacts: a global modelling analysis with country-level detail.Lancet Planet Health. 2018; 2: 451-461Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (323) Google Scholar supports the evidence that health outcomes and environmental impacts of diets can be improved by ensuring that dietary guidelines are followed and suggests a failure of communication and of food policy, not insufficient evidence. The task now is to translate that knowledge into practice by finding effective ways of bringing about the required changes. The proportion of people who meet dietary guidelines tends to be very low.9Krebs-Smith S Guenther PM Subar AF et al.Americans do not meet Federal dietary recommendations.J Nutr. 2010; 140: 1832-1838Crossref PubMed Scopus (520) Google Scholar, 10Jones NRV Tong TYN Monsivais P Meeting UK dietary recommendations is associated with higher estimated consumer food costs: an analysis using the National Diet and Nutrition Survey and consumer expenditure data, 2008‚Äì2012.Public Health Nutr. 2018; 21: 948-956Crossref PubMed Scopus (35) Google Scholar Reasons for this might vary according to the context: access to sufficient healthy food is a problem in low-income and middle-income countries (and among low-income groups worldwide), but in high-income countries, some targets are not met (eg, fruit and vegetable consumption) while other recommended limits are exceeded. The complex interplay of factors such as price, desirability, convenience, and culture makes designing interventions that will actually change diets a substantial challenge. Thus, research into sustainable diets will increasingly need to be co-designed and guided by input from those responsible for creating policy. The engagement aspect of research (with the public and stakeholders) will be more important than ever, and increased attention will need to be devoted to empirical applications of models and assessments of interventions. Desirable endpoints for diets across the globe have been well established, but the journey to achieving these is just beginning. We declare no competing interests. Health and nutritional aspects of sustainable diet strategies and their association with environmental impacts: a global modelling analysis with country-level detailApproaches for sustainable diets are context specific and can result in concurrent reductions in environmental and health impacts globally and in most regions, particularly in high-income and middle-income countries, but they can also increase resource use in low-income countries when diets diversify. A public health strategy focused on improving energy balance and dietary changes towards predominantly plant-based diets that are in line with evidence on healthy eating is a suitable approach for sustainable diets. Full-Text PDF Open Access

title: Research on climate change, health inequities, and migration in the Caribbean
display_name: Research on climate change, health inequities, and migration in the Caribbean

author.au_affiliation_raw: School of Social Work, Faculty of Arts and Sciences, University of Montreal, Montreal, QC H3T1N8, Canada
French Institute For Research on sustainable Development, CEPED (IRD-Universit√© Paris Descartes), Universit√©s Paris Sorbonne Cit√©s, ERL INSERM SAGESUD, Paris, France

ab: On Sept 18, 2017, a few days after Hurricane Irma caused extensive damage to the Caribbean, Hurricane Maria‚Äîanother category five hurricane‚Äîbadly hit many islands in the region. Among them was Dominica, a small island developing state (SIDS) of the Caribbean community, located in the Windward Islands between Guadeloupe in the north and Martinique in the south. Dominica was devastated after the passage of Hurricane Maria with at least 30 deaths out of a population of 72 000, and 60% of houses were either gone (blown into the sea or totally scattered in pieces across the island) or severely damaged.

title: A community-based approach integrating conservation, livelihoods, and health care in Indonesian Borneo
display_name: A community-based approach integrating conservation, livelihoods, and health care in Indonesian Borneo

author.au_affiliation_raw: Health In Harmony, Portland, OR, USA
Health In Harmony, Portland, OR, USA
Health In Harmony, Portland, OR, USA

ab: Human health is dependent on healthy ecosystems, yet often our quest for health drives environmental degradation. This issue is crucial for people living around Borneo's Gunung Palung National Park (GPNP), who in 2007, were still rampantly logging to pay for health care. Health In Harmony's pilot programme, Alam Sehat Lestari (ASRI), which was initiated in 2007, offers a disruptive model that combines access to affordable and high-quality health care, opportunities for alternative livelihoods and entrepreneurship, and conservation programmes to restore the severely degraded park. GPNP, a 108 000 hectare protected area in Indonesian Borneo, is well known for its biodiversity and covers a vital watershed that supports more than 60 000 people living in 44 villages (appendix). Unfortunately, more than 70% of the lowland forests within the park's 10 km buffer zone around the outer perimeter of GPNP were deforested between 1988 and 2002.1Curran LM Trigg SN McDonald AK et al.Lowland forest loss in protected areas of Indonesian Borneo.Science. 2004; 303: 1000-1003Crossref PubMed Scopus (549) Google Scholar In 2007, Health In Harmony initiated a process of radical listening to identify the drivers of deforestation and to help communities design and implement solutions. After more than 400 h of community meetings, villages unanimously agreed they could stop logging if they had access to high-quality, affordable health care and training in alternative livelihoods. Before the work began in 2007, the communities bordering GPNP were extremely poor, with an average annual income of 3¬∑7 million Indonesian rupiah (US$1¬∑21 per day) in 2003.2Indonesia. Kayong Utara Regency in figures. Badan Pusat Statistik Kabupaten Ketapang, Sukadana2008Google Scholar Health-care services were either unavailable or of extremely low quality, and the nearest hospital was 2‚Äì12 h away. Poverty and a lack of access to affordable health care left local people with few choices of livelihoods, and many turned to logging. Health In Harmony's pilot programme, ASRI, uses an integrated approach that includes monitoring logging activity through community meetings, satellite imagery, and surveys; providing health care in ASRI's hospital, which offers non-cash payment options and progressive discounts to villages as they reduce rates of logging; making alternative livelihood opportunities available through training and assistance to people who want to stop logging; implementing conservation education programmes for all ages; and planting native rainforest trees in the park to restore crucial habitats for orangutans and other species. Quantitative results of ASRI have shown a positive impact, with an estimated 1350 logging households at baseline in 2007 decreasing to 450 households in 2012 and 150 in 2017 (an 89% decline from baseline; appendix). Geographic Information Systems data also show a stabilisation in primary forest loss and an increase in secondary forest growth (appendix). Additionally, the 2012 survey found 52% of previous loggers switched to farming. Survey results have also shown substantial improvements in health indicators. From 2007 to 2012, infant mortality declined from 3¬∑4 to 1¬∑1 deaths per 100 households. To date, ASRI has treated nearly 70 000 patients, maintained a patient dropout rate of less than 1% for tuberculosis treatment, distributed more than 1000 eyeglasses and 4000 mosquito nets, done monthly mobile clinic visits, and initiated maternity services at its hospital. ASRI has improved the health of people and the forest in the GPNP region in Borneo. This comprehensive approach to conservation and health care empowers individuals to improve their wellbeing and protect the natural ecosystems we all depend on. Funding Arcus Foundation, US Fish and Wildlife Service, A'lani Kailani Blue Lotus White Star Foundation, Tides Foundation, Sheryl Lee Osborne Foundation, Water Hope Foundation, Disney Conservation Fund, Softmatter Fund, The Ford Foundation, Mulago Foundation, The David and Lucile Packard Foundation, Reinsch Pierce Family Foundation, The Chapin Foundation, Sall Family Foundation, Dining For Women, The Grantham Foundation for the Protection of the Environment, Seneca Park Zoo Society, Full Circle Fund, Rotary Service Fund Of Burlingame, Fondation Lord Michelham, Francis and Christine Martin Family Foundation, Seaworld Busch Gardens Conservation Fund, Phoenix Zoo, Amanat Trust, Blank Park Zoo Foundation, Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, DIVERSITAS, The International Foundation, Utah Zoological Society (Hogle Zoo), Wild4Ever, CaringCrowd, Guilford Rotary Club, Sierra Club, Chicago Zoological Society, Lake Immunogenics, B1G1, Lantern Projects, Mongabay, Jacksonville Zoological Society, Earth Island Institute, Entrepreneurs' Organization, Yale University, Stanford University, University of Rochester, Johnson & Johnson Global Health Scholars Program, Kalpataru Award (managed by Indonesian Ministry of Environment and Forestry), The Prince Bernhard Nature Fund, Japan's Grant Assistance for Grassroots Human Security Projects, European Outdoor Conservation Association, USAID‚ÄìIndonesian Forest & Climate Support Project, Waterloo Foundation, Whitely Fund for Nature, World Wildlife Fund Russell E Train Education for Nature Program, and Bank Central Asia. Contributors KW contributed to study design and data collection, analysis, and interpretation. JJ and DM contributed to data analysis and interpretation, and writing of the Case Report. Declaration of interests We declare no competing interests. Download .pdf (.19 MB) Help with pdf files Supplementary appendix

title: Earth, wind, rain, and melioidosis
display_name: Earth, wind, rain, and melioidosis

author.au_affiliation_raw: Division of Infectious Disease, National University Hospital, Singapore
Division of Infectious Disease, National University Hospital, Singapore

ab: The earliest report of melioidosis is accredited to Whitmore and Krishnaswami1Whitmore A Krishnaswami CS A hitherto undescribed infective disease in Rangoon.Ind Med Gaz. 1912; 47: 262-267PubMed Google Scholar in Myanmar in 1912, in which they described a series of 38 patients presenting with a variant glanders-like disease. Autopsy showed "peculiar cheesy consolidation" of the lungs, subcutaneous or splenic abscesses with "non-Gram-staining-[Burkholderia mallei]-like bacilli". The infection, identified later in the Federated Malay States, was coined melioidosis in 1921. Indeed, naming the condition has been somewhat whimsical through the 20th century, with names given by those working with the organism to describe its key features, such as the clinical presentation (pseudoglanders), its latency (Vietnamese time bomb), or those at risk (morphia injector's septicaemia, Nightcliff gardener's disease and paddy-field disease). Mass underdiagnosis of melioidosis is evident across the tropics, and this is probably due in part to the lack of specific identifying features. The varied and quirky nicknames highlight that there is no simple way to describe this condition in lay terms. Melioidosis can incubate for 1 day or for decades, and it can be an acute fulminant condition or very slow mild disease (indeed, it can be asymptomatic). Although inoculation is typically cutaneous or inhalational, several other routes of transmission have been described, such as ingestion2Currie BJ Melioidosis: evolving concepts in epidemiology, pathogenesis, and treatment.Semin Respir Crit Care Med. 2015; 36: 111-125Crossref PubMed Scopus (170) Google Scholar and even sexual and mother-to-child transmission.3McCormick JB Sexton DJ McMurray JG Carey E Hayes P Feldman RA Human-to-human transmission of Pseudomonas pseudomallei.Ann Intern Med. 1975; 83: 512-513Crossref PubMed Scopus (75) Google Scholar A state of altered immunity influences the presentation and outcomes, but deaths of healthy military servicemen in Singapore have been described.4Lim MK Tan EH Soh CS Chang TL Burkholderia pseudomallei infection in the Singapore Armed Forces from 1987 to 1994‚Äîan epidemiological review.Ann Acad Med Singapore. 1997; 26: 13-17PubMed Google Scholar Melioidosis is relatively unknown to the public and is unidentified by health workers in most countries where it is endemic, except for perhaps Australia, Singapore, and Brunei.5Limmathurotsakul D Golding N Dance DA et al.Predicted global distribution of Burkholderia pseudomallei and burden of melioidosis.Nat Microbiol. 2016; 1: 15008Crossref Scopus (426) Google Scholar Stories of melioidosis feature routinely in the Australian Northern Territory's lay press.6NT NewsDarwin melioidosis warning following monsoonal rains.https://www.ntnews.com.au/news/darwin-melioidosis-warning-following-monsoonal-rains/news-story/c0ed87f63607314f4ea4f55a0b5faf9fDate: Jan 30, 2018Date accessed: July 11, 2018Google Scholar By contrast, in Thailand there is little public knowledge.7Chansrichavala P Wongsuwan N Suddee S et al.Public awareness of melioidosis in Thailand and potential use of video clips as educational tools.PloS One. 2015; 10: e0121311Crossref PubMed Scopus (13) Google Scholar Why is melioidosis so underdiagnosed? Being a disease of the tropics, it is endemic in many countries with less sophisticated health systems. Melioidosis requires a laboratory diagnosis because the clinical features and presentations are so variable and non-specific. Laboratory systems are even less accessible in rural areas, where most cases present. In this issue of The Lancet Planetary Health, Philip Bulterys and colleagues8Bulterys PL Bulterys MA Phommasone K et al.Climatic drivers of melioidosis in Laos and Cambodia: a 16-year case series analysis.Lancet Planet Health. 2018; 2: e334-e343Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (11) Google Scholar report findings from their study of melioidosis in Laos and Cambodia, where the incidence of the disease has not been previously well described. The authors identified humidity, visibility, rainfall, and wind speed as independent predictors of melioidosis, thus adding to the pool of data from Thailand, Singapore, and northern Australia that links weather with the incidence of disease.9Liu X Pang L Sim SH et al.Association of melioidosis incidence with rainfall and humidity, Singapore, 2003‚Äì2012.Emerg Infect Dis. 2015; 21: 159-162Crossref PubMed Scopus (35) Google Scholar There is a clear seasonal pattern of increased melioidosis incidence during the monsoon season, which sweeps through Asia bringing heavy rainfall.9Liu X Pang L Sim SH et al.Association of melioidosis incidence with rainfall and humidity, Singapore, 2003‚Äì2012.Emerg Infect Dis. 2015; 21: 159-162Crossref PubMed Scopus (35) Google Scholar Additionally, extreme weather events can precede melioidosis clusters. Tropical, unpredictable wet weather, especially with occurrence of the La Ni√±a phenomenon, can create flooding in rural and highly urbanised areas alike. Precipitation and humidity optimise conditions for Burkholderia pseudomallei. Bulterys and colleagues, and others,10Limmathurotsakul D Kanoksil M Wuthiekanun V et al.Activities of daily living associated with acquisition of melioidosis in northeast Thailand: a matched case-control study.PLoS Negl Trop Dis. 2013; 7: e2072Crossref PubMed Scopus (92) Google Scholar have made a strong case for water exposure being central to transmission of disease. This theory, together with the significant invocation of wind speed, substantiates the current perception that inhalation of aerosolised B pseudomallei is a major method of acquisition and, in particular, predisposing people to fulminant pneumonia. The pathogen is small and devoid of advanced homoeostatic or thermostatic mechanisms. As such, humidity and temperature changes have a bearing on B pseudomallei growth characteristics, including survival and incubation times. Indeed, B pseudomallei exhibits enhanced growth, motility, and tolerance to environmental stress at hotter, tropical temperatures.11Paksanont S Sintiprungrat K Yimthin T Pumirat P Peacock SJ Chantratita N Effect of temperature on Burkholderia pseudomallei growth, proteomic changes, motility and resistance to stress environments.Sci Rep. 2018; 8: 9167Crossref PubMed Scopus (9) Google Scholar Unique geographical or local characteristics also facilitate prevalence of the disease. Melioidosis is common in the Asia-Pacific region, where agriculture and farming are prominent. Anthrosol and acrisol soil, encountered in irrigated agriculture in this geographical region, favour B pseudomallei.10Limmathurotsakul D Kanoksil M Wuthiekanun V et al.Activities of daily living associated with acquisition of melioidosis in northeast Thailand: a matched case-control study.PLoS Negl Trop Dis. 2013; 7: e2072Crossref PubMed Scopus (92) Google Scholar Agricultural practices, including residual crop burning that results in depletion of soil nutrients, further support B pseudomallei. Rice-field workers and others exposed to soil or the ingestion of contaminated water have high risks of melioidosis.2Currie BJ Melioidosis: evolving concepts in epidemiology, pathogenesis, and treatment.Semin Respir Crit Care Med. 2015; 36: 111-125Crossref PubMed Scopus (170) Google Scholar, 10Limmathurotsakul D Kanoksil M Wuthiekanun V et al.Activities of daily living associated with acquisition of melioidosis in northeast Thailand: a matched case-control study.PLoS Negl Trop Dis. 2013; 7: e2072Crossref PubMed Scopus (92) Google Scholar Concerns about the effect of climate change on infectious diseases are understated. Global warming and extreme weather, together with soil changes and unplanned urbanisation, may cause an increase in the incidence and the geographical spread of melioidosis. Improved understanding of climatic factors that facilitate transmission could allow for improved awareness by the public and health workers. However, this understanding needs to translate to improved surveillance, diagnostics, and interventions for prevention and case management. Linking these efforts to weather conditions could provide the best value for countries with many competing health priorities. This online publication has been corrected. The corrected version first appeared at thelancet.com/planetaryhealth on February 20, 2019 This online publication has been corrected. The corrected version first appeared at thelancet.com/planetaryhealth on February 20, 2019 LYAC is supported by the Clinician Scientist Award, Individual Research Grant, Bedside & Bench Grants, Centre Grant, and the Training Fellowship Award from the National Medical Research Council, Singapore. LYAC. also acknowledges the Aspiration Grant & Summit Research Program and Bench to Bedside Grant from the National University Health System, as well as the Synthetic Biology Research & Development Program of the National Research Foundation, Singapore. DF declares no competing interests. Climatic drivers of melioidosis in Laos and Cambodia: a 16-year case series analysisThe results of this study demonstrate a significant seasonal burden of melioidosis among adults and children in Laos and Cambodia. Our findings highlight the risks of infection during highly humid and windy conditions, and suggest a need for increased awareness among at-risk individuals, such as children. Full-Text PDF Open AccessCorrection to Lancet Planet Health 2018; 2: e329‚Äì30Chai LYA, Fisher D. Earth, wind, rain, and melioidosis. Lancet Planet Health 2018; 2: e329‚Äì30‚ÄîThe reference to the linked Article by Philip Bulterys and colleagues has been corrected. This correction has been made to the online version as of Feb 20, 2010, and the printed version is correct. Full-Text PDF Open Access

title: Imagination challenges in planetary health: re-conceptualising the human-environment relationship
display_name: Imagination challenges in planetary health: re-conceptualising the human-environment relationship

author.au_affiliation_raw: Heidelberg Institute of Global Health, and Heidelberg Centre for the Environment, Heidelberg University, 69120 Heidelberg, Germany

ab: The new field of planetary health has identified three key challenges, concerning imagination, knowledge, and implementation.1Whitmee S Haines A Beyrer C et al.Safeguarding human health in the Anthropocene epoch: report of The Rockefeller Foundation-Lancet Commission on planetary health.Lancet. 2015; 386: 1973-2028Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1125) Google Scholar We need research to increase our knowledge on how anthropogenic environmental change is affecting human health, through short-term (eg, air pollution) and long-term (eg, climate change), direct (eg, heat effects), and complex pathways (eg, biodiversity loss). We also need to improve our understanding of how we can implement sustainable solutions to stay within planetary boundaries, which will help to avoid catastrophic long-term consequences for human health and survival, as well as often also having immediate human health co-benefits (eg, improved cardiovascular health through active transport). We also need to fundamentally rethink our relationship with the planet, combining philosophical, ethical, literary, medical, and other perspectives, ideally creating a positive vision which can energise the so-called Great Transformation of human societies globally, which we so urgently need. This Comment aims to stimulate debate around such a re-conceptualisation. With increasing success in domesticating and controlling nature, humans have started to regard themselves as separate from nature. The environment is, however, also within us: we breathe the air, drink the water, eat other species, co-exist with millions of microorganisms on our external and internal surfaces, all of which are essential to our health and survival. Furthermore, now that we have entered the Anthropocene epoch, with humans as the major shaping force of the planet, there is no pure nature or untouched environment, so to speak, anymore; everything on this planet is influenced by human activities. Thus, the environment is part of us and we are part of the environment. James Lovelock and Lynn Margulis suggested in the 1970s that the Earth can be regarded as a superorganism, with self-regulatory feedback loops and emerging properties, ie, the whole being more than its parts, similar to a beehive that can keep its temperature stable over a certain range, although the individual insects cannot, without presupposing any intended purpose or consciousness.2Lovelock JE Gaia: a new look at life on earth. Oxford University Press, Oxford1979Google Scholar Lovelock and Margulis' idea was named Gaia theory, after the Greek earth goddess, a suggestion by Lovelock's neighbour, the writer William Golding. The theory implies that we are part of a larger entity, Gaia or, less poetic, the Earth system, that we are one component of a living planet, connected with all its other components, and totally dependent on it for our survival‚Äîa powerful image. What role do humans play today as part of the superorganism Earth? Our role has been compared to that of a cancer or a parasite infesting the Earth.3MacDougall AK Humans as cancer.http://www.brontaylor.com/courses/pdf/MacDougall--HumansCancer.pdfDate: 1996Date accessed: August 14, 2018Google Scholar The defining feature of cancer cells is that their growth is unregulated, ie, they do not react to feedback mechanisms, consequently using up a disproportionate amount of energy, invading other tissues, and eventually damaging vital organs and leading to death. Humans have emerged from the Earth, then gained some independence from nature by using technology. We liberated ourselves from constraints in food and energy supplies through using fossil fuels, and increased our population size and consumption exponentially. We are consuming vast natural resources and dumping toxic by-products into the air, water, and soil. As we gained independence from nature through technology, we also started disconnecting emotionally and ethically, dissociating ourselves from nature. We gave ourselves the right to exploit all other species as we please, seeing them as a pile of resources to be used for ourselves, the self-appointed pinnacle of evolution. It is clear now, however, that our success has become our biggest enemy. We cannot defeat nature as we are a part of it. Just like a cancer cannot defeat the body. The moment of a cancer's biggest success, the peak of its growth, is right before the collapse of the larger system. Albert Einstein famously pointed out that we cannot solve a problem with the same mindset that created it, that we need a new way of thinking if humanity is to survive. The first step towards solving our global environmental problems could be to rethink the human-environment relationship and realise that we are part of a living planet, but have been behaving like a cancer and need to re-integrate ourselves into the planetary feedback loops. Such re-integration does not imply reverting to (cruel) natural regulation mechanisms through hunger and disease, as existed during the stone age, can be achieved through self-regulation using social and political mechanisms, such as family planning and carbon taxes. As Heinrich von Kleist wrote in his essay On the Marionette Theatre,4von Kleist H On the marionette theatre.http://southerncrossreview.org/9/kleist.htmDate accessed: July 1, 2018Google Scholar once humans have eaten from the tree of knowledge and been thrown out of paradise, there is no easy way back; but we have to make the journey around the world and see if we can find an entrance to paradise from the other end. Kleist describes the example of the professional dancer striving to regain the gracefulness of the puppet, and, in a similar way, humanity has to try and find ways of reconnecting with nature at a conscious level. With humans now interfering with almost all of the Earth's systems, we are steering into the Anthropocene epoch with vastly less stable and hospitable conditions for human societies than during the Holocene epoch. To stay within the safe operating space as defined by the planetary boundaries approach and not destabilise planetary systems beyond critical tipping points,5Steffen W Richardson K Rockstr√∂m J et al.Planetary boundaries: guiding human development on a changing planet.Science. 2015; 347: 1259855Crossref PubMed Scopus (5075) Google Scholar we must learn how to organise ourselves differently. Similar to a beehive, humanity needs to act intelligently as a whole, as a global community. Can our political systems and institutions respond to this challenge in a timely fashion? Why have we been painfully slow at responding so far? Why are we failing to recognise the scale and urgency of the problem? A deeper understanding of ourselves and a transformation of our value system might be required to change our actions, as has been highlighted by some religious leaders.6Lama Dalai Ethics for the new millennium. Riverhead Books, New York1999Google Scholar, 7Francis Pope Encyclical letter Laudato si': on care for our common home. Vatican Press, 2015http://w2.vatican.va/content/francesco/en/encyclicals/documents/papa-francesco_20150524_enciclica-laudato-si.htmlDate accessed: July 1, 2018Google Scholar Besides improved regulatory mechanisms at societal and political levels, we might need ethical principles to guide and self-regulate our behaviour. As the Brazilian environmentalist Jos√© Lutzenberger pointed out, the environmental crisis is not primarily a technological challenge, but rather an ethical challenge, in that our current mainstream ethics are human-centred, exclude other living beings, and devaluate nature.8Lutzenberger JA Our suicidal ethics. Written for the World Ethics Congress, K√ºhlungsborn, Germany.http://www.fgaia.org.br/texts/e-worldethics.htmlDate: 2000Date accessed: July 1, 2018Google Scholar Albert Schweitzer's concept of Reverence for Life9Schweitzer A Reverence for life: the words of Albert Schweitzer. Maurice Basset, Anna Maria, FL2017Google Scholar and many indigenous value systems give nature its own intrinsic value, as well as foster an understanding that we are part of a living Earth, together with so many other beings, and not the only species on the planet that matters. We need to transform societal structures and individual minds from a focus on having to a focus on being, as highlighted already in the 1970s by Erich Fromm.10Fromm E To have or to be? A new blueprint for mankind. Harper & Row, New York1976Google Scholar Humans can be greedy and selfish, exploiting others and nature, like the Homo economicus in economists' models, but we can also choose to behave differently and cultivate generosity and compassion, realising our interconnectedness. In a world where spirituality has been lost and where unlimited growth has gained the status of a religion, this connectedness to other humans and other species, this feeling of being embedded into a bigger whole, having a purpose, and actively working towards the wellbeing of others and the planet could be a true and lasting source of happiness. Many thinkers, activists, communities, and social movements are working towards such a transformational change in our worldview and actions, in line with the statements in the Lancet's manifesto for planetary health.11Horton R Beaglehole R Bonita R Raeburn J McKee M Wall S From public to planetary health: a manifesto.Lancet. 2014; 383: 847Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (188) Google Scholar As health professionals, aware of the imminent collapse of our civilisation if we continue with business as usual, the formidable challenges ahead, but also the tremendous opportunities, we should be joining these forces. I declare no competing interests.

title: Prevention of malaria transmission around reservoirs: an observational and modelling study on the effect of wind direction and village location
display_name: Prevention of malaria transmission around reservoirs: an observational and modelling study on the effect of wind direction and village location

author.au_affiliation_raw: Ralph M Parsons Laboratory, Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA, USA
Ralph M Parsons Laboratory, Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA, USA

ab: BackgroundMany large dams are constructed annually in Africa, with associated reservoirs that might exacerbate the risk of malaria in new villages built nearby. We aimed to investigate the heterogeneous risk of malaria around reservoirs related to the impact of wind direction on malaria transmission.MethodsBetween June 15, 2012, and April 22, 2015, we obtained field data on climate and hydrological conditions, and monitored Anopheles mosquito populations around the Koka reservoir in Ethiopia using in-situ weather stations, mosquito light traps, and larval dipping. The field data were used to calibrate a field-tested, spatially explicit mechanistic malaria transmission model, the Hydrology, Entomology, and Malaria Transmission Simulator (HYDREMATS), to investigate the effect of relative wind direction on malaria transmission and associated mechanisms. We combined our simulation results and observational data to assess the association between village location around a reservoir and risk of malaria.FindingsHYDREMATS simulations showed that wind blowing from a village towards a reservoir increases the size of malaria vector populations, whereas wind blowing from a reservoir towards a village decreases the size of malaria vector populations, which was consistent with our field data. Larval mortality is low in locations with village-to-reservoir wind due to weak surface waves, and this wind direction creates conditions that enable mosquitoes to identify village locations more easily than in conditions caused by reservoir-to-village wind, which increases the size of malaria vector populations, and thus malaria transmission. Among the wind conditions investigated (0¬∑5‚Äì5 m/s), the effect of CO2 attraction on the size of the Anopheles population was largest at wind speeds of 0¬∑5 m/s and 1 m/s, decreasing with higher wind speed. At a wind speed of 5 m/s, the effect of CO2 attraction was negligible, whereas the effect of waves was strongest. The effect of advection on Anopheles population size was negligible at all wind speeds and wind directions.InterpretationThe effect of wind on malaria transmission around reservoirs can be substantial. The transmission of malaria can be minimised if the location of villages situated near a reservoir is carefully considered. For areas in which the environmental conditions surrounding a resevoir are equal, villages should be located downwind of reservoirs to reduce the incidence of malaria, although further research will be required in locations where wind direction changes in different seasons.FundingUS National Science Foundation, and Cooperative Agreement between the Masdar Institute of Science and Technology, Abu Dhabi, UAE, and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA, USA.
grants: Masdar Institute of Science and Technology

Boston University School of Public Health, Boston, MA, USA
Boston University School of Public Health, Boston, MA, USA

ab: The 2018 North Atlantic hurricane season is underway, accompanied by the timely publication of advances in atmospheric science that confirm what was observed during the hyperactive 2017 experience.1Kossin JP A global slowdown of tropical-cyclone translation speed.Nature. 2018; 558: 104-107Crossref PubMed Scopus (303) Google Scholar During 2017, atmospheric and oceanic conditions combined to generate 17 named storms that collectively and repetitively emphasised the connections among climate drivers, storm hazards, and destructive impacts on vulnerable human populations.2Shultz JM Kossin JP Shepherd JM et al.Risks, health consequences, and response challenges for small-island-based populations: observations from the 2017 Atlantic hurricane season.Disaster Med Public Health Prep. 2018; (published online Apr 6.)DOI:10.1017/dmp.2018.28Crossref Scopus (39) Google Scholar In many ways, the expression "perfect storm"3Junger S The perfect storm: a true story of men against the sea. WW Norton & Company, New York2000Google Scholar (a reference to a ferocious 1991 nor'easter) could well be extended to refer to 2017 as an entire perfect storm season that raised issues of environmental injustice intrinsic to climate change, particularly in relation to its disproportionate effect on Caribbean small island developing states (SIDS).2Shultz JM Kossin JP Shepherd JM et al.Risks, health consequences, and response challenges for small-island-based populations: observations from the 2017 Atlantic hurricane season.Disaster Med Public Health Prep. 2018; (published online Apr 6.)DOI:10.1017/dmp.2018.28Crossref Scopus (39) Google Scholar Climate change has been aptly conceptualised as "an environmental hazard operating on a global scale" and 2017 provided a strong illustration of this paradigm.4Patz JA Gibbs HK Foley JA Rogers JV Smith KR Climate change and global health: quantifying a growing ethical crisis.EcoHealth. 2007; 4: 397-405Crossref Scopus (181) Google Scholar On key metrics tracked by the Colorado State University's Tropical Meteorology Project‚Äînamed tropical cyclone numbers and days, hurricane numbers and days, and major hurricane numbers and days‚Äîthe 2017 season far exceeded the 1981‚Äì2010 baseline norms.2Shultz JM Kossin JP Shepherd JM et al.Risks, health consequences, and response challenges for small-island-based populations: observations from the 2017 Atlantic hurricane season.Disaster Med Public Health Prep. 2018; (published online Apr 6.)DOI:10.1017/dmp.2018.28Crossref Scopus (39) Google Scholar As a further distinction, the accumulated cyclone energy, a summative measure of storm intensity for the entire basin, was the highest on record for the month of September and seventh overall for the complete hurricane season.2Shultz JM Kossin JP Shepherd JM et al.Risks, health consequences, and response challenges for small-island-based populations: observations from the 2017 Atlantic hurricane season.Disaster Med Public Health Prep. 2018; (published online Apr 6.)DOI:10.1017/dmp.2018.28Crossref Scopus (39) Google Scholar In addition to warm ocean temperatures, high thermal potential, and minimal vertical wind shear, 2017 illustrated how environmental warming can produce extreme precipitation rates and rainfall accumulations as storms stall over populated areas.1Kossin JP A global slowdown of tropical-cyclone translation speed.Nature. 2018; 558: 104-107Crossref PubMed Scopus (303) Google Scholar, 5Shultz JM Galea S Mitigating the mental and physical health consequences of Hurricane Harvey.JAMA. 2017; 318: 1437-1438Crossref PubMed Scopus (69) Google Scholar The UN formally recognises the heightened disaster risks faced by 57 SIDS situated along the midsection of the globe worldwide. The 29 Caribbean SIDS are extraordinarily vulnerable to strikes by Atlantic basin hurricanes.2Shultz JM Kossin JP Shepherd JM et al.Risks, health consequences, and response challenges for small-island-based populations: observations from the 2017 Atlantic hurricane season.Disaster Med Public Health Prep. 2018; (published online Apr 6.)DOI:10.1017/dmp.2018.28Crossref Scopus (39) Google Scholar Depending upon storm properties, time, and place, SIDS residents were exposed to various hurricane hazards: cyclonic and tornadic winds, deluging rains, storm surge, wave action, coastal inundation, inland flooding, and mudslides. As a consequence of their distinctive disaster risk landscape, SIDS inhabitants bore much of the brunt of hurricane-induced human harm and environmental destruction (panel).2Shultz JM Kossin JP Shepherd JM et al.Risks, health consequences, and response challenges for small-island-based populations: observations from the 2017 Atlantic hurricane season.Disaster Med Public Health Prep. 2018; (published online Apr 6.)DOI:10.1017/dmp.2018.28Crossref Scopus (39) Google ScholarPanelDisaster risk landscape for small island developing states (SIDS)‚Ä¢SIDS are primarily located in tropical latitudes where hurricanes occur frequently‚Ä¢Climate scientists predict sea level rise and increasing tropical storm intensity over the next few decades‚Ä¢As island nations with an ocean perimeter, SIDS are extremely vulnerable to sea level rise and related risks for storm surge‚Ä¢SIDS with minimal elevation above sea level are susceptible to pummelling from wave action and inundation from downpours‚Ä¢SIDS with steep, mountainous terrain are prone to mudslides‚Ä¢Mass off-island population evacuation is logistically unfeasible when storms approach and most SIDS are too small to achieve meaningful inland evacuation away from coastlines‚Ä¢Many SIDS are composed of multiple inhabited islands, thereby complicating emergency response activities that must reach geographically isolated pockets of citizens affected by storm‚Ä¢Island infrastructure, particularly electrical power, is fragile and easily destroyed when strong storms strike‚Ä¢SIDS disaster management services are typically rudimentary and under-resourced‚Ä¢Tropical and sub-tropical SIDS are endemic for vector-borne infectious diseases‚Ä¢SIDS have scarce economic resources to expend at any phase of disaster: preparedness, mitigation, response, or recovery‚Ä¢Elevated climate-related risks for SIDS are largely determined by the actions of high-income, highly-industrialised countries ‚Ä¢SIDS are primarily located in tropical latitudes where hurricanes occur frequently‚Ä¢Climate scientists predict sea level rise and increasing tropical storm intensity over the next few decades‚Ä¢As island nations with an ocean perimeter, SIDS are extremely vulnerable to sea level rise and related risks for storm surge‚Ä¢SIDS with minimal elevation above sea level are susceptible to pummelling from wave action and inundation from downpours‚Ä¢SIDS with steep, mountainous terrain are prone to mudslides‚Ä¢Mass off-island population evacuation is logistically unfeasible when storms approach and most SIDS are too small to achieve meaningful inland evacuation away from coastlines‚Ä¢Many SIDS are composed of multiple inhabited islands, thereby complicating emergency response activities that must reach geographically isolated pockets of citizens affected by storm‚Ä¢Island infrastructure, particularly electrical power, is fragile and easily destroyed when strong storms strike‚Ä¢SIDS disaster management services are typically rudimentary and under-resourced‚Ä¢Tropical and sub-tropical SIDS are endemic for vector-borne infectious diseases‚Ä¢SIDS have scarce economic resources to expend at any phase of disaster: preparedness, mitigation, response, or recovery‚Ä¢Elevated climate-related risks for SIDS are largely determined by the actions of high-income, highly-industrialised countries For the 2017 Atlantic storms, public health consequences accrued continuously over a period of months. Modest impact-phase mortality figures were tabulated for Hurricanes Harvey (91 deaths) and Irma (134 deaths; 90 US mainland citizens, 44 Caribbean). Puerto Rico, however, had prolonged and crippling island-wide power outages following the impacts of Irma and Maria and substantial post-storm mortality.6Santos-Lozada AR Howard JT Use of death counts from vital statistics to calculate excess deaths in Puerto Rico following Hurricane Maria.JAMA. 2018; (published online Aug 2.) (preprint)DOI:10.1001/jama.2018.10929Crossref PubMed Scopus (63) Google Scholar Millions of Caribbean SIDS and mainland US residents experienced traumatic effects due to wind and water hazards. In addition to injuries during clean-up, SIDS experienced elevated rates of morbidity including epidemics of infectious and vector-borne diseases. Mental health issues become evident several months into the recovery phase. Traumatic, life-threatening exposures to storm hazards during impact, experienced by millions in the Caribbean, followed by extreme hardships in the aftermath, and exacerbated by months without power, can lead to increases in post-traumatic stress disorder, major depressive disorder, suicidality, and substance use.5Shultz JM Galea S Mitigating the mental and physical health consequences of Hurricane Harvey.JAMA. 2017; 318: 1437-1438Crossref PubMed Scopus (69) Google Scholar, 7Ferr√© IM, Negr√≥n S, Shultz JM, et al. Hurricane Maria's impact on Punta Santiago, Puerto Rico: community needs and mental health assessment six months post-impact. Disaster Med Public Health Prep (in press).Google Scholar Population displacement and outmigration adds another element to the public health consequences of these storms.2Shultz JM Kossin JP Shepherd JM et al.Risks, health consequences, and response challenges for small-island-based populations: observations from the 2017 Atlantic hurricane season.Disaster Med Public Health Prep. 2018; (published online Apr 6.)DOI:10.1017/dmp.2018.28Crossref Scopus (39) Google Scholar, 8Galea S Climate change and our health.in: Galea S Healthier: fifty thoughts on the foundations of population health. Oxford University Press, New York2018: 101-104Google Scholar The inhospitable conditions on the Caribbean SIDS following the 2017 storms triggered a mass, largely unidirectional, exodus of islanders to off-island, continental destinations, especially for survivors of Hurricanes Irma and Maria, which rendered most of Puerto Rico without power for months.7Ferr√© IM, Negr√≥n S, Shultz JM, et al. Hurricane Maria's impact on Punta Santiago, Puerto Rico: community needs and mental health assessment six months post-impact. Disaster Med Public Health Prep (in press).Google Scholar SIDS are very sensitive to the effects of climate change. As powerfully demonstrated by the 2017 season, climate-driven increases in the hazard properties of tropical cyclones, combined with progressive increases in sea level, pose both disproportionate disaster risks and existential threats to SIDS.1Kossin JP A global slowdown of tropical-cyclone translation speed.Nature. 2018; 558: 104-107Crossref PubMed Scopus (303) Google Scholar, 2Shultz JM Kossin JP Shepherd JM et al.Risks, health consequences, and response challenges for small-island-based populations: observations from the 2017 Atlantic hurricane season.Disaster Med Public Health Prep. 2018; (published online Apr 6.)DOI:10.1017/dmp.2018.28Crossref Scopus (39) Google Scholar Moreover, SIDS residents serve unwittingly as sentinel populations for detecting and documenting the first signs of climate change effects on population health.2Shultz JM Kossin JP Shepherd JM et al.Risks, health consequences, and response challenges for small-island-based populations: observations from the 2017 Atlantic hurricane season.Disaster Med Public Health Prep. 2018; (published online Apr 6.)DOI:10.1017/dmp.2018.28Crossref Scopus (39) Google Scholar Ironically, SIDS by necessity contribute minimally to the production of greenhouse gases. Yet, despite being among those least responsible for environmental change, SIDS populations are those most likely to experience severe public and environmental health consequences.1Kossin JP A global slowdown of tropical-cyclone translation speed.Nature. 2018; 558: 104-107Crossref PubMed Scopus (303) Google Scholar, 4Patz JA Gibbs HK Foley JA Rogers JV Smith KR Climate change and global health: quantifying a growing ethical crisis.EcoHealth. 2007; 4: 397-405Crossref Scopus (181) Google Scholar, 9Boeckmann M Zeeb H Justice and equity implications of climate change adaptation: a theoretical evaluation framework.Healthcare. 2016; 4: 65Crossref Scopus (9) Google Scholar Climate change magnifies health inequities. Issues of environmental injustice and health inequity are central to the understanding of the contribution of the actions of high-income countries to the pace and magnitude of climate change. The behaviours of wealthy industrialised nations set off effects that spread globally and result in the involuntary exposure4Patz JA Gibbs HK Foley JA Rogers JV Smith KR Climate change and global health: quantifying a growing ethical crisis.EcoHealth. 2007; 4: 397-405Crossref Scopus (181) Google Scholar, 9Boeckmann M Zeeb H Justice and equity implications of climate change adaptation: a theoretical evaluation framework.Healthcare. 2016; 4: 65Crossref Scopus (9) Google Scholar of vulnerable populations to climate-associated hazards not of their own creation.4Patz JA Gibbs HK Foley JA Rogers JV Smith KR Climate change and global health: quantifying a growing ethical crisis.EcoHealth. 2007; 4: 397-405Crossref Scopus (181) Google Scholar, 10Levy BS Patz JA Climate change, human rights, and social justice.Ann Glob Health. 2015; 81: 310-322Crossref PubMed Scopus (181) Google Scholar, 11McMichael C Barnett J McMichael AJ An ill wind? Climate change, migration and health.Environ Health Perspect. 2012; 120: 646-654Crossref PubMed Scopus (170) Google Scholar This gross asymmetry, illustrated by the experience of the Caribbean SIDS, represents an enormous, global scale environmental injustice.2Shultz JM Kossin JP Shepherd JM et al.Risks, health consequences, and response challenges for small-island-based populations: observations from the 2017 Atlantic hurricane season.Disaster Med Public Health Prep. 2018; (published online Apr 6.)DOI:10.1017/dmp.2018.28Crossref Scopus (39) Google Scholar Large industrialised nations hold the fate of SIDS in their hands, as they delay needed climate solutions in favour of profit-driven and self-interested policy objectives. Even as many of the SIDS have established themselves as independent, sovereign states, the subjugation of their economic, ecological, and existential survival to the behaviour of large, high-income countries extends colonial dependence of these smaller countries' wellbeing on actions beyond their control. We declare no competing interests.

title: Antimicrobial resistance: an urgent need for a planetary and ecosystem approach
display_name: Antimicrobial resistance: an urgent need for a planetary and ecosystem approach

author.au_affiliation_raw: Healthcare Information for all, Charlbury, OX7 3PN, UK

ab: Our planet is rushing towards a post-antibiotic era and the global burden of antimicrobial resistance is estimated to rise to 10 million annual deaths by 2050,1de Kraker ME Stewardson AJ Harbarth S Will 10 million people die a year due to antimicrobial resistance by 2050?.PLoS Med. 2016; 13: e1002184Crossref PubMed Scopus (625) Google Scholar a figure that can substantially increase if adequate measures are not taken. Antimicrobial resistance is an ancient but complex phenomenon that emerges in response to antimicrobial exposure. The abundance of existing scientific publications on antimicrobial resistance in an environmental context supports its inclusion in the planetary health agenda. Unfortunately, antimicrobial resistance is still a public health concern and it has not been considered a priority area to work on from an ecological perspective. Ecologists and Earth scientists have not been made aware of this situation and have not been included in discussions of control strategies between public health experts and social scientists. Woolhouse and colleagues2Woolhouse M Ward M van Bunnik B Farrar J Antimicrobial resistance in humans, livestock and the wider environment.Philos Trans R Soc Lond B Biol Sci. 2015; 70: 20140083Crossref Scopus (339) Google Scholar have shown that the problem of antimicrobial resistance is analogous to climate change and have urged the development of an intergovernmental panel to address the problem. Their justification for the need of this panel is logical because of the global magnitude of antimicrobial resistance, and because of its multidisciplinary involvement in pathogenesis and prevention pathways. Currently, there are no set targets for antibiotic use or global regulations for pharmaceutical waste disposal, unlike the regulations that control the level of carbon emissions. A more integrated implementation approach should be adopted for the resource-poor settings because of the highest burden of antimicrobial resistance in low-income and middle-income countries with extensive environmental transmission.3Alvarez-Uria G Gandra S Laxminarayan R Poverty and prevalence of antimicrobial resistance in invasive isolates.Int J Infect Dis. 2016; 52: 59-61Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (48) Google Scholar The less studied but enormous impact of antibiotics on the biogeochemical processes in the ecological system, especially on the production of toxic gases such as nitrous oxide and nitrite, has been discussed by Amsaleg and Laverman.4Roose-Amsaleg C Laverman AM Do antibiotics have environmental side-effects? Impact of synthetic antibiotics on biogeochemical processes.Environ Sci Pollut Res Int. 2016; 23: 4000-4012Crossref PubMed Scopus (133) Google Scholar Another important area that should be explored is the impact of antimicrobial resistance genes reaching the Earth's critical zone, which is the outer layer of the Earth that comprises soil, air, microbial agents, water, and rock.5Zhu YG Gillings M Simonet P Stekel D Banwart S Penuelas J Human dissemination of genes and microorganisms in Earth's Critical Zone.Glob Chang Biol. 2017; (published online Dec 20.)DOI:10.1111/gcb.14003Google Scholar Further studies on the impact of antibiotic residue at chronic, environmentally relevant concentrations are important to further address the issue of antimicrobial resistance. The prioritisation of antibiotics based on their effect on ecological processes is also necessary for regulatory purposes. In their review,6Huijbers PM Blaak H de Jong MC Graat EA Vandenbroucke-Grauls CM de Roda Husman AM Role of the environment in the transmission of antimicrobial resistance to humans: a review.Environ Sci Technol. 2015; 49: 11993-12004Crossref PubMed Scopus (237) Google Scholar Huijbers and colleagues discuss the plausible transmission of clinically significant resistant organisms from the environment to human beings. Many settings can harbour resistant bacteria, including fresh water, waste water, soil, air, dust, fresh produce, meat, wildlife, and even animal manure. A review by Costello and colleagues7Costello EK Stagaman K Dethlefsen L Bohannan BJ Relman DA The application of ecological theory toward an understanding of the human microbiome.Science. 2012; 336: 1255-1262Crossref PubMed Scopus (932) Google Scholar sheds light on the link between the human microbial ecosystem and disease caused by resistant bacteria. They describe the role of community ecology on individual gut microbiota, and the influence of local environmental diversity and selection pressures on resistance. The antimicrobial effect of heavy metals exists for a longer time in the environment, acting as an additional selective pressure and worsening the effect of antimicrobial resistance.8Yu Z Gunn L Wall P Fanning S Antimicrobial resistance and its association with tolerance to heavy metals in agriculture production.Food Microbiol. 2017; 64: 23-32Crossref PubMed Scopus (90) Google Scholar All these facts establish the urgency of acknowledgement of antimicrobial resistance as a distinct discipline in planetary health. One of the major solutions to this problem involves the adoption of environmental mitigation strategies. The most effective pathway to reducing selection pressures involves removal of antibiotic residues and development of new drugs. Medicinal plants and fungi have been used widely in the past to fight human and animal pathogens and could be the key to production of new antibiotics. A review by Savoia9Savoia D Plant-derived antimicrobial compounds: alternatives to antibiotics.Future Microbiol. 2012; 7: 979-990Crossref PubMed Scopus (331) Google Scholar states that 69% of antibiotics approved between 1981 and 2006 were derived from natural plant products. Ethnopharmacology, which involves the medicinal use of plants, is one of the major alternative pathways that are still available to control antimicrobial resistance. It is obvious that the ongoing policies for prevention of antimicrobial resistance will be ineffective if no interventions are made to tackle environmental reservoirs of antibiotic resistance, such as biofilms. Over time, the magnitude of resistance will surpass the threshold level.10Wallinga D Rayner G Lang T Antimicrobial resistance and biological governance: explanations for policy failure.Public Health. 2015; 129: 1314-1325Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (20) Google Scholar In addition to doctors and veterinarians, people from multiple disciplines (eg, ecologists, Earth and marine scientists, epidemiologists, ecological and health economists, microbiologists, wildlife experts, lawyers, pharmacologists, biochemists, hydrologists, metagenomics and modelling experts, social scientists, political leaders, and community leaders) must be called to action under the platform of planetary health. An international framework convention that tackles antimicrobial resistance by adopting a more ecological public health approach and includes firm legislation and political commitment can be a way forward. I declare no competing interests.
