author.institution_display_name: Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation

ab: The Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation (IHME) held a workshop in Seattle (March 1 and 2, 2018) to plan a new Initiative‚Äîthe Global Burden of Disease (GBD)-Pollution and Health Initiative‚Äîto increase knowledge on the contributions of pollution and climate to the GBD study. The workshop attracted 60 attendees from around the world, including experts in environmental health research, economics, and policy; senior scientists based at IHME; and representatives from the US National Institute for Environmental Health Sciences, environmental non-governmental organisations, the UN Environment Programme, and major foundations. The concept of the Initiative originated from the 2017 Lancet Commission on pollution and health.1Landrigan PJ Fuller R Acosta NJR et al.The Lancet Commission on pollution and health.Lancet. 2018; 391: 462-512Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (2009) Google Scholar This report estimated that in 2015 pollution was responsible for 9 million premature deaths and 268 million disability-adjusted life-years, with the most severe impacts in low-income and middle-income countries, and called for the establishment of a Global Pollution Observatory to aggregate, analyse, archive, and disseminate data on pollution and pollution-related disease in cities and countries worldwide. The Initiative also builds on the work of the Lancet Countdown on health and climate change,2Watts N Amann M Ayeb-Karlsson S et al.The Lancet Countdown on health and climate change: from 25 years of inaction to a global transformation for public health.Lancet. 2017; 391: 581-630Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (591) Google Scholar which reports increasing but inadequately measured climate-related deaths. A main driver of the Initiative is the recognition that estimates of pollution-related disease and death‚Äîlarge as they are‚Äîundervalue pollution's full impacts. This underestimation is due to constraints on the scope of the GBD study and the lack of knowledge about the global distribution and health effects of many pollutants. The GBD study limits its analysis to environmental risk factor-disease pairs for which there is definitive evidence of causality. This approach has proven highly reliable and has yielded robust estimates of the burden of disease attributable to air, water, and occupational pollution and to lead. However, there are many other environmental risk factors not yet included in the GBD study for which causal associations with disease have been established through basic science, clinical, and epidemiological studies, and many more are emerging from big-data studies.3Hu H Galea S Rosella L Henry D Big data and population health: focusing on the health impacts of the social, physical, and economic environment.Epidemiology. 2017; 28: 759-762Crossref PubMed Scopus (16) Google Scholar Furthermore, the disease and premature deaths related to climate (ie, climate variability and change) are not yet well reflected in GBD estimates. The key priorities identified during the workshop for the GBD-Pollution and Health Initiative were PM2.5 air pollution, lead, neurodevelopmental neurotoxicants, exposure science, climate change, policy and economics, and management of potential conflicts of interest in relation to judging causal relationships and effects. The Initiative needs to critically examine the contributions to GBD of endpoints such as low birthweight, diabetes, chronic kidney disease, and neurodegenerative diseases that have been reliably linked to PM2.5 pollution but are not yet included in GBD estimates (some are presently under review). The Initiative needs to undertake a critical assessment of research suggesting that lead might increase cardiovascular, renal, and all-cause mortality at exposure levels well below those previously examined. It also needs to develop new methods in exposure science to improve estimates of lead exposure in low-income and middle-income countries, particularly with respect to hotspots. Lead, mercury, organophosphate insecticides, and other developmental toxicants have widespread impacts on children's cognitive function and behaviour even at low levels of exposure. By design, however, the GBD study focuses exclusively on clearcut health impacts and restricts consideration of pollution's impacts on cognitive function to IQ decreases to scores lower than 85, a cutoff that does not capture most of pollution's effects on children's intelligence, creativity, and lifelong earning potential. Cognitive dysfunction caused by lead is, for example, responsible for wide-scale reductions in intelligence that result in estimated productivity losses of US$728¬∑6‚Äì1162¬∑5 billion annually, 80% of which in low-income and middle-income countries.4Attina TM Trasande L Economic costs of childhood lead exposure in low- and middle-income countries.Environ Health Perspect. 2013; 121: 1097-1102Crossref PubMed Scopus (128) Google Scholar Two strategies were discussed for overcoming this issue: to re-examine whether the GBD study can consider effects on health and wellbeing of less severe IQ losses; and to establish an approach that assesses the impacts of neurotoxicants on intelligence and lifelong economic productivity as a part of a new human-capital construct that is being developed as a collaboration between the World Bank and IHME.5Horton R Offline: Jim Kim finds his voice.Lancet. 2017; 390: 1726Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (2) Google Scholar Advances in exposure science and data analytics can greatly increase information on levels and geographical distribution of multiple pollutants, especially in countries that undertake little or no environmental monitoring. Examples include expanding the use of satellite imaging‚Äîcurrently used in the GBD study to estimate levels of particulate matter air pollution‚Äîto generate estimates of nitrogen oxides, ozone, and other air pollutants and to identify mines, smelters, factories, and other hotspots of lead and other ground-level pollutants; integrating arsenic concentrations in groundwater with soil, geology, climate, and elevation data to model global groundwater arsenic contamination;7Amini M Abbaspour KC Berg M et al.Statistical modeling of global geogenic arsenic contamination in groundwater.Environ Sci Technol. 2008; 42: 3669-3675Crossref PubMed Scopus (295) Google Scholar and using low-cost personal samplers such as silicone wrist bands8O'Connell SG Kincl LD Anderson KA Silicone wristbands as personal passive samplers.Environ Sci Technol. 2014; 48: 3327-3335Crossref PubMed Scopus (164) Google Scholar to measure exposures to pesticides, phthalates, and other industrial compounds. The Initiative can also leverage advances in source apportionment to disentangle the relative contributions of motor vehicles, coal-fired power plants, and biomass burning to PM2¬∑5 air pollution-related disease burden.9Hopke PK Review of receptor modeling methods for source apportionment.J Air Waste Manag Assoc. 2016; 66: 237-259Crossref PubMed Scopus (336) Google Scholar Workshop participants supported the plan to incorporate in the GBD study estimates of disease burden related to suboptimal temperature as a first step towards assessing disease due to climate, but noted that much work will be needed to quantify the health impacts of other climate-related effects such as vector-borne disease, coastal flooding, severe weather, and food insecurity. Estimates of the health impacts of climate will also be particularly relevant to an ongoing IHME initiative that aims to generate forecasts of disease burden. Translating the GBD study's findings on pollution-related disease into policy will require to expand the focus to include economic analyses, and to identify the ministries that are responsible for the control of sources of pollution in cities and countries worldwide. In India, for example, it was reported at the workshop that 16 national ministries have responsibilities that concern pollution emitted by power plants, industry, crop burning, vehicles, and indoor cook stoves. As the GBD study develops a new evidence-based system for scoring risks, it will be important to determine mechanisms‚Äîsuch as those adopted by the International Agency for Research on Cancer‚Äîto minimise conflict of interest in the assessment process related to new and potentially contentious risk-outcome pairs that involve chemical pollutants. The definition of these strategies will require the input of the GBD study's Scientific Council and Independent Advisory Committee. The challenges confronting the GBD-Pollution and Health Initiative are formidable. Nonetheless, we believe that this Initiative is timely and that by leveraging the GBD study's enormous global influence,10Murray CJL Lopez AD Measuring global health: motivation and evolution of the Global Burden of Disease Study.Lancet. 2017; 390: 1460-1464Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (103) Google Scholar the Initiative's findings will inform low-income and middle-income countries on how to pursue the Sustainable Development Goals while avoiding the health and environmental tragedies that have plagued past development. We declare no competing interests. We acknowledge the input of the workshop's 55 other participants, especially the Early Career Scientists: Marissa Baker, Rebecca De Buen, Joey Frostad, Samuel Sellers, Rachel Shaffer, and Megan Suter Consideration of local geographical variations in PM2¬∑5 concentrations in ChinaGlobal efforts have been made to reduce air pollution. The Lancet Commission on pollution and health estimates that in 2015, air pollution was responsible for 9 million premature deaths and 268 million disability-adjusted life-years, with the most severe effects on individuals residing in low-income and middle-income countries.1,2 Although various factors have been used to understand air pollution-related mortalities in low-income and middle-income countries,2 geographical variations of air pollution concentrations in low-population dense and rural regions are often overlooked. Full-Text PDF Open Access

title: Environmental racism: time to tackle social injustice
display_name: Environmental racism: time to tackle social injustice
ab: Among the injustices faced by racial and ethnic minority communities, one aspect that is frequently overlooked is the effect of discrimination on the environment that the community is based in. Whether due to targeted prejudice or resulting from ingrained institutional bias, the effects are too often the same: minority residents end up living in more polluted areas with less access to green space than their majority peers.

title: Redesigning public health for planetary health
display_name: Redesigning public health for planetary health

author.au_affiliation_raw: School of Public Administration, University of Victoria, Victoria, BC V8P 5C2, Canada
Centre de recherche‚ÄîH√¥pital Charles-Le Moyne, Universit√© de Sherbrooke, Longueuil, QC J4K 0A8, Canada

ab: The current state of planetary health inevitably leads to recognition of the failure of our current models of development, and it constitutes a call for each of us to profoundly revise our frameworks for action. The public health field, with its mission of protecting and promoting health and equity, is at the forefront of such an agenda. However, we are still ignoring the harmful effects of our current recommendations on planetary health. As practitioners and researchers, we need to invest in a new public health ecological approach.1Rayner G Lang T What is the point of public health in the 21st century?.Public Health. 2015; 129: 1309-1313Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (3) Google Scholar This change requires both incorporating a new value‚Äîsustainability‚Äîinto our discourse and practices and investing in the strategic political dimension of our role. We propose foundational elements that should be integrated in our practice, to address unprecedented threats to biodiversity and human health. Nowadays, we realise the importance of ecological determinants of health, and how human activity has created an imbalance that has negative consequences for biodiversity. Pollution is considered one of the biggest threats to human life.2Landrigan PJ Fuller R Acosta NJR et al.The Lancet Commission on pollution and health.Lancet. 2017; 391: 462-512Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1963) Google Scholar However, our idea of the role of public health has been focused increasingly on individual health, and the impact of the human footprint on the ecology of our planet (which is the primary determinant of human health), has been neglected. For instance, most national food guides still recommend fish intake as a source of protein. Although sensible at an individual level, such a recommendation is irresponsible when we know that, over the past 50 years, populations of commercially important species of fish have been reduced by 90%.3Pauly D Aquacalypse now: the end of fish.New Republic. 2009; 240: 24-27Google Scholar It is essential that we prioritise sustainability in all of our actions and recommendations. Solutions for building more sustainable societies exist in all sectors: food, housing, transportation, etc. The solutions range from being high tech, to implementing degrowth and supporting local initiatives. The challenge is knowing how to implement these solutions. Public policies have remained unchanged, and we are far from making the drastic changes that are necessary to meet the sustainability agenda.4UNEPThe Emissions Gap Report 2017: A UN Environment Synthesis Report.https://wedocs.unep.org/bitstream/handle/20.500.11822/22070/EGR_2017.pdf?sequence=1&isAllowed=yDate: November, 2017Date accessed: November 30, 2017Google Scholar For example, all industrialised countries that signed the Paris Agreement are failing to reach the targets set by the agreement.4UNEPThe Emissions Gap Report 2017: A UN Environment Synthesis Report.https://wedocs.unep.org/bitstream/handle/20.500.11822/22070/EGR_2017.pdf?sequence=1&isAllowed=yDate: November, 2017Date accessed: November 30, 2017Google Scholar The major cause of this undesired stability is political. Even if people and communities are mobilising in a growing number of localities, (with examples such as the Transition Towns movement) the positive impact of those initiatives is largely undone by macro policies, which are of larger scope.5van den Berg RD Cando-Noordhuizen L Action on climate change: what does it mean and where does it lead to?.in: Uitto JI Puri J Evaluating climate change action for sustainable development. Springer, Cham, Switzerland2017: 13-34Crossref Google Scholar Furthermore, several authors have pointed out that such initiatives seem paradoxically to be maintaining the capitalist paradigm that was causing the problem.6Alloun E Alexander S The transition movement: questions of diversity, power and affluence. Simplicity Institute.http://www.vikalpsangam.org/static/media/uploads/Resources/transitionmovement_simplicity_inst.pdfDate: 2014Date accessed: November 30, 2017Google Scholar, 7Laigle L Pour une transition √©cologique √† vis√©e soci√©tale.https://www.cairn.info/revue-mouvements-2013-3-page-135.htmDate: 2013Google Scholar What can public health professionals and researchers do? We suggest reinforcing the strategic political dimension of these roles. Several pathways for political action are open to us; we need to consider the political forces and economic interests that influence government decisions, and adopt more strategic action. Commercial interests are strong, and private sector lobbyists have extensive experience in influencing public policy.8Freudenberg N The manufacture of lifestyle: the role of corporations in unhealthy living.J Public Health Policy. 2012; 33: 244-256Crossref PubMed Scopus (33) Google Scholar Building coalitions of actors to move the transition agenda forward could be one option.9Jenkins-Smith HC Nohrstedt D Weible CM Sabatier PA The advocacy coalition framework: foundations, evolution and ongoing research.in: Sabatier PA Weible CM Theories of the Policy Process. 3rd edn. West View Press, Boulder, CO2014Google Scholar Also, an increased effort to shape public opinion is needed. Working with people in communications and in political sciences could help reinforce our actions. The nature of the message that we would like to bring across also needs to be adapted in several aspects. It is our responsibility to frame our discourse differently and make it more accessible. We need to give meaningful and local representations of the impacts of climate change10Bertrand F Amalric M L'√©laboration des politiques climatiques locales: usage et port√©e d'un dispositif de concertation.D√©veloppement durable et territoires. 2017; 8: 1-24Google Scholar and relate a positive message to day-to-day life. By showing that solutions exist, we can persuade people that change is possible. Public health has evolved in its approaches over the past century.1Rayner G Lang T What is the point of public health in the 21st century?.Public Health. 2015; 129: 1309-1313Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (3) Google Scholar The ecological challenge requires us to profoundly revise our public health policies, to address unprecedented threats to biodiversity and human health. History has shown that such change is possible, but action must be taken, right now. We declare no competing interests.

title: Antimicrobial use and planetary health: developing a framework for priorities
display_name: Antimicrobial use and planetary health: developing a framework for priorities

author.au_affiliation_raw: Global Academy on Agriculture and Food Security, University of Edinburgh, Edinburgh EH25 9RG, UK

ab: Increased strategic thinking is needed about antimicrobial use and antimicrobial resistance (AMR), which has been termed the quintessential One Health challenge1Robinson TP Bu DP Carrique-Mas J et al.Antibiotic resistance is the quintessential One Health issue.Trans R Soc Trop Med Hyg. 2016; 110: 377-380Crossref PubMed Scopus (345) Google Scholar and compared to greenhouse gas emissions (GHG) mitigation or abatement.2Woolhouse M Farrar J Policy: an intergovernmental panel on antimicrobial resistance.Nature. 2014; 509: 555-557Crossref PubMed Scopus (109) Google Scholar The parallels between these wicked problems are indeed striking. AMR is characterised by market and institutional failures in terms of externalised costs by antimicrobial users and the absence of global regulatory or governance architecture. Multiple human and animal sources of antimicrobial pollution exist that are further complicated by complex environmental interactions, pooling, and persistence. Multiple potential entry points could be used to modify clinical and veterinary uses of medicines and detect and diagnose AMR. Many interventions complement or interact in unanticipated ways and the human dimension to antimicrobial use raises unresolved behavioural challenges. Finally, political economy dimensions can create conflicts between public and private sector interests and the interests of developed and developing countries. These conflicts can inhibit innovation and the adoption of even the most technically effective measures. Overall, the science policy discourse can seem incoherent and overwhelming. Recourse to One Health, planetary boundary, or ecosystem service rhetoric can only go so far. An immediate question is what to do first, or how to set priorities for action, on the basis of a consensus of what is and isn't known. This situation is reminiscent of the climate change experience. A decade ago, much unstructured discussion occurred around different GHG abatement measures, but an understanding of the relative cost of avoiding a tonne of carbon dioxide equivalent emission was unclear. Some governments took the initiative to develop a more rational approach to the problem, drawing on environmental economics and related theories of pollution control to develop marginal abatement cost curves (MACCs) to rank cost competitive interventions.3Committee on Climate ChangeBuilding a low-carbon economy‚Äîthe UK's contribution to tackling climate change.https://www.theccc.org.uk/publication/building-a-low-carbon-economy-the-uks-contribution-to-tackling-climate-change-2/Date: Dec 1, 2008Date accessed: May 20, 2018Google Scholar This information provided a basis for estimating carbon budgets sector by sector by comparing marginal abatement costs. This comparison includes agriculture which is a biophysically complex sector for seeking GHG mitigation. Could adopting a similar approach for the identification of cost-effective ways to reduce antimicrobial use, if not AMR outcomes, be beneficial? MACCs form a framework to cumulate data on effectiveness and to measure implementation cost to estimate technical or economic and feasible mitigation potentials, the latter being mitigation achievable with existing or potential policy instruments and behavioural barriers. For given assumptions inherent in their construction, MACCs help frame numerous questions for research and policy, including: what are the known feasible abatement measures, how do they work, and what is their current baseline use; to what extent can measures be applied (alone and in combination) and with what approximate outcome above baseline; what are the costs including any ancillary effects; which measures are relatively cost-effective including win-win measures (ie, implying negative or cost savings); which policies apply to which measures; and which measures need more research, are relatively uncertain, or out of scope because of cost or policy and regulatory feasibility? The climate experience shows the value of an analytical framework to organise disparate information and to improve scientific dialogue, consensus, and policy evidence on what is known. Development of a MACC is typically multidisciplinary, collaborative, and evolutionary, allowing stakeholders to clarify assumptions, add and scrutinise measures, and validate input data. Such frameworks offer a template for focusing discussion across public and private sectors nationally and internationally. AMR research and policy urgently needs a similar framework to focus efforts and to organise information on entry points applicable at different scales (eg, farm, production unit, supply chain, and region or country for antimicrobial use in agriculture). A conspicuous gap in global efforts to combat AMR exists. An international scientific collaboration to advance this agenda makes sense for transparency and impartiality. Climate change mitigation has shown the way. I declare no competing interests.

title: Ambient air pollution-induced health risk for children worldwide
display_name: Ambient air pollution-induced health risk for children worldwide

author.au_affiliation_raw: Institute of Health and Environment and Graduate School of Public Health, Seoul National University, Seoul 08826, South Korea
Institute of Health and Environment and Graduate School of Public Health, Seoul National University, Seoul 08826, South Korea

ab: Air pollution has severe effects on health, including mortality, and researchers have been actively attempting to work out the nature of this relationship. According to The Lancet Commission on pollution and health,1Landrigan PJ Fuller R Acosta NJR et al.The Lancet commission on pollution and health.Lancet. 2018; 391: 462-512Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1962) Google Scholar ambient air pollution-induced excess mortality exceeded 4¬∑5 million worldwide in 2015. By comparison, this mortality toll is more than two-thirds of the 6¬∑4 million deaths caused by tobacco smoking.1Landrigan PJ Fuller R Acosta NJR et al.The Lancet commission on pollution and health.Lancet. 2018; 391: 462-512Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1962) Google Scholar, 2GBD 2015 Risk Factor CollaboratorsGlobal, regional, and national comparative risk assessment of 79 behavioural, environmental and occupational, and metabolic risks or clusters of risks, 1990‚Äì2015: a systematic analysis for the Global Burden of Disease Study 2015.Lancet. 2016; 388: 1659-1724Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (2838) Google Scholar, 3GBD 2015 LRI CollaboratorsEstimates of the global, regional, and national morbidity, mortality, and aetiologies of lower respiratory tract infections in 195 countries: a systematic analysis for the Global Burden of Disease Study 2015.Lancet Infect Dis. 2017; 17: 1133-1161Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (411) Google Scholar In particular, exposure to ambient air pollution is extremely harmful to young children, as it can increase their risk of mortality through lower respiratory tract infections (LRIs).1Landrigan PJ Fuller R Acosta NJR et al.The Lancet commission on pollution and health.Lancet. 2018; 391: 462-512Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1962) Google Scholar, 3GBD 2015 LRI CollaboratorsEstimates of the global, regional, and national morbidity, mortality, and aetiologies of lower respiratory tract infections in 195 countries: a systematic analysis for the Global Burden of Disease Study 2015.Lancet Infect Dis. 2017; 17: 1133-1161Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (411) Google Scholar, 4Zhu L Ge X Chen Y et al.Short-term effects of ambient air pollution and childhood lower respiratory diseases.Sci Reports. 2017; 7: 4414Crossref PubMed Scopus (43) Google Scholar, 5Gascon M Sunyer J Air pollution and respiratory health in childhood.Arch Bronconeumol. 2015; 51: 371-372Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 6Jassal M Pediatric asthma and ambient pollutant levels in industrializing nations.Int Health. 2015; 7: 7-15Crossref PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar According to WHO estimates and the Global Burden of Diseases, Injuries, and Risk Factors Study (GBD), about 1 million children younger than 5 years died from LRIs in 2015, which can be partly attributed to air pollution exposure in combination with poor nutrition and health care.3GBD 2015 LRI CollaboratorsEstimates of the global, regional, and national morbidity, mortality, and aetiologies of lower respiratory tract infections in 195 countries: a systematic analysis for the Global Burden of Disease Study 2015.Lancet Infect Dis. 2017; 17: 1133-1161Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (411) Google Scholar, 7WHO. Estimates for 2000‚Äì2016. http://www.who.int/healthinfo/global_burden_disease/estimates/en/index3.html (accessed June 9, 2018).Google Scholar In The Lancet Planetary Health, Jos Lelieveld and colleagues examined ambient air pollution-induced excess mortality between 2010 and 2015, focusing on children younger than 5 years.8Lelieveld J Haines A Pozzer A Age dependent health risk from ambient air pollution: childhood mortality in middle and low-income countries.Lancet Planet Health. 2018; 2: e292-e300Scopus (71) Google Scholar The researchers used a general circulation model called EMAC to estimate the concentrations of ambient air pollutants such as PM2¬∑5 and ozone. They then estimated the air pollution attributable fraction of mortality based on integrated exposure-response functions. As well as excess mortality, the investigators presented the corresponding years of life lost (YLL) due to premature mortality. Because YLLs more heavily weight deaths at younger ages, they are a suitable metric to express the effect of air pollution on childhood mortality. For a detailed analysis, the excess mortality and YLLs were divided into disease categories and geographic locations. Lelieveld and colleagues found that ambient air pollution-induced under-5 mortality accounted for 5% (246 000 deaths) of the total ambient air pollution-induced mortality (4¬∑55 million deaths), and that YLLs from children younger than 5 years accounted for 18% (22¬∑4 million years) of the total YLLs due to exposure to air pollution (122 million). Given that children younger than 5 years constitute 9% of the total global population, this subpopulation faces roughly twice as much of a potential loss of life than the remaining population. Additionally, the authors analysed this excess mortality by disease categories and found that LRIs were the main cause of death in children. Of the total ambient air pollution-induced under-5 mortality, 237 000 (96%) deaths were due to LRIs. Similarly, of the total YLLs due to air pollution in children younger than 5 years, 96% were due to LRIs. Breaking down the results by geographic location, 99% (235 000 deaths) of under-5 mortality occurred in Africa (128 000 [54%]) and Asia (107 000 [45%]). Of the African portion of this burden, 40% of deaths (n=51 000) were in Nigeria, whereas in Asia, 48% of deaths (n=51 000) were in India. These two countries both have low incomes and large populations. Finally, the authors found that between 2010 and 2015, ambient air pollution induced under-5 mortality from LRIs fell by 22% (from 302 000 to 237 000 deaths per year), whereas the under-5 population only decreased by 4%. This large decrease in under-5 mortality is probably largely driven by improved health care and nutrition for children, especially in India, where under-5 mortality fell by 34% (from about 77 000 to 51 000 deaths per year). Although the researchers calculated 95% CIs for their findings to show statistical uncertainties, there might be other sources of uncertainties that are not captured by the confidence intervals. These other sources would include unaccounted confounding factors and uncertainties in the epidemiological data, such as misclassification of disease. While under-5 mortality due to air pollution-attributable LRIs dropped by 22%, this disease category still accounted for 18% of total air pollution-related YLLs in 2015. As such, further action must be taken. One promising aspect of the present study's findings is that, since under-5 mortality is dominated by LRIs and occurs almost exclusively in Africa and Asia, a targeted effort to improve nutrition and health care for children in low-income countries in Africa and Asia could be a very effective way to reduce under-5 mortality. In this regard, the work done by Lelieveld and colleagues will be a good reference for people involved in relief and aid activities. We declare no competing interests. This Comment was financially supported by the Global Research Lab (K21004000001-10A0500-00710) through the National Research Foundation of Korea, funded by the Ministry of Science,(Information and Communication Technologies, and Future Planning, as well as by the Korean Ministry of Environment under the Climate Change Correspondence Program (project number 2014001310007). Age-dependent health risk from ambient air pollution: a modelling and data analysis of childhood mortality in middle-income and low-income countriesMost child deaths due to AAP-LRIs occur in low-income countries in Africa and Asia. A three-pronged strategy is needed to reduce the health effects of ambient air pollution in children: aggressive reduction of air pollution levels, improvements in nutrition, and enhanced treatment of air pollution-related health outcomes. Full-Text PDF Open Access

title: Environmental nudges to reduce meat demand
display_name: Environmental nudges to reduce meat demand

author.au_affiliation_raw: Tulane University, School of Public Health and Tropical Medicine, New Orleans, LA 70112, USA

ab: Agriculture is a major contributor to environmental damage. Although substantial evidence indicates that a demand for less meat could significantly reduce the effects of diet on the environment,1Aleksandrowicz L Green R Joy EJ Smith P Haines A The impacts of dietary change on greenhouse gas emissions, land use, water use, and health: a systematic review.PLoS One. 2016; 11: e0165797Crossref PubMed Scopus (440) Google Scholar we know much less about how to achieve this goal. Changing dietary behaviour is difficult because individuals might not be motivated to change their habits or have the tools to do so, or there might be social pressures for them to maintain current eating patterns. Moreover, aspects of the physical microenvironments in which we live, such as worksites, schools, grocery stores, cafeterias, and restaurants, can affect our behaviour. For example, restaurant portion sizes can affect how much we eat. We might put more vegetables on our plate if they are placed at the beginning of a cafeteria line. An enticing verbal description of a meat-free menu item can increase the odds of its selection. These and other environmental influences on eating behaviour have been appreciated for some time in the fields of public health and behavioural economics.2Booth SL Sallis JF Ritenbaugh C et al.Environmental and societal factors affect food choice and physical activity: rationale, influences, and leverage points.Nutr Rev. 2001; 59: S21-S39Crossref PubMed Scopus (489) Google Scholar, 3Thaler RH Sunstein CR Nudge: improving decisions about health, wealth, and happiness. Yale University Press, New Haven, CT2008Google Scholar What do we know from the accumulated research about the effects of changing physical microenvironments to reduce meat demand? This question is addressed in a systematic review and qualitative comparative analysis by Filippo Bianchi and colleagues4Bianchi F Garnett E Dorsel C Aveyard P Jebb SA Restructuring physical micro-environments to reduce the demand for meat: a systematic review and qualitative comparative analysis.Lancet Planet Health. 2018; 2: e384-e397Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (72) Google Scholar in The Lancet Planetary Health. Bianchi and colleagues combed the literature‚Äîmore than 10 000 articles‚Äîto find experimental evidence on the effects of environmental changes, categorised into availability, portion size, position, label, sensory properties, and price, on reducing meat demand (defined by the authors as consumption, purchase, or selection of meat in real or virtual environments). 14 articles describing 22 interventions met the inclusion criteria. Interventions most likely to succeed in reducing demand were those that reduced portion sizes, provided meat alternatives with accompanying educational material, or changed the sensory properties of meat and meat alternatives. Restructuring physical microenvironments is not the only way to reduce meat consumption. Consumer change can also be attempted through education or motivation. Unfortunately, studies of purely educational or motivational interventions to reduce meat consumption were not included in this review,4Bianchi F Garnett E Dorsel C Aveyard P Jebb SA Restructuring physical micro-environments to reduce the demand for meat: a systematic review and qualitative comparative analysis.Lancet Planet Health. 2018; 2: e384-e397Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (72) Google Scholar unless they also included components to restructure the environment. Some might find this inclusion criterion to be too restrictive because it precludes the possibility of jointly analysing the relative merits of educational, environmental, and combined educational and environmental interventions. Another concern is the use of the word meat in the review because it represents an overly aggregated category that could include meat from ruminant animals (beef and lamb), as well as pork and poultry. These meats differ substantially in their effects on health, as alluded to by the authors. Environmental differences are even more pronounced. For example, beef has about eight times the carbon footprint of chicken (33 kg vs 4 kg carbon dioxide equivalents per kg).5Heller MC Willits-Smith A Meyer R Keoleian GA Rose D Greenhouse gas emissions and energy use associated with production of individual self-selected US diets.Environ Res Lett. 2018; 13: 044004Crossref PubMed Scopus (96) Google Scholar The use of this terminology is a common problem, and is complicated by the differing nutritional and culinary definitions of meat and even red meat. For interventions to have the greatest effects on health and the environment, it will be helpful going forward to use more specific categorisations. The review appropriately focused on experimental studies, but observational studies can provide tremendous insight into the effects of large-scale policy changes on population-wide phenomena, such as demand change. This approach is particularly needed when analysing economic variables, such as prices. Bianchi and colleagues4Bianchi F Garnett E Dorsel C Aveyard P Jebb SA Restructuring physical micro-environments to reduce the demand for meat: a systematic review and qualitative comparative analysis.Lancet Planet Health. 2018; 2: e384-e397Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (72) Google Scholar found that evidence on the effects of price changes from randomised trials of reducing meat consumption was too limited to be conclusive. Although this finding is accurate in a narrow sense, it is broadly misleading. Thousands of studies from the field of consumer economics tell us that price matters and that when the price of a good goes up with all else equal, consumers will buy less of it. This well developed economic theory is based mostly on observational studies. However, it has been confirmed in studies aiming to improve nutritional outcomes by use of experimental evidence on vending machine snacks,6French SA Jeffery RW Story M et al.Pricing and promotion effects on low-fat vending snack purchases: the CHIPS study.Am J Public Health. 2001; 91: 112-117Crossref PubMed Scopus (384) Google Scholar natural experiments on taxation of sugar-sweetened beverages,7Colchero MA Popkin BM Rivera JA Ng SW Beverage purchases from stores in Mexico under the excise tax on sugar sweetened beverages: observational study.BMJ. 2016; 352: h6704Crossref PubMed Scopus (514) Google Scholar, 8Falbe J Thompson HR Becker CM Rojas N McCulloch CE Madsen KA Impact of the Berkeley excise tax on sugar-sweetened beverage consumption.Am J Public Health. 2016; 106: 1865-1871Crossref PubMed Scopus (284) Google Scholar and experimental evidence from grocery store interventions.9Hartmann-Boyce J Bianchi F Piernas C et al.Grocery store interventions to change food purchasing behaviors: a systematic review of randomized controlled trials.Am J Clin Nutr. 2018; 107: 1004-1016Crossref PubMed Scopus (96) Google Scholar This is not to say that experimental work on increasing meat prices is not warranted. Despite the substantial economics literature on meat demand, controversies still exist about conclusions based on econometric (ie, observational) studies. For example, the long-term decline in beef demand in the USA, which began in the 1970s, could be attributed to either a structural change in consumer preferences for healthier meats (ie, chicken), demographic changes, increased consumption of meals away from home, or simply increased prices as a result of supply changes.10Alston JM Chalfant JA Can we take the con out of meat demand studies?.Western Journal of Agricultural Economics. 1991; 16: 36-48Google Scholar, 11Eales JS Unnevehr LJ Simultaneity and structural change in US meat demand.Am J Agric Econ. 1993; 2: 259-268Crossref Scopus (81) Google Scholar More context-specific studies of meat demand, both experimental and observational, are needed to better understand where macro and micro policies can nudge consumers towards reducing their meat consumption. Given political considerations, some national policies, such as a carbon tax, might be difficult to implement. When national governments fail to act, policies enacted at the local level‚Äîeither by local governments or private institutions‚Äîcan lead the way for environmental change. In this regard, the review by Bianchi and colleagues is important because it provides a foundation for better understanding of how changes to physical microenvironments can help meet goals to reduce the environmental effects of meat in our diets. This work was supported by the Wellcome Trust (grant number 106854/Z/15/Z). Restructuring physical micro-environments to reduce the demand for meat: a systematic review and qualitative comparative analysisSome interventions restructuring physical micro-environments could help to promote lower demand for meat. Interventions reducing portion sizes of meat servings, providing meat alternatives, or changing the sensory properties of meat and meat alternatives at point of purchase offered the most promise in the context of experimental studies. Full-Text PDF Open Access

title: Understanding excess mortality from not-so-natural disasters
display_name: Understanding excess mortality from not-so-natural disasters

author.au_affiliation_raw: University of East Anglia, Norwich Medical School, Norwich, UK

ab: Hurricane Maria made landfall in Puerto Rico on Sept 20, 2017, as a high-end category 4 hurricane, only weeks after the island had been affected by another hurricane. Puerto Rico experienced severe weather associated with the hurricane, including storm surges and flash flooding. The hurricane severely affected basic infrastructure such as electricity and water for several months, initially leading to a complete collapse of the power grid, affecting all 3¬∑4 million inhabitants. Early reporting on the death toll of the hurricane by the government and media was confusing and contradictory, and led to several law suits. Ultimately, Carlos Santos-Burgoa and colleagues were tasked with determining the actual death toll of the hurricane, which they now report in The Lancet Planetary Health.1Santos-Burgoa C Sandberg J Su√°rez E et al.Differential and persistent risk of excess mortality from Hurricane Maria in Puerto Rico: a time-series analysis.Lancet Planet Health. 2018; (published online Oct 11.)http://dx.doi.org/S2542-5196(18)30209-2Scopus (56) Google Scholar Beyond political reasons, some of the initial controversy can certainly be attributed to the methodological difficulties of determining excess mortality in post-disaster situations of high complexity. Mechanisms and dynamics of excess mortality might not be obvious and hence cause difficulty in correctly attributing mortality to the disaster. Additionally, studies on excess mortality need to consider issues such as internal displacement and disaster-related migration, which change population baselines. Santos-Burgoa and colleagues1Santos-Burgoa C Sandberg J Su√°rez E et al.Differential and persistent risk of excess mortality from Hurricane Maria in Puerto Rico: a time-series analysis.Lancet Planet Health. 2018; (published online Oct 11.)http://dx.doi.org/S2542-5196(18)30209-2Scopus (56) Google Scholar accounted for these factors and, using all-cause mortality data from the Puerto Rico Vital Statistics System, estimated 2975 excess deaths (95% CI 2658‚Äì3290) from September, 2017, to February, 2018. The uneven distribution of those deaths along socioeconomic and age strata they noted begs further investigation. It is important to understand not only absolute numbers of excess deaths but also the mechanisms and dynamics underlying the excess mortality and hence the reasons for the uneven distribution. Although it can be argued that the hurricane was responsible for those deaths, it has to be acknowledged that this unequal distribution shows that more than the actual disaster caused by a natural hazard is responsible for excess mortality in such situations and that issues such as development, planning, and other human and societal factors strongly contribute towards turning natural hazard events into disasters. Hence, we need to rethink our use of the term ‚Äúnatural disaster‚Äù. Although hardly a new idea,2O'Keefe W Westgate K Wisner B Taking the naturalness out of natural disasters.Nature. 1976; 260: 566-567Crossref Scopus (511) Google Scholar there has been increasing attention to the problematic assumptions underlying it.3Chmutina K von Meding J Gaillard J Bosher L Why natural disasters aren't all that natural.https://www.opendemocracy.net/ksenia-chmutina-jason-von-meding-jc-gaillard-lee-bosher/why-natural-disasters-arent-all-that-naturalDate: Sept 14, 2017Date accessed: October 2, 2018Google Scholar Although the proposed term of ‚Äúdisaster associated with a natural hazard‚Äù is lengthy, it is certainly more accurate. Another correct term would simply be ‚Äúdisaster‚Äù. Both the immediate and long-term situations in Puerto Rico show that the disastrousness of so-called natural disasters is in fact not so natural. Understanding these not-so-natural underlying human and socioeconomic factors, which contribute not only to excess mortality after hurricanes and other disasters but also to excess morbidity is of vital importance. Hurricanes can affect human health through many mechanisms both in the short term and in the medium-to-long term. Immediate concerns include the risk of drowning and traumatic injury from flooding, high winds, and debris.4Du W FitzGerald G Clark M Hou X Health impacts of floods.Prehosp Disaster Med. 2010; 25: 265-272Crossref PubMed Scopus (122) Google Scholar, 5Ragan P Schulte J Nelson S Jones K Mortality Surveillance: 2004 to 2005 Florida hurricane-related deaths.Am J Forensic Med Pathol. 2008; 29: 148-153Crossref PubMed Scopus (29) Google Scholar, 6Bourque L Siegel J Kano M Wood M Weathering the storm: the impact of hurricanes on physical and mental health.Ann Am Acad Pol Soc Sci. 2006; 604: 129-151Crossref Google Scholar In the medium and long term, health concerns related to hurricanes shift towards communicable diseases, especially those due to remaining flood water and potentially unsafe conditions in shelters.4Du W FitzGerald G Clark M Hou X Health impacts of floods.Prehosp Disaster Med. 2010; 25: 265-272Crossref PubMed Scopus (122) Google Scholar, 6Bourque L Siegel J Kano M Wood M Weathering the storm: the impact of hurricanes on physical and mental health.Ann Am Acad Pol Soc Sci. 2006; 604: 129-151Crossref Google Scholar In the long term, hurricanes also exacerbate other health issues because of their impact on infrastructure and health systems, leading to a potential increase in the severity of non-communicable diseases and lack of appropriate treatment for other conditions, such as traumatic injury.4Du W FitzGerald G Clark M Hou X Health impacts of floods.Prehosp Disaster Med. 2010; 25: 265-272Crossref PubMed Scopus (122) Google Scholar, 6Bourque L Siegel J Kano M Wood M Weathering the storm: the impact of hurricanes on physical and mental health.Ann Am Acad Pol Soc Sci. 2006; 604: 129-151Crossref Google Scholar Finally, both the disaster itself as well as the potential socioeconomic decline associated with it can have substantial mental health impacts.4Du W FitzGerald G Clark M Hou X Health impacts of floods.Prehosp Disaster Med. 2010; 25: 265-272Crossref PubMed Scopus (122) Google Scholar, 6Bourque L Siegel J Kano M Wood M Weathering the storm: the impact of hurricanes on physical and mental health.Ann Am Acad Pol Soc Sci. 2006; 604: 129-151Crossref Google Scholar The severity of the impact of a hurricane is, however, not solely determined by the severity of the hurricane but also by the resilience of the systems in place, including the health system, basic infrastructure, and building codes. Such systems urgently need to be reinforced and augmented with mitigation measures to reduce the impact of hurricanes on coastal and island communities. Climate change affects ocean and air temperatures; rainfall and precipitation; sea levels; and oceanic and atmospheric circulation.7Michener W Blood E Bildstein K Brinson M Gardner L Climate change, hurricanes and tropical storms, and rising sea level in coastal wetlands.Ecol Appl. 1997; 7: 770-801Crossref Scopus (358) Google Scholar These factors can influence both the severity and the frequency of hurricanes and other tropical storms. Intensity of tropical storms is estimated to increase by 2‚Äì11% by 2100 as a result of greenhouse gas emissions, with changes to frequency depending highly on the model being applied.8Knutson T McBride J Chan J et al.Tropical cyclones and climate change.Nat Geosci. 2010; 3: 157-163Crossref Scopus (1850) Google Scholar This potential for increased severity and changed frequency, together with the outlined public health concerns related to hurricanes means that communities with an increased risk of exposure to such hazards need to be better protected. The most vulnerable groups in particular need to be considered in any resilience-building and mitigation efforts because they bear the brunt of excess mortality, as Santos-Burgoa and colleagues1Santos-Burgoa C Sandberg J Su√°rez E et al.Differential and persistent risk of excess mortality from Hurricane Maria in Puerto Rico: a time-series analysis.Lancet Planet Health. 2018; (published online Oct 11.)http://dx.doi.org/S2542-5196(18)30209-2Scopus (56) Google Scholar have shown. I declare no competing interests. Differential and persistent risk of excess mortality from Hurricane Maria in Puerto Rico: a time-series analysisAnalysis of all-cause mortality with vital registration data allows for unbiased estimation of the impact of disasters associated with natural hazards and is useful for public health surveillance. It does not depend on certified cause of death, the basis for the official death toll in Puerto Rico. Although all sectors of Puerto Rican society were affected, recovery varied by municipal socioeconomic development and age groups. This finding calls for equitable disaster preparedness and response to protect vulnerable populations in disasters. Full-Text PDF Open Access

title: Sunscreens, cancer, and protecting our planet
display_name: Sunscreens, cancer, and protecting our planet

author.au_affiliation_raw: John A. Burns School of Medicine, University of Hawaii, Honolulu, HI, USA
author.institution_display_name: University of Hawai ªi at MƒÅnoa

author.au_affiliation_raw: United Nations Development Program, New York, NY, USA
Program for Clinical Research, Department of Dermatology, University of California, San Francisco, CA 94115, USA

ab: Beginning Jan 1, 2021, Hawaii will ban the sale or distribution of any sunscreens containing oxybenzone or octinoxate without a prescription from a licensed health-care provider. The ban is the result of concerns about the detrimental effects of these chemicals on coral and other marine organisms. Coral reefs are among the most important parts of marine ecosystems, providing food and shelter for ocean species, and offering vital services to human societies through their role in coastal protection, building materials, fisheries, and tourism. However, coral reef ecosystems have been threatened by climate change, ocean acidification, and coastal pollution.1Hoegh-Guldberg O Climate change, coral bleaching and the future of the world's coral reefs.Mar Freshw Res. 1999; 50: 839-866Crossref Scopus (2629) Google Scholar, 2Hoegh-Guldberg O Mumby PJ Hooten AJ et al.Coral reefs under rapid climate change and ocean acidification.Science. 2007; 318: 1737-1742Crossref PubMed Scopus (3904) Google Scholar Meanwhile, the incidence of malignant melanoma and non-melanoma skin cancers continue to rise,3Rogers H W Weinstock MA Feldman SR Coldiron BM Incidence estimate of nonmelanoma skin cancer (keratinocyte carcinomas) in the US population, 2012.JAMA Dermatol. 2015; 151: 1081-1086Crossref PubMed Scopus (1059) Google Scholar and public health efforts have focused on increasing sun protection practices. It is time to think about skin cancer and its prevention in the context of planetary health,4Whitmee S Haines A Beyrer C et al.Safeguarding human health in the Anthropocene epoch: report of The Rockefeller Foundation‚ÄìLancet Commission on planetary health.Lancet. 2015; 386: 1973-2028Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1152) Google Scholar to balance the benefits to human health with the preservation of our environment and the ecosystems that underpin it. Excessive ultraviolet radiation exposure is a preventable cause of all types of skin cancer,5American Cancer SocietyCancer Facts & Figures 2018. American Cancer Society, Atlanta2018Google Scholar with numerous studies confirming that exposure in childhood and adolescence increases the risk of skin cancer later in life, especially when resulting in severe sunburn.6Grossman D C Curry S J Owens D K et al.Behavioral counseling to prevent skin cancer: US Preventive Services Task Force recommendation statement.JAMA. 2018; 319: 1134-1142Crossref Scopus (6) Google Scholar, 7S√°nchez G Nova J Rodriguez-Hernandez A E et al.Sun protection for preventing basal cell and squamous cell skin cancers.Cochrane Database Syst Rev. 2016; 7 (CD011161.)Google Scholar Although long-term randomised trials of sunscreen on skin cancer prevention are still needed, it is widely established that broad-spectrum chemical and physical sunscreens reduce sunburn, one of the main risk factors for skin cancer. Several methods for effectively protecting skin from excessive ultraviolet radiation exposure and sunburn exist, including the use of protective clothing and hats, avoiding midday sun, and seeking shade. Broad-spectrum sunscreen of sun protection factor 30 or greater is an important supplement to these behaviours, especially for areas of the body that are not covered by clothing. Some dermatologists and public health professionals might therefore question whether Hawaii's decision to ban certain chemical sunscreens was the right one. We believe that based on the precautionary principle that encourages policies that protect human health and the environment in the face of uncertain risks and the fact that there are many safe alternatives that people can use until this uncertainty is resolved, this is not the wrong decision. We reviewed the scientific data on the effects of sunscreens on the environment. Overall, we identified very few studies on the topic, suggesting it might be too soon to draw firm conclusions. However, in laboratory conditions, oxybenzone was toxic to corals and led to coral bleaching,8Danovaro R Bongiorni L Corinaldesi C et al.Sunscreens cause coral bleaching by promoting viral infections.Environ Health Perspect. 2008; 116: 337-340Crossref Scopus (357) Google Scholar, 9Downs CA Kramarsky-Winter E Segal R et al.Toxicopathological effects of the sunscreen UV filter, oxybenzone (benzophenone-3), on coral planulae and cultured primary cells and its environmental contamination in Hawaii and the U.S. Virgin Islands.Arch Environ Contam Toxicol. 2016; 70: 265-288Crossref PubMed Scopus (311) Google Scholar a process by which corals that are stressed by changes in environmental conditions expel the symbiotic algae living in their tissues, causing them to turn white. Up to an estimated 14 000 tonnes of sunscreens, of which many contain as much as 10% oxybenzone, are washed off in tourist reef areas annually.9Downs CA Kramarsky-Winter E Segal R et al.Toxicopathological effects of the sunscreen UV filter, oxybenzone (benzophenone-3), on coral planulae and cultured primary cells and its environmental contamination in Hawaii and the U.S. Virgin Islands.Arch Environ Contam Toxicol. 2016; 70: 265-288Crossref PubMed Scopus (311) Google Scholar Ultraviolet filters might also enter the ocean through wastewater treatment plant effluent. In Brazil, oxybenzone and octinoxate were identified in both raw and treated water.10Pereira da Silva C Emdio ES Rodrigues de Marchi MR The occurrence of UV filters in natural and drinking water in S√£o Paulo State (Brazil).Environ Sci Pollut Res. 2015; 22: 19706-19715Crossref Scopus (40) Google Scholar The effects of oxybenzone on other marine life have also been studied. In Japanese medaka and rainbow trout, exposure to high concentrations of oxybenzone led to decreased egg production, with significant reductions in egg hatchings and possible feminisation of male fish.11Coronado M De Haro H Deng X Rempel MA Lavado R Schlenk D Estrogenic activity and reproductive effects of the UV-filter oxybenzone (2-hydroxy-4- methoxyphenyl-methanone) in fish.Aquat Toxicol. 2008; 90: 182-187Crossref PubMed Google Scholar These documented effects on coral and marine life call the aforementioned precautionary principle into play.12Kriebel D Tickner J Epstein P et al.The precautionary principle in environmental science.Environ Health Perspect. 2001; 109: 871-876Crossref PubMed Scopus (453) Google Scholar Planetary health is an emerging field focused on the dual goal of protecting the health of humans while also protecting the health of our planet for today's and future generations. This approach was developed because of the threatened state of the environment and a realisation that human behaviours have led to a transgression of several planetary boundaries, putting the health of both humans and the planet at risk. Dermatologists should be familiar with this problem, given that stratospheric ozone depletion, as evident in the hole in the ozone layer, has put many humans at increased risk of malignant melanoma and other cancers. We clearly need further studies to better evaluate the potential environmental effects of sunscreen. In the meantime, both dermatologists and sunscreen sceptics agree on the benefits of other sun-protective behaviours, including avoiding indoor tanning, seeking shade, and wearing sun-protective clothing and sunscreens with physical filters including zinc oxide and titanium dioxide.13Schneider SL Lim HW Review of environmental effects of oxybenzone and other sunscreen active ingredients.J Am Acad Dermatol. 2018; (published online June 28.)DOI:10.1016/j.jaad.2018.06.033Google Scholar It is time for dermatologists to continue advocating for skin cancer prevention, while also being cognisant of the understudied but potential risks to our planet. And for Hawaiians, He po'i na kai uli, kai ko'o, 'a'ohe hina p≈´ko'a. Though the sea be deep and rough, the coral rock remains standing. Hopefully, for generations to come. EL is supported by the National Cancer Institute (grants DP2CA225433 and R21CA212201) and the National Institute of Aging (grant K76AGO54631). All other authors declare no competing interests.

title: The impact of global environmental change on vector-borne disease risk: a modelling study
display_name: The impact of global environmental change on vector-borne disease risk: a modelling study

author.au_affiliation_raw: Barcelona Institute for Global Health, Barcelona, Spain

ab: BackgroundVector-borne diseases, such as dengue virus, Zika virus, and malaria, are highly sensitive to environmental changes, including variations in climate and land-surface characteristics. The emergence and spread of vector-borne diseases is also exacerbated by anthropogenic activities, such as deforestation, mining, urbanisation, and human mobility, which alter the natural habitats of vectors and increase vector‚Äìhost interactions. Innovative epidemiological modelling tools can help to understand how environmental conditions interact with socioeconomic risk factors to predict the risk of disease transmission. In recent years, climate-health modelling has benefited from computational advances in fitting complex mathematical models; increasing availability of environmental, socioeconomic, and disease surveillance datasets; and improved ability to understand and model the climate system. Climate forecasts at seasonal time scales tend to improve in quality during El Ni√±o-Southern Oscillation events in certain regions of the tropics. Thus, climate forecasts provide an opportunity to anticipate potential outbreaks of vector-borne diseases from several months to a year in advance. The aim of this study was to develop a framework to incorporate seasonal climate forecasts in predictive disease models to understand the future risk of vector-borne diseases, with a focus on dengue fever in Latin America.MethodsA Bayesian spatiotemporal model framework that quantifies the extent to which environmental and socioeconomic indicators can explain variations in disease risk was designed to disentangle the effects of climate from other risk factors using multi-source data and random effects, which account for unknown and unmeasured sources of spatial, seasonal, and inter-annual variation. The model was used to provide probabilistic predictions of monthly dengue incidence and the probability of exceeding outbreak thresholds, which were established in consultation with public health stakeholders.FindingsThis disease model framework, combined with seasonal climate forecasts, successfully produced real-time, probabilistic estimates of dengue outbreak risk ahead of a mass gathering in Brazil in June, 2014, for all 550 microregions. Additionally, the model predicted dengue outbreak risk after a major El Ni√±o event in southern coastal Ecuador from January to November, 2016. Forecasts from the new model framework did better than those from benchmark models based on historical seasonal dengue averages.InterpretationThis flexible model framework can be adapted to predict any climate-sensitive disease at various spatiotemporal scales and in diverse ecological settings. Incorporating sub-seasonal and seasonal climate forecasts in disease prediction models could support public health decision makers in implementing timely disease-control and prevention strategies months in advance to mitigate the risk of imminent disease epidemics and emerging disease threats.FundingRoyal Society Dorothy Hodgkin Fellowship.

title: Scientific opportunities for food and nutrition security
display_name: Scientific opportunities for food and nutrition security

author.au_affiliation_raw: European Academies Science Advisory Council, German National Academy of Sciences Leopoldina, 06019 Halle, Germany
author.institution_display_name: German National Academy of Sciences Leopoldina

author.au_affiliation_raw: InterAcademy Partnership, Trieste, Italy
Centre for Development Research, Bonn, Germany

ab: Malnutrition in its various forms‚Äîundernutrition and micronutrient deficiencies, as well as overweight and obesity‚Äîis a problem faced by all countries. Despite substantial advances in the improvement of nutrition in recent decades, large-scale problems persist.1Development InitiativesGlobal nutrition report 2017: nourishing the SDGs.https://www.globalnutritionreport.org/files/2017/11/report_2017.pdfDate: 2017Google Scholar The global challenges in attainment of food and nutrition security are compounded by pressures of growing and urbanising populations, climate and other environmental changes, and economic inequity and instability. There have been many reports about these issues‚Äîreflecting the complexity of the causes, the consequences for the public burden of disease, and the increasing concerns about sustainability‚Äîbut also the potential of science and technology to bring change. In this Comment, we concentrate on these transformative opportunities. Science has already contributed greatly in tackling the problems of food and nutrition security but more is needed. The broad research agenda is becoming clearer2Haddad L Hawkes C Webb P et al.A new global research agenda for food.Nature. 2016; 540: 30-32Crossref PubMed Scopus (119) Google Scholar but, in addition to the specific priorities, it is important to recognise the value of basic research as the underpinning resource for all other inquiry. The Sustainable Development Goals provide an important policy framework for understanding and meeting the challenges of malnutrition, and they mandate fresh engagement by science to resolve the complexities of evidence-based policies and programmes. Academies of science worldwide have a sustained history of interest in these areas. Recent reorganisation of the InterAcademy Partnership (IAP), the global network of science academies, brings new impetus to engage widely to strengthen the evidence base and ensure that the voice of science is heard in addressing controversies and societal priorities. An ambitious, pioneering project for IAP on food and nutrition security and agriculture uses a novel method that involves the four regional academy networks from Africa (the network of African Science Academies), the Americas (the Inter-American Network of Academies), Asia (the Association of Academies and Societies of Sciences in Asia), and Europe (the European Academies Science Advisory Council). Four parallel expert working groups proceeded from a common starting point‚Äîguided by a collectively agreed template of interconnected themes (panel)‚Äîto diverse analysis according to regional experience, evidence, and policy priorities.PanelInterAcademy Partnership's template of themes for food and nutrition security and agriculture‚Ä¢Key elements in describing national and regional characteristics for food and nutrition security and agriculture‚Ä¢Major current challenges and opportunities, and future projections for the region‚Ä¢Strengths and weaknesses of science and technology at national and regional levels‚Ä¢Prospects for innovation to improve agriculture‚Ä¢Prospects for increasing efficiency of food systems‚Ä¢Public health and nutrition issues, particularly with regard to effect of dietary change on food demand and health‚Ä¢Competition for arable land use‚Ä¢Other major environmental issues associated with agriculture at the landscape scale‚Ä¢Effect of national and regional regulatory frameworks and other sectoral or intersectoral policies‚Ä¢Implications for inter-regional and global levels ‚Ä¢Key elements in describing national and regional characteristics for food and nutrition security and agriculture‚Ä¢Major current challenges and opportunities, and future projections for the region‚Ä¢Strengths and weaknesses of science and technology at national and regional levels‚Ä¢Prospects for innovation to improve agriculture‚Ä¢Prospects for increasing efficiency of food systems‚Ä¢Public health and nutrition issues, particularly with regard to effect of dietary change on food demand and health‚Ä¢Competition for arable land use‚Ä¢Other major environmental issues associated with agriculture at the landscape scale‚Ä¢Effect of national and regional regulatory frameworks and other sectoral or intersectoral policies‚Ä¢Implications for inter-regional and global levels These four groups are now publishing their reports, to identify both the knowledge gaps and how use of current knowledge can be improved, with two objectives. Firstly, engage groups of regional and national policy makers and stakeholders. Secondly, contribute resource to a coordinated fifth report, advising on inter-regional matters, local‚Äìglobal connections, and issues at the science‚Äìpolicy interface that should be resolved by intergovernmental institutions and other bodies with international roles and responsibilities. Food systems are in transition. Our work emphasises the imperative to tackle both supply-side and demand-side issues: reduction of food waste as well as change to healthier and sustainable consumption patterns. There are inter-related issues for resource efficiency, environmental and economic sustainability, resilience, and the public health agenda. We aim to clarify where there might be current disconnects between objectives in different policy areas, where trade-offs are needed, and where synergies are possible, perhaps particularly in accruing co-benefits for health and the environment from actions on climate.3Haines A Health co-benefits of climate action.Lancet Planet Health. 2017; 1: e4-e5Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (36) Google Scholar, 4Watts N Amann M Ayeb-Karlsson S et al.The Lancet countdown on health and climate change: from 25 years of inaction to a global transformation for public health.Lancet. 2017; (published online Oct 30.)http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/S0140-6736(17)32464-9Summary Full Text Full Text PDF Scopus (584) Google Scholar We hope that our reports will also provide distinctive insight on the social and natural sciences' frontiers in nutrition and diet as well as the importance of considering variation in dietary requirements over the lifespan, on new approaches to innovation at the farm scale, in managing competition for natural resources while also capitalising on opportunities for the bioeconomy, and in delivering more efficient and equitable food systems than is currently available. We highlight the importance of generating, standardising, sharing, and using large datasets, alongside multidisciplinary research as a core part of the evidence base. There is urgent need to build global research capacity and to mobilise that research for innovation and to inform policy and practice. We have not been disappointed in the IAP's expectations of diversity in analysis and recommendations from the four regions, and we regard this heterogeneity as a strength of the novel project design, providing the foundations for the current global integration phase of the IAP project. The regional reports will shortly be available from IAP and the regional academy networks. We now invite feedback on these outputs and on what priorities should be emphasised in the global synthesis work. We declare no competing interests.

title: The health and economic benefits of climate mitigation and pollution control
display_name: The health and economic benefits of climate mitigation and pollution control

author.au_affiliation_raw: Arnhold Institute for Global Health, Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai, New York, NY 10029, USA
author.institution_display_name: Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai

ab: The heat waves, floods, rising sea levels, violent storms, and expanded ranges of vector-borne diseases associated with global climate change and the diseases and premature deaths caused by pollution are responsible for enormous economic losses. Yet despite the great magnitude of these costs, they are frequently overlooked and generally undercounted. The problem is that the links between floods, storms, rising rates of disease, and disruption of the earth's support systems1 are not widely recognised, and the costs of these events are spread across large populations, extend over many years, and are not neatly collected in one place.

title: Natural environments and suicide
display_name: Natural environments and suicide

author.au_affiliation_raw: Institute of Health Behaviors and Community Sciences, College of Public Health, National Taiwan University, Taipei 100, Taiwan
Bristol Medical School, Population Health Sciences, University of Bristol, Bristol, UK

ab: Suicide is a global public health priority. An estimated 800 000 people die by suicide a year, exceeding deaths by war and homicide combined.1WHOPreventing suicide: a global imperative. World Health Organization, Geneva2014Google Scholar The United Nations Sustainable Development Goals include a target (target 3.4) to "reduce by one third premature mortality from non-communicable diseases through prevention and treatment and promote mental health and well-being"; suicide is one of the two indicators for that target.2WHOMental health: Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).http://www.who.int/mental_health/suicide-prevention/SDGs/en/Google Scholar With the degradation of the planet due to human activities, rapid urbanisation, and the influence these factors have on the environments in which people live, there is growing evidence of the impact of natural environments on health, including mental health.3Gascon M Triguero-Mas M Martinez D et al.Mental health benefits of long-term exposure to residential green and blue spaces: a systematic review.Int J Environ Res Public Health. 2015; 12: 4354-4379Crossref PubMed Scopus (596) Google Scholar The association of natural environments with population suicide risk is therefore worth exploring. Possible mechanisms underlying any association might include a beneficial effect of natural environments on stress,4Markevych I Schoierer J Hartig T et al.Exploring pathways linking greenspace to health: theoretical and methodological guidance.Environ Res. 2017; 158: 301-317Crossref PubMed Scopus (947) Google Scholar depression5Tomita A Vandormael AM Cuadros D et al.Green environment and incident depression in South Africa: a geospatial analysis and mental health implications in a resource-limited setting.Lancet Planet Health. 2017; 1: e152-e162Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (51) Google Scholar and other mental disorders, and social cohesion,4Markevych I Schoierer J Hartig T et al.Exploring pathways linking greenspace to health: theoretical and methodological guidance.Environ Res. 2017; 158: 301-317Crossref PubMed Scopus (947) Google Scholar which are all risk or protective factors of suicide.6Turecki G Brent DA Suicide and suicidal behaviour.Lancet. 2016; 387: 1227-1239Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (980) Google Scholar In The Lancet Planetary Health, Marco Helbich and colleagues7Helbich M Beurs Dd Kwan M-P O'Connor R Groenewegen P Natural environments and suicide mortality in the Netherlands: a cross-sectional, ecological study.Lancet Planet Health. 2018; 2: e134-e139Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (55) Google Scholar examined the association of outdoor natural environments‚Äîas indexed by green space (ie, grass, forests, or parks) and blue space (ie, visible bodies of fresh or salt water) and proximity to the coast‚Äîwith suicide rates across nearly 400 municipalities in the Netherlands. They reported statistical evidence for lower suicide incidence in municipalities with large or moderate proportions of green space compared with those with less green space. By contrast, no evidence was found for an association of suicide with blue spaces or living near the coast. The study is original in its systematic investigation of three types of natural environments in relation to suicide mortality and its use of advanced spatial analysis methodology. Although the findings resonate with contemporary concerns about the destruction of the natural environment, they need to be interpreted in the context of several caveats. First, this is an ecological, cross-sectional study and the possibility of confounding is substantial. Past research into geographical variations in suicide rates has shown strong associations with area socioeconomic characteristics,8Rehkopf DH Buka SL The association between suicide and the socio-economic characteristics of geographical areas: a systematic review.Psychol Med. 2006; 36: 145-157Crossref PubMed Scopus (306) Google Scholar which in turn are likely to be related to an area's natural environments (eg, poorer areas might be more densely built with fewer green spaces). Helbich and colleagues' findings were notably weakened in the model controlling for potential confounding factors such as unemployment. For example, the unadjusted model showed a 24% reduction in suicide incidence in municipalities with a high level of green space (rate ratio [RR] 0¬∑760, 95% credibility interval 0¬∑681‚Äì0¬∑849) whereas the risk reduction halved (12%; 0¬∑879, 0¬∑779‚Äì0¬∑991) after adjusting for confounders. Residual confounding (ie, confounding that remains uncontrolled for) is likely because the unemployment variable was based on a one-off measure using data for 2005 whereas the suicide data spanned over the period 2005‚Äì14, a time when unemployment rates fluctuated considerably. Furthermore, the study used house prices as an indicator of local economic circumstances, but prices can be affected by the local housing market and the type of housing available, which might vary considerably across areas‚Äîeg, between urban and rural areas‚Äîand thus might not reflect local economic circumstances as well as other indicators. Other spatial analyses of suicide have used income or deprivation indices, which might better capture socioeconomic deprivation than do house prices, and have generally found strong associations of these deprivation indicators with local suicide incidence.9Hsu CY Chang SS Lee ES Yip PS Geography of suicide in Hong Kong: Spatial patterning, and socioeconomic correlates and inequalities.Soc Sci Med. 2015; 130: 190-203Crossref PubMed Scopus (46) Google Scholar Second, the measures of local levels of green and blue space were based on the amount of land in certain land-use categories (eg, agricultural and natural areas and man-made greenery such as parks for green spaces) in each municipality. Measures based on other indicators such as travelling distance to the exposures of interest might yield different findings,10Guo Y Chang S-S Chen M Yip PSF Do poorer areas have poorer access to services in Hong Kong? A small-area analysis based on multiple spatial accessibility indicators.Soc Ind Res. 2018; (in press).Google Scholar and sensitivity analyses using different availability and accessibility measures of natural environments would aid examination of the robustness of findings. Furthermore, the median municipality population was approximately 25 000, and within area units this populous, there is likely to be very mixed accessibility and proximity to green space. Third, previous studies have indicated access to suicide methods as an important factor contributing to the spatial patterning of suicide.11Chang SS Sterne JA Wheeler BW Lu TH Lin JJ Gunnell D Geography of suicide in Taiwan: spatial patterning and socioeconomic correlates.Health Place. 2011; 17: 641-650Crossref PubMed Scopus (85) Google Scholar For example, suicide by drowning would be more common in coastal areas or regions with major harbours or lakes, which might complicate the association of blue spaces with suicide. In fact, a study12Middleton N Sterne JA Gunnell DJ An atlas of suicide mortality: England and Wales, 1988‚Äì1994.Health Place. 2008; 14: 492-506Crossref PubMed Scopus (47) Google Scholar from England and Wales has shown increased suicide incidence in coastal areas. Agricultural areas, where the percentage of farmers and hunters is higher, could see more suicides by firearms.13Skegg K Firth H Gray A Cox B Suicide by occupation: does access to means increase the risk?.Aust N Z J Psychiatry. 2010; 44: 429-434Crossref PubMed Scopus (71) Google Scholar Sensitivity analyses based on suicide by methods whose accessibility does not vary geographically (eg, hanging) could be considered to test the robustness of the suicide‚Äìnature association. The authors rightly point out the need for future research to verify the association they found. Useful approaches might include natural experiments (eg, after park construction or loss of green space) or investigations of people who move from one area to another14Wood L Hooper P Foster S Bull F Public green spaces and positive mental health - investigating the relationship between access, quantity and types of parks and mental wellbeing.Health Place. 2017; 48: 63-71Crossref PubMed Scopus (262) Google Scholar to study the effect of natural environments on factors underlying suicide risk such as depression. New evidence in this area could not only contribute to a better understanding of suicide but also have the potential to inform land use and urban planning. For unemployment rates in the Netherlands see https://tradingeconomics.com/netherlands/unemployment-rate For unemployment rates in the Netherlands see https://tradingeconomics.com/netherlands/unemployment-rate We declare no competing interests. Natural environments and suicide mortality in the Netherlands: a cross-sectional, ecological studyOur findings support the notion that exposure to natural environments, particularly to greenery, might have a role in reducing suicide mortality.
