title: Resurgence of infectious diseases due to forced migration: is planetary health and One Health action synergistic?
display_name: Resurgence of infectious diseases due to forced migration: is planetary health and One Health action synergistic?

author.au_affiliation_raw: Universitas Gadjah Mada, Yogyakarta, Indonesia
School of Public Health, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720, USA

ab: Forced migration is an ancient phenomenon and will continue as long as politics exists. Although it mainly evolves from persecution, development, or exploitation, its public health consequences and effects go far beyond assumption. The ongoing epidemic of a rare and controlled disease like diphtheria in Rohingya camps, in Bangladesh (figure), is a unique example of a public health disaster due to forced migration. Planetary health and One Health have approached the issue by working together as an interdisciplinary collaboration; which might be the best strategy in such conditions. Infectious diseases know no boundaries and therefore diseases like diphtheria are a global biosecurity issue. Out of 8031 clinically suspected diphtheria cases from Nov 3, 2017, to July 24, 2018, 169 cases occurred in the host community.1WHOBangladesh: Rohingya emergency response EWARS epidemiological bulletin W29 2018.https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/weeklyepidemiologicalbulletinw292018_0.pdfDate: July 24, 2018Date accessed: September 4, 2018Google Scholar Therefore, the epidemic is not only a health concern for migrant populations, but also a regional public health crisis, with 44 reported deaths from a vaccine-preventable disease in a short span of time. Forced human migration, along with movement of livestock, is a well-recognised condition for emergence of infectious diseases.2Crudo Blackburn C Lenze Jr, PE Forced migration and the spread of infectious disease: impact of Syrian refugee movements on disease prevalence in the European Union. Scowcroft Institute of International Affairs, Nov 17, 2017http://bush.tamu.edu/scowcroft/papers/blackburn-lenze/Paper%20No.%2010%20Blackburn%20&%20Lenze.pdfDate accessed: September 4, 2018Google Scholar, 3Soto S Human migration and infectious diseases.Clin Microbiol Infect. 2009; 15: 26-28Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (41) Google Scholar However, the livestock movement with Rohingya refugees received little attention from the authorities. Unfortunately, several thousands of cows, buffaloes, sheep, and goats have reached the households of local Bangladeshi people without any biosecurity checking.4DhakaTribuneLivestock trade booms in Teknaf as the Rohingya sell them for whatever they can get.https://www.dhakatribune.com/bangladesh/nation/2017/09/26/livestock-trade-booms-teknaf-rohingyas-sell-whatever-can-getDate: Sept 26, 2017Date accessed: September 4, 2018Google Scholar The livestock department has not been deployed effectively in this context, and surveillance activity of livestock that belong to the migrant population is not evident. The present flow of displaced Rohingya started in August, 2017, and about 700 000 Rohingya, mostly women and children, have migrated.5Qadri F Azad AK Flora MS et al.Emergency deployment of oral cholera vaccine for the Rohingya in Bangladesh.Lancet. 2018; 391: 1877-1879Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (21) Google Scholar The Government of Bangladesh with WHO started prompt emergency vaccination6WHOWHO plans, supports delivery of life-saving vaccinations to 150 000 children in Cox's Bazar, Bangladesh.http://www.searo.who.int/mediacentre/sear-in-the-field/vaccinations-in-cox-bazar/en/Date: 2017Date accessed: September 2, 2018Google Scholar against measles, rubella, and polio from Sept 16, 2017. Vaccination against diphtheria (which needs three phases of vaccination) started on Dec 12, 2017, whereas the epidemic started on Nov 3, 2017.7UNICEFBangladesh moves to protect Rohingya children from diphtheria.https://reliefweb.int/report/bangladesh/bangladesh-moves-protect-rohingya-children-diphtheriaDate: Dec 12, 2017Date accessed: September 2, 2018Google Scholar Diphtheria might not have been prioritised in the first instance because of the scarcity of evidence synthesis or adequate risk mapping, although the pentavalent vaccine is protective for five distinct diseases. The incidence of diphtheria, and mortality caused by it, has been high in Nepal and Myanmar8Dias AA Santos LS Sabbadini PS et al.Corynebacterium ulcerans diphtheria: an emerging zoonosis in Brazil and worldwide.Rev Saude Publica. 2011; 45: 1176-1191Crossref PubMed Scopus (40) Google Scholar for many years. A 4-year cohort study9Salter SJ Turner C Watthanaworawit W et al.A longitudinal study of the infant nasopharyngeal microbiota: the effects of age, illness and antibiotic use in a cohort of south east Asian children.PLoS Negl Trop Dis. 2017; 11: e0005975Crossref PubMed Scopus (32) Google Scholar was done in the Mae La refugee camp on the Thailand-Myanmar border; children from birth to 24 months of age were included and five dominating nasopharyngeal microbiota‚ÄîMoraxella, Streptococcus, Haemophilus, Corynebacterium, and an uncharacterised Flavobacteriaceae similar to Ornithobacterium‚Äîwere found. Therefore, pneumonia and diphtheria are the most anticipated childhood illnesses in the population. Diphtheria is a highly infectious toxin-mediated disease caused by Corynebacterium species; usually, pharyngeal diphtheria is caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae and cutaneous diphtheria is caused by Corynebacterium ulcerans.10Schuhegger R Lindermayer M Kugler R Heesemann J Busch U Sing A Detection of toxigenic Corynebacterium diphtheriae and Corynebacterium ulcerans strains by a novel real-time PCR.J Clin Microbiol. 2008; 46: 2822-2823Crossref PubMed Scopus (51) Google Scholar However, C ulcerans is the most common cause of pharyngeal diphtheria in the UK population,11Wagner K White J Crowcroft N De Martin S Mann G Efstratiou A Diphtheria in the United Kingdom, 1986‚Äì2008: the increasing role of Corynebacterium ulcerans.Epidemiol Infect. 2010; 138: 1519-1530Crossref PubMed Scopus (102) Google Scholar mainly due to contact with domestic animals, and its incidence is increasing worldwide. Therefore, diphtheria has a zoonotic connection with the potential of an initial zoonotic and subsequent human-to-human transmission.12Konrad R H√∂rmansdorfer S Sing A Possible human-to-human transmission of toxigenic Corynebacterium ulcerans.Clin Microbiol Infect. 2015; 21: 768-771Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (15) Google Scholar, 13Meinel DM Konrad R Berger A et al.Zoonotic transmission of toxigenic Corynebacterium ulcerans strain, Germany, 2012.Emerg Infect Dis. 2015; 21: 356-358Crossref PubMed Scopus (21) Google Scholar In the Rohingya population, respiratory diphtheria could be transmitted to humans from dairy cattle. Moreover, its transmission is influenced by socioeconomic factors, such as overcrowding, poverty, and a lack of personal hygiene.14Quick ML Sutter RW Kobaidze K et al.Risk factors for diphtheria: a prospective case-control study in the Republic of Georgia, 1995‚Äì1996.J Infect Dis. 2000; 181: S121-S129Crossref PubMed Scopus (21) Google Scholar When only 32¬∑7% reported cases are PCR positive15WHOWeekly situation report #11, Rohingya refugees 2018.https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/weeklysitrep11cxbban.pdfDate: Jan 29, 2018Date accessed: September 4, 2018Google Scholar and real-time PCR failing to detect C ulcerans,10Schuhegger R Lindermayer M Kugler R Heesemann J Busch U Sing A Detection of toxigenic Corynebacterium diphtheriae and Corynebacterium ulcerans strains by a novel real-time PCR.J Clin Microbiol. 2008; 46: 2822-2823Crossref PubMed Scopus (51) Google Scholar the link should have a logical ground as the Rohingya population depends on agriculture and are more exposed to cattle and other animals, with no awareness of zoonotic disease transmission.16Arakan Rohingya National OrganisationFacts about the Rohingya muslims of Arakan 2006.http://www.rohingya.org/portal/index.php/learn-about-rohingya.htmlDate: Oct 5, 2006Date accessed: September 4, 2018Google Scholar From a planetary health perspective, there is evidence of seasonal occurrence of diphtheria (mostly in late summer), and waning of immunity affected by environmental factors.17Metcalf CJ Bj√∏rnstad ON Grenfell BT Andreasen V Seasonality and comparative dynamics of six childhood infections in pre-vaccination Copenhagen.Proc Biol Sci. 2009; 276: 4111-4118Crossref PubMed Scopus (81) Google Scholar Amuakwa-Mensah and colleagues18Amuakwa-Mensah F Marbuah G Mubanga M Climate variability and infectious diseases nexus: evidence from Sweden.Infect Dis Model. 2017; 2: 203-217PubMed Google Scholar have described the climate-health nexus model of various infectious diseases including diphtheria; they have shown multiple relationships with climate variability‚Äîeg, linear negative effect of temperature and positive effect of overcrowding and immigration on the incidence of infection. Therefore, we recommend that along with public health experts, veterinarians, economists, environmental and social scientists, community leaders, and policy makers should all have a substantial role in preparing a contingency plan for this type of calamity ahead of a possible outbreak, or disaster. There is an urgent need for a migratory and vulnerable population health information repository, that includes public and animal health and environmental statistics based on available literature and expert opinions. The One Health and planetary health approach should be adopted for addressing migrant health issues, with a distinct action plan. MA is supported by National Institutes of Health Fogarty International Center Global Health Equity Scholars program (D43TW010540) and MTF is supported by WHO TDR Fellowship program. We declare no competing interests.

title: Cognition, heuristics, and biases behind environment-related behaviours
display_name: Cognition, heuristics, and biases behind environment-related behaviours

author.au_affiliation_raw: Faculty of Science and Engineering, University of Wolverhampton, Wolverhampton WV1 1SB, UK
Faculty of Science and Engineering, University of Wolverhampton, Wolverhampton WV1 1SB, UK
Faculty of Science and Engineering, University of Wolverhampton, Wolverhampton WV1 1SB, UK

ab: We read with great interest Matthieu Guitton and Julien Poitras' Comment1Guitton MJ Poitras J Acquiring an operative sustainability expertise for health professionals.Lancet Planet Health. 2017; 1: e299-e300Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (4) Google Scholar published in The Lancet Planetary Health, and we would like to reinforce the importance of environmental education for health professionals. Particularly, some health disciplines‚Äîsuch as Psychology, which is often neglected in this field‚Äîmight have a cardinal role in environmental protection because they can help to support the delicate and long process of changing people's attitudes and behaviours for the protection of the environment they live in. We agree that environmental control has to be taken more seriously by governmental leaders. However, we think that society must be encouraged and inspired to understand environmental changes as well as to act proactively to safeguard the environment.2Weber E Doing the right thing willingly: behavioral decision theory and environmental policy.in: Shafir E The behavioral foundations of policy. Princeton University Press, Princeton2013Google Scholar Evidence suggests that technical and industrial practices as well as governmental policies are inadequate in supporting environmental control. To avoid these inadequacies, practices and policies have to take into consideration people's behaviours. People have to be taught how to infer and react to often confounding technical, governmental, and public information. Psychology is attentive, through its careful scientific research on behaviour, and might assist individuals in processing and responding effectively to the information about inherent multifaceted environmental challenges, such as the safeguard of the environment in which individuals live in.3Krantz DH Peterson N Arora P Milch K Orlove B Individual values and social goals in environmental decision making.in: Kugler T Smith JC Connolly T Son Y-J Decision modeling and behavior in complex and uncertain environments. Springer-Verlag New York, New York2008: 165-198Crossref Google Scholar Yet even with appropriate knowledge about how to protect the environment and a professed intention to do so, many people still do not behave coherently toward environment protection. There is often a substantial difference between peoples' self-reported knowledge, beliefs, thoughts, and intents, as well as their observable behaviour.4Wester J Timpano KR √áek D Lieberman D Fieldstone SC Broad K Psychological and social factors associated with wastewater reuse emotional discomfort.J Environ Psychol. 2015; 42: 16-23Crossref Scopus (67) Google Scholar, 5Baldi PL Iannello P Riva S Antonietti A Cognitive reflection and socially biased decisions.Studia Psychologica. 2013; 55: 265Crossref Scopus (23) Google Scholar Why does this difference exist? By drawing on important insights from psychology, particularly from cognitive psychology, an understanding of the key cognitive processes‚Äîsuch as biases, heuristics, and motivational factors‚Äîmight help explain why environment-related behaviour is frequently discordant between personal beliefs and people's intentions. The understanding of these psychological mechanisms can help design more cost-effective and successful interventions to encourage more appropriate behaviours among people. This online publication has been corrected. The corrected version first appeared at thelancet.com/planetaryhealth on February 26, 2020. This online publication has been corrected. The corrected version first appeared at thelancet.com/planetaryhealth on February 26, 2020. We acknowledge support from the Psychology in Construction and Smart, Sustainable, safe and healthy cities groups of the University of Wolverhampton. The Comment is based on a project that was funded by the European Commission (Project H2020-MSCA-IF2015/H2020-MSCA-IF-2015, Grant Agreement: 703236‚ÄîInhibiting Stress in the Construction Industry [INSTINCT]). The authors are very grateful to the EC for this funding. We declare no other competing interests. Acquiring an operative sustainability expertise for health professionalsThe effects of human activities on planetary ecosystems are nearing a point of no return. It is getting increasingly clear that population-wide behavioural changes will have to be the basis of any solution.1‚Äì4 Yet, in order for such changes to occur, a substantial proportion of the population has to be willing to endorse them. Because health professionals are heavily connected with all layers of the population and can have a major impact on societal issues,5‚Äì7 they might be able to encourage positive changes. Full-Text PDF Open AccessCorrection to Lancet Planet Health 2018; 2: e11Riva S, Chinyio E, Hampton P. Cognition, heuristics, and biases behind environment-related behaviours. Lancet Planet Health 2018; 2: e11‚ÄîThis Comment has been updated to acknowledge funding by the European Commission. This correction has been made as of Feb 26, 2020. Full-Text PDF Open Access

title: Health, livelihood, and environmental impacts of the distribution of a carbon-credit-financed, large-scale water filter and improved cookstove programme in Rwanda
display_name: Health, livelihood, and environmental impacts of the distribution of a carbon-credit-financed, large-scale water filter and improved cookstove programme in Rwanda

author.au_affiliation_raw: University of Colorado Boulder, Boulder, CO, USA
Emory University, Atlanta, GA, USA
Emory University, Atlanta, GA, USA
School of Public Health, Oregon Health & Science University, Portland State University, Portland, OR, USA

ab: In Rwanda, where two of the largest contributors to mortality among children younger than 5 years are pneumonia (11%) and diarrhoea (7%),1UNICEFCommitting to child survival: a promise renewed-progress report 2015.https://www.unicef.org/publications/index_83078.htmlDate: 2015Date accessed: April 7, 2018Google Scholar interventions that can improve access to clean drinking water and reduce exposure to harmful indoor air pollution have the potential to provide significant health impact. Additionally, with more than 80% of Rwandans relying on firewood as their primary fuel,2National Institute of Statistics of RwandaFourth Rwanda population and housing census.http://www.statistics.gov.rw/survey-period/fourth-population-and-housing-census-2012Date: 2012Date accessed: April 7, 2018Google Scholar decreased firewood demand could help reduce the shortage in firewood and the stress on forests. Cost and time savings from reduced fuelwood consumption could help curb some of the economic burden of roughly 60% of Rwandans who live on less than US$2 per day.3World BankPoverty headcount ratio at $1¬∑90 a day (2011 PPP) (% of population). Indicators.https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SI.POV.DDAY?locations=RW&view=chartlDate: 2018Date accessed: April 7, 2018Google Scholar The Tubeho Neza (Live Well) programme is a partnership between the Rwanda Ministry of Health and the social enterprise DelAgua Health to deliver environmental health technologies to some of the poorest Rwandan households. The programme distributed the EcoZoom Dura improved wood-burning cookstove (EcoZoom, Portland, OR, USA) and the LifeStraw Family 2.0 water filter (Vestergaard Frandsen, Lausanne, Switzerland) to more than 100 000 lower-income households in Rwanda's Western Province, followed by a further 250 000 cookstoves to households primarily in the Eastern Province, in 2015. The intervention included household-level education and behaviour-change messaging to each household through community health workers.4Barstow CK Ngabo F Rosa G et al.Designing and piloting a program to provide water filters and improved cookstoves in Rwanda.PLoS One. 2014; 9: e92403Crossref PubMed Scopus (20) Google Scholar, 5Barstow CK Nagel C Clasen TF Thomas EA Process evaluation and assessment of use of a large scale water filter and cookstove program in Rwanda.BMC Public Health. 2016; 16: 584Crossref PubMed Scopus (16) Google Scholar The programme was privately funded by DelAgua, and earns revenue, in part, through the generation and sale of carbon credits issued under the UN Clean Development Mechanism, tied proportionally to repeatedly measured use of the intervention.6Thomas EA Barstow C Clasen T Incentivizing impact‚Äîprivately financed public health in Rwanda.in: Thomas E Broken pumps and promises. Springer, Cham2016: 99-131Crossref Scopus (0) Google Scholar To assess the effects of the intervention in Western Province, investigators undertook a randomised controlled trial7Nagel CL Kirby MA Zambrano LD et al.Study design of a cluster-randomized controlled trial to evaluate a large-scale distribution of cook stoves and water filters in Western Province, Rwanda.Contemp Clin Trials Commun. 2016; 4: 124-135Crossref PubMed Scopus (14) Google Scholar among 174 village-level clusters, half of which were randomly assigned to receive the intervention (filter, stove, and use promotion) and the other half to serve as controls. Investigators also undertook studies to estimate the economic and environmental impact of the intervention. The purpose of this Case Report is to describe the Tubeho Neza programme in western Rwanda, in the context of health, economic, and environmental benefits. Preliminary analysis of the results of the health impact study suggest that the intervention increased the proportion of households with no detectable faecal contamination in drinking water samples by 92% (p<0¬∑0001), and reduced the prevalence of caretaker-reported child diarrhoea in the previous week by 30% (p=0¬∑0002). Preliminary results also suggest that the intervention reduced the prevalence of reported acute respiratory infection in the previous week by 29% (p=0¬∑0006). After conducting kitchen performance tests, we estimated that 120 000 tonnes of annual woodfuel savings in the Western Province might be attributable to the programme, decreasing to 102 000 tonnes in 2024. These estimates suggest that this programme alone might compensate for the government-projected deficit in woodfuel in the Western Province of 106 000 tonnes per year by 2020.8Ministry of Natural Resources, Rwanda Natural Resources Authority, Department of Forestry and Nature ConservationRwanda Supply Master Plan for fuelwood and charcoal. Final report. Update and upgrade of WISDOM Rwanda.http://rnra.rw/fileadmin/user_upload/Final_Report_SMP_Rwanda.pdfDate: 2013Date accessed: April 7, 2018Google Scholar Households that collect fuelwood might save around 48 days per year in collection of fuelwood, while households who previously boiled water might save around 23 days in boiling of water for drinking. We found that this intervention provides significant benefits that might continue to accrue if the programme continues to be supported. Ongoing support of this programme is contingent on viable revenue earned through carbon-credit generation and sales, a business model currently in jeopardy given the depressed carbon-credit market attributable in part to the USA's declaration of withdrawal from the Paris Climate Agreement. Funding DelAgua Health, Rwanda Ministry of Health. Contributors CB was responsible for the behaviour change design and environmental impact study. TC and MK designed and managed the health impact study. MK implemented and analysed the health impact study. ET designed and managed the overall programme concept and implementation. Declaration of interests CB and ET were financially compensated consultants for DelAgua as programme managers. TC and MK were compensated by their university through a grant from DelAgua.

title: Making measurable progress in improving China's air and health
display_name: Making measurable progress in improving China's air and health

author.au_affiliation_raw: Health Effects Institute, Boston, MA 02110-1817, USA

ab: Ambient air pollution emanates from a dizzying array of combustion sources‚Äîeg, the burning of fuel for transportation, electricity, industry, agricultural burning, and home heating and cooking‚Äîand non-combustion sources, including construction and other dusts, off-gassing from agricultural practice, wastewater treatment, and many others. Populations across the globe are exposed to this complex mixture, and the latest health science estimates that it contributed to approximately 4¬∑1 million deaths from heart disease, stroke, lung cancer, and chronic lung disease in 2016.1Gakidou E Afshin A Abajobir AA et al.Global, regional, and national comparative risk assessment of 84 behavioural, environmental and occupational, and metabolic risks or clusters of risks, 1990‚Äì2016: a systematic analysis for the Global Burden of Disease Study 2016.Lancet. 2017; 390: 1345-1422Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1631) Google Scholar Nowhere is this public health impact more keenly felt than in two rapidly developing countries, China and India, which together account for more than half of the public health burden.2Health Effects InstituteState of Global Air 2018. Special report.http://www.stateofglobalair.org/sites/default/files/soga-2018-report.pdfDate: 2018Date accessed: June 13, 2018Google Scholar Reducing population exposure from these sources of air pollution is a huge technical, economic, and often political challenge. Yet we have seen substantial progress over the past half century in the UK, the USA, and elsewhere, with investments in air pollution science, strong government action, and development of new and efficient technologies for pollution control.3National Research CouncilAir quality management in the United States. National Academies Press, Washington, DC2004Google Scholar For example, as a result of vehicle emission controls, levels of ambient carbon monoxide in the Los Angeles (CA, USA) area have fallen from more than 40 ppm in the 1960s to under 8 ppm (the current national standard), even while the number of vehicles have doubled, and vehicle miles travelled have tripled.4National Research CouncilManaging carbon monoxide pollution in meteorological and topographical problem areas. National Academies Press, Washington, DC2003Google Scholar Furthermore, increasing evidence shows that these reductions have translated into health improvements: for example, a substantial improvement in lung function growth was seen in children growing up in a cohort in Southern California in 2003 compared with children in similar cohorts who grew up there in 1992‚Äì96, when air was more highly polluted.5Gilliland F Avol E McConnell R et al.The effects of policy-driven air quality improvements on children's respiratory health.https://www.healtheffects.org/system/files/GillilandRR190.pdfDate: January, 2017Date accessed: June 12, 2018Google Scholar In the wake of increased awareness of air pollution and its health implications for China, the Chinese Government has responded with substantial investments in atmospheric science to better understand the sources and causes of the air pollution, and with a multidimensional control strategy aimed at reducing emissions from vehicle and fuels, coal-fired electric generating units, and many other sources. In The Lancet Planetary Health, Jing Huang and colleagues6Huang J Pan X Guo X Li G Health impact of China's Air Pollution Prevention and Control Action Plan: an analysis of national air quality monitoring and mortality data.Lancet Planet Health. 2018; 2: e313-e323Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (324) Google Scholar have now contributed a systematic analysis of how these many actions have measurably reduced air pollution in 74 key Chinese cities that have the longest track record of measuring air pollution. The authors found that annual average concentrations of PM2¬∑5 decreased by 33¬∑3% (95% CI 16¬∑3‚Äì50¬∑3), PM10 by 27¬∑8% (8¬∑0‚Äì47¬∑5), sulphur dioxide by 54¬∑1% (28¬∑2‚Äì80¬∑0), and carbon monoxide by 28¬∑2% (3¬∑1‚Äì53¬∑3) in the 74 key cities. The investigators went further to apply the latest‚Äîand widely recognised‚Äîintegrated exposure‚Äìresponse functions7Cohen AJ Brauer M Burnett R et al.Estimates and 25-year trends of the global burden of disease attributable to ambient air pollution: an analysis of data from the Global Burden of Diseases Study 2015.Lancet. 2017; 389: 1907-1918Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (3222) Google Scholar to estimate that in 2017 there were 47 240 (95% CI 25 870‚Äì69 990) fewer deaths and 710 020 (420 230‚Äì1 025 460) fewer years of life lost attributable to air pollution in the 74 key cities than in 2013, a substantial public health improvement. Having documented this progress, the investigators are also careful to note the challenges in undertaking such an analysis‚Äîand in making continuing air quality progress in China. First, although they did analyses to test whether meteorology rather than air quality control might be responsible for the improvement, and did not find evidence that this was the case, they note that weather might still have contributed. Although 5 years is a reasonable initial time to test air quality trends, the multiple atmospheric and meteorological variables argue for continued surveillance to ensure that progress is real and lasting. Second, they note that economic trends other than the air pollution control measures (ie, improvements in the efficiency of industries) might have also contributed, reminding us of the importance of tracking many factors that could improve air quality and public health over the long term, including the economy and changes in health care (eg, improvements in cardiovascular treatment care that extend life). They do, however, present strong evidence of reduced emissions from key sources that could only have resulted from the implementation of the required control measures, suggesting an important role for the Government's actions in achieving progress. Third, the investigators note that even with the improvements in air quality, levels still substantially exceed China's air quality standards for fine particulate matter (PM2¬∑5), and about 365 000 premature deaths could still be attributed to PM2¬∑5 air pollution, even accounting for the 47 240 fewer deaths reported. This finding should not come as a surprise: every country has accomplished cleaner air only after many years of effort (close to 50 years in the USA, for example), and after continued revisiting and improvement of control measures. To this end, it is heartening to see the Chinese Government, even as it notes the progress it has made, make a new set of commitments to an additional 3 years of action.8Leng S China has new three-year plan to clean up environment, minister says. South China Morning Post.http://www.scmp.com/news/china/policies-politics/article/2137666/china-has-new-three-year-plan-clean-environmentDate: March 18, 2018Date accessed: June 12, 2018Google Scholar Fourth, the investigators report that even as progress has been made on reducing PM2¬∑5 pollution, there has been substantial growth in exposures to, and health effects from, ozone air pollution. This trend is important to note and will require further attention. Although many of the sources of the pollutants that contribute to the formation of ozone smog are similar to those needing control for PM2¬∑5 , the complex chemistry in which these chemicals mix with ultraviolet radiation and weather to form ozone makes successful control of ozone levels considerably more challenging, a fact that has made continued progress on ozone in countries with stronger air quality management and controls such as the USA very difficult. Clearly, the issues surrounding air pollution in China pose public health challenges. The actions of the Chinese Government‚Äîand this new analysis by Huang and colleagues documenting the substantial progress‚Äîaugur very well for continued learning and improvement in tackling this important issue. I declare no competing interests. Health impact of China's Air Pollution Prevention and Control Action Plan: an analysis of national air quality monitoring and mortality dataSubstantial reductions in mortality and YLL related to control of ambient air pollution were achieved from 2013 to 2017 in China, indicating appreciable effectiveness of China's APPCAP. However, emissions control efforts for ozone and nitrogen dioxide should be strengthened in the future. Full-Text PDF Open Access

title: Space technologies for monitoring health and environmental impact of hydraulic fracturing
display_name: Space technologies for monitoring health and environmental impact of hydraulic fracturing

author.au_affiliation_raw: Credit Valley Family Medicine Teaching Unit and Summerville Family Medicine Teaching Unit, Trillium Health Partners and University of Toronto, Mississauga, ON, Canada
Space Studies Program, International Space University, Strasbourg, France
Space Generation Advisory Council, Vienna, Austria
Functional Architecture of Mammals in Their Environment Laboratory, University of Thessaly, Trikala, Greece
Space Studies Program, International Space University, Strasbourg, France
Space Studies Program, International Space University, Strasbourg, France
Russ College of Engineering and Technology, Ohio University, Athens, OH, USA
Russ College of Engineering and Technology, Ohio University, Athens, OH, USA

ab: The world continues to depend on fossil fuels, increasing consumption despite increased awareness of renewable options and measures to curb its use. The rising demand for energy has led many countries to rely on hydraulic fracturing for oil and gas. With the oil and gas extraction industries accounting for more than 1¬∑7% of the US gross domestic product, such drilling activities are believed to improve national and local economies through job creation. This economic growth has acted as a great incentive for private companies to enter hydraulic fracturing operations. Although chemicals identified at these drilling operations are known to have health and climate change implications, there is still much debate about the effect of hydraulic fracturing on public health and the environment. Over 600 chemicals have been identified from drilling activity in the USA, 75% of which might pose a health risk to the skin and eyes; 40% to the nervous, immune, and cardiovascular systems; and 25% might increase the risk of cancer.1Colborn T Kwiatkowski C Schultz K Bachran M Natural gas operations from a public health perspective.Hum Ecol Risk Asses. 2011; 17: 1039-1056Crossref Scopus (347) Google Scholar In general, detailed information about chemicals used in hydraulic fracturing operations is usually not available as jurisdictions do not oblige companies to report it. Evidence shows that hydraulic fracturing contaminates water sources because of surface spills and wastewater disposal,2Jackson RB Vengosh A Carey JW et al.The environmental costs and benefits of fracking.Annu RevEnviron Resour. 2014; 39: 327-362Crossref Scopus (297) Google Scholar increases greenhouse gas emissions,3Roy AA Adams PJ Robinson AL Air pollutant emissions from the development, production, and processing of Marcellus Shale natural gas.J Air Waste Manag Assoc. 2014; 64: 19-37Crossref PubMed Scopus (98) Google Scholar might be linked with an increase in earthquakes,4Xuewei B Eaton DW Fault activation by hydraulic fracturing in western Canada.Science. 2016; 354: 1406-1409Crossref Scopus (366) Google Scholar and has a health-related effect because lower-than-average birthweights were observed in areas within a 3 km radius of hydraulic fracturing sites.5Currie J Greenstone M Meckel K Hydraulic fracturing and infant health: new evidence from Pennsylvania.Sci Adv. 2017; 3: e1603021Crossref PubMed Scopus (94) Google Scholar Public opinion about hydraulic fracturing operations is mixed because of the scarcity of trustworthy information about this topic. An article in The Guardian highlighted the public's fears about the pollution that hydraulic fracturing could cause given the recent development of this industry in Scotland.6The GuardianUK fracking to begin in earnest in 2018 after tough year for industry.https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2017/dec/25/fracking-start-2018-shale-gas-uk-industry-protestsDate: Dec 25, 2017Date accessed: January 25, 2018Google Scholar Although hydraulic fracturing could supply the UK with gas for 25 years, public protests are common because of the potential environmental pollution and public health issues it could cause.6The GuardianUK fracking to begin in earnest in 2018 after tough year for industry.https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2017/dec/25/fracking-start-2018-shale-gas-uk-industry-protestsDate: Dec 25, 2017Date accessed: January 25, 2018Google Scholar Similar concerns are increasing in the UK, EU, USA, and Canada. Although organisations such as the International Energy Agency try to help share knowledge with the international community about policies and regulations pertaining to these operations, most countries rely on national regulatory frameworks. In this light, Public Health England recommends the need for baseline environmental monitoring to assess the effect of hydraulic fracturing on public health and the need for effective monitoring throughout development, production, and post-production.7Public Health EnglandShale gas extraction: review of the potential public health impacts of exposures to chemical and radioactive pollutants (draft for comment).https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/shale-gas-extraction-review-of-the-potential-public-health-impacts-of-exposures-to-chemical-and-radioactive-pollutants-draft-for-commentDate: Oct 30, 2013Date accessed: May 16, 2017Google Scholar There is a need to gather more data about the public health and environmental effect of hydraulic fracturing, to help policy-makers make more informed decisions about the matter. Space assets have already had a role in environmental monitoring and have also been used in areas of health care for disaster management,8Dinas PC Mueller C Clark N et al.Innovative methods for the benefit of public health using space technologies for disaster response.Disaster Med Public Health Prep. 2015; 9: 319-328Crossref PubMed Scopus (12) Google Scholar public health emergencies, and infectious disease outbreaks.9Asrar FM Asrar S Clark JB et al.Help from above: outer space and the fight against Ebola.Lancet Infect Dis. 2015; 15: 873-875Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (10) Google Scholar Currently, several satellites, including GOSAT (Japan), Aura (USA), MetOp (Europe), and Sentinel 4 and 5 (Europe), monitor environmental pollutants and elements. These satellites might play a role in monitoring pollutants of hydraulic fracturing activities because of their ability to measure pollutants such as carbon dioxide, carbon monoxide, methane, nitrous oxide, ozone, sulphur dioxide, nitrogen dioxide, and particulate matters 2¬∑5 and 10. A report10Tracking FrackingInternational Space University Team Project report. Space Studies Program 2015. International Space University.Available from https://isulibrary.isunet.edu/opac/index.php?lvl=notice_display&id=9450Date: 2015Date accessed: May 16, 2017Google Scholar from the Space Studies Program of the International Space University, recommended a remote sensing multiplatform system to address the challenge of monitoring and quantifying the emissions from hydraulic fracturing sites (figure). The findings from this report suggest that in the short term (0‚Äì2 years) data from existing space, airborne, and ground air pollution monitoring systems can be utilised to create a multiplatform monitoring system for hydraulic fracturing operations. In the medium term (2‚Äì10 years), the system will be supplemented with high-resolution air pollution monitoring sensors on geostationary orbit satellites, such as the TEMPO satellite, and future instruments to measure geostationary orbit-coastal and air pollution events. In the long-term (10+ years), the performance of present satellite monitoring systems will advance and include high spatial and temporal resolution remote-sensing satellite systems that will achieve global coverage and all hydraulic fracturing sites could be monitored by the satellite-based system. Frequent, high-resolution monitoring of air pollution will allow organisations to reduce health and environmental threats where necessary. This satellite-based monitoring will eventually provide a global solution for monitoring hydraulic fracturing activities. Nowadays, it is feasible to monitor environmental pollutants by using a combination of methods. The aggregation of data over time will enable scientists to better understand the underlying mechanisms behind the impact of hydraulic fracturing on public health and the environment. This might enable policy-makers to form regulations for proper and safe hydraulic fracturing activities that will eventually benefit the global economy and not threat global health and the environment. We declare no competing interests. FMA, AHW, SAN, CN, and PD contributed equally and are joint first authors. We would like to acknowledge the help and support of Mr John Connolly from the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) and International Space University, and key informants for their assistance during the Space Studies Program team project. We would also like to acknowledge the members of the Space Studies Program who were involved in the Tracking Fracking Project.

title: Can the Paris Agreement save us from a climate catastrophe?
display_name: Can the Paris Agreement save us from a climate catastrophe?
ab: As a society, we are living through one of the most challenging periods of human civilisation. Climate change's impacts affect not only our health but also have a profound effect on the rate of social, economic, and technological transformation that is possible. Climate change represents the biggest threat to humankind. As well as immediate hazards, extreme weather events impact on mental health and often create conditions conducive to outbreaks of infectious diseases: heavy rains produce insect-breeding grounds and contaminate clean water sources; while drought can increase distribution of fungal spores. Women, especially expectant mothers, are highly vulnerable to water-borne diseases, extremes of temperature and other catastrophic events. Women and children are 14-times more likely than men to die during a disaster. If we consider that 68% of disasters are related to climate change, then this is an alarming disparity. In December, 2015, 195 countries and the European Union announced in Paris a global commitment to change. The central part of the Paris Agreement was that temperature rise would not exceed 2¬∞C above preindustrial levels, and a secondary part set the target to 1¬∑5¬∞C. The Agreement is due to commence in 2020 and so far 195 parties remain committed to it. However, the signatories have not yet agreed how they intend to achieve these targets and a rise of 1¬∞C has already occurred. How is the Paris Agreement helping to tackle climate change? Even though renewable energy technologies for energy production are approaching cost parity with fossil fuels and vehicles are becoming more efficient to reduce fuel consumption and limit air pollution, the world is off target. 2 years after the Agreement was signed, global emissions of carbon dioxide are rising again after several years of stability; in June, 2017, US President Donald Trump said he intends to withdraw from the climate accord and the USA will see its emission rates rise this year by 1¬∑8% after 3 years of plateau. Other countries are also giving signs that they might not meet the targets. Reasons vary from country to country. In Brazil, for example, deforestation has boosted carbon dioxide emissions through reduced carbon capture. In Turkey and Indonesia, new coal-fired power plants are being built to meet the growing demand for electricity as a consequence of population growth. A huge gap remains between what countries have agreed in Paris and what they have managed to achieve so far. Economic and political concerns mean that countries are struggling to meet their nationally determined contributions. Germany, for example‚Äîone of the most active countries when it comes to renewable energy‚Äîintended to generate 80% of its energy from renewable sources by 2050 and to cut greenhouses gas emissions by 40% below 1990 levels by 2020. But concerns over job losses and changes within the coalition government mean that Germany is likely to miss its targets. With traditional global powers like the USA pulling out and Germany not reaching its targets, China and India‚Äîwhich together produce about 24% of the world's emissions‚Äîmight provide some hope. Both have invested heavily in renewable energies markets (as well as traditional sources). If they manage to cut emissions, it could make up for the shortfall elsewhere. In this issue, Wenjia Cai and colleagues analyse China's nationally determined contributions under the Paris Agreement, and conclude that 18‚Äì62% of implementation costs at the national level would be offset by the health benefits in 2030. The overall health benefits in 2050 could increase to 3‚Äì9-times the implementation costs. Such a tangible cost-benefit outcome, especially in the important context of China, could encourage other countries to redouble their efforts to curb climate change. These health benefits should also encourage public health and medical professionals to speak up on the importance of climate change. If the world's emissions do not start declining decisively by 2020 it might be too late to stop the sea level rise, droughts, storms, and other catastrophic effects of climate change. Although current commitments of the Paris signatories fall short of the emissions cuts required to meet the aspirational 1¬∑5¬∞C target, the solution is not to give up but to reinvest. It is imperative that countries get focused on the targets of the Paris agreement put in practice the pledges agreed 2 years ago. We must look further upstream to enable planetary health-literate urban developmentThe gap between academic research and real-world practice in urban planning and development is a major barrier to planetary health.1 By exploring uncertainty and complexity further upstream, we might be able to narrow that gap, and make progress in tackling the urban health crisis. Full-Text PDF Open AccessThe Lancet Countdown on PM2¬∑5 pollution-related health impacts of China's projected carbon dioxide mitigation in the electric power generation sector under the Paris Agreement: a modelling studyOur results suggest that cost‚Äìbenefit analysis of climate policy that omits regional air pollution could greatly underestimate benefits. A compensation mechanism for inter-regional interests (including financial, technological, and knowledge support) should be established for regions that give up their human health benefits for the sake of the whole nation to realise the climate change targets. Full-Text PDF Open Access

title: The world's biggest threats are environmental risks
display_name: The world's biggest threats are environmental risks
ab: On Jan 23‚Äì26, global leaders gathered once again in Davos, Switzerland, on the occasion of the 48th World Economic Forum annual meeting. In the past few years the global landscape has changed substantially economically and politically, putting our planet seriously in danger, and for the first time these environmental threats were put at the centre of the debate. According to the World Economic Forum's Global Risks Report 2018, released a week before the meeting was held, the most pressing threats that are perceived as having the biggest impact in the next 10 years are extreme weather events and natural disasters, failure of climate change mitigation and adaptation, water crises, biodiversity loss, and air and soil pollution. Before 2010, environmental risks had never topped the global risks report, but have done so three times since then. What has changed so dramatically to justify this elevation? What has made the environmental so important suddenly? Why are global leaders putting the environment in the spotlight? Economic collapses, triggered by oil price shocks or financial crises, were frequently considered to be the most likely risks to cause significant global disruption before 2011. Back then, environmental issues such as extreme weather events and natural disasters took a backseat. In the past 7 years this attitude has changed strikingly; not because economic risks have been melted way or resolved but because they have been surpassed by concerns over the lack of action on the environmental front. Today it is not difficult to see how the environment tops the list, given the extreme climate events of the past few years. 2017 for example was characterised by the three frightening Atlantic hurricanes Harvey, Irma, and Maria; extreme temperatures; and a rise in carbon dioxide for the first time in 4 years. Storms and high temperatures have imposed a huge economic burden on the governments of many nations‚Äîthe economic losses from global disasters was estimated to be as high as US $306 billion in 2017, almost double the amount recorded in 2016 of $188 billion. The USA was the most damaged. The three storms losses were estimated to have contributed $93 billion to the annual economic losses from global disasters, but they were also the leading cause of human displacement and insecurity. According to the report, in 2016, 76% of the 31¬∑1 million people displaced were forced from their homes as a consequence of weather events. 2017 was also the hottest year on record; temperatures were 1¬∑1¬∞C above preindustrial levels and further increases are expected. Rising temperatures and frequent heatwaves are expected to strain agriculture systems. According to the UN Food and Agricultural Organization, heat, drought, and flood events will cause a fault in the production of maize in the two biggest growers (the USA and China). Loss in biodiversity is occurring at disturbing rates. Destruction of forests for farming, mining, and oil and gas production, not to mention infrastructure development, remains the main driver of biodiversity loss. And as if these challenges were not enough, air pollution is not making our life on this planet any better. More than 90% of the world's population live in areas with levels of pollution exceeding WHO guidelines. 2018 is not looking a more promising year. As we move towards an era of decarbonisation, new risks are expected to arise. Drastic changes in the way energy will be produced are likely to pose new risks on economies, societies, and our planet. Unfortunately, not enough has been done to mitigate climate change and to preserve our planet. Scenarios from the fifth assessment report of the UN Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change that keep the temperature rises to less than 2¬∞C above the preindustrial level rely on the implementation of carbon dioxide removal (negative emission) technologies during the latter half of the century. However a broader range of scenarios that do not place the burden on future generations should employed, as highlighted in a commentary in Nature Climate Change. There, the authors argue that to support international policymakers in limiting climate change we need a more realistic and earlier deployment of interventions. We live in era characterised by a great technological, scientific, and financial development. The current generation are facing today a big challenge to use available resources in a sustainable way to build a more resilient future. Scientists, policymakers, global leaders, societies, and governments across regions and nations have the responsibility to reduce the global risks by setting more realistic targets and work together to build a better world for all. People's voice to reduce global environmental risksWe read the editorial of The Lancet Planetary Health (February, 2018) describing how environmental risks have been recognised as the ‚Äúworld's biggest threats‚Äù at the 48th annual meeting of World Economic Forum.1 Alongside the meeting, the report of Environmental Performance Index was published, which ranked Bangladesh and India as the second and fourth worst countries, respectively, in terms of their efforts towards improving environmental health and ecosystem vitality.2 Although many parameters are considered for such ranking, tiny efforts from the community are reflections of the intentions of many individuals and provide a ray of hope for a better future. Full-Text PDF Open Access
