author.au_affiliation_raw: School of Public Health, Tongji Medical College, Huazhong University of Science and Technology, 13 Hangkong Road, Wuhan, Hubei 430030, China
author.institution_display_name: Huazhong University of Science and Technology

author.au_affiliation_raw: School of Public Health, Tongji Medical College, Huazhong University of Science and Technology, 13 Hangkong Road, Wuhan, Hubei 430030, China
author.institution_display_name: Huazhong University of Science and Technology

ab: From Jan 1, 2018, the Environmental Protection Tax (EPT) law in China was officially launched.1State Administration of TaxationThe environmental protection tax will be levied on.http://www.chinatax.gov.cn/n810341/n810780/c2949707/content.htmlDate: Jan 1, 2018Date accessed: January 1, 2018Google Scholar This is the first tax law in China specifically established for environmental protection. Compared with the traditional pollution discharge fee, the EPT law has a stronger legal, executive, and binding force. Now, as emphasised by the politician Xi Jinping, people in China have a law to abide by and the Chinese government must guarantee strict law enforcement.2people.cn. Decision of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China on several major issues of ruling the country by law.http://politics.people.com.cn/n/2014/1029/c1001-25926893.htmlDate accessed: January 1, 2018Google Scholar Enacting this law is the first and most important step for China to control environmental pollution. The implementation of the EPT law requires the cooperation of citizens, enterprises, and governments in different areas and levels. According to EPT law, in China and other areas under the jurisdiction of China, the enterprises and institutions that directly discharge taxable pollutants into the environment have to pay tax. However, the organisations, groups, and residents who are not involved in the production and management of taxable pollutants do not pay tax. Considering that everybody is responsible for environmental pollution, and that environmental pollution affects everybody to some extent, it is our common responsibility to protect planetary health.3The Principle of ‚ÄúCommon but Differentiated Responsibilities‚Äù.http://world.people.com.cn/n/2014/1206/c157278-26160771.htmlDate accessed: January 1, 2018Google Scholar In the next step, an individual garbage disposal fee should be brought to the agenda. Additionally, environmental protection is a systematic and integral work. Improving individuals' awareness of and ability to contribute to environmental protection, providing technical support for enterprise transformation and upgrading, establishing disposal and recycling systems for waste, perfecting independent monitoring and assessment systems, and refining the government's responsibility together shall promote its implementation. Finally, environmental protection is the foundation of human survival and development. Preventing pollution should have both a nationally and internationally high priority at all planning levels.4Landrigan P J Fuller R Njr A et al.The Lancet Commission on pollution and health.Lancet. 2017; 391: 462-512Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1963) Google Scholar We declare no competing interests.

title: Land degradation: a solution is possible
display_name: Land degradation: a solution is possible
ab: Land degradation is harming the wellbeing of 3¬∑2 billion people and the impact of its effects will only grow with time. So reports the Intergovernmental Science-Policy Platform on Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services (IPBES), an independent intergovernmental body set up by UN member states, in a new summary for policy makers. Land degradation is the human-induced loss of biodiversity, productivity, and ecosystem functions from terrestrial and aquatic environments. It results from practices that bring short-term benefits to those doing them, but have substantial long-term costs, such as overgrazing of land, draining of wetlands for agricultural uses, and disruptive mining practices.

title: Implementation of policies to protect planetary health
display_name: Implementation of policies to protect planetary health

author.au_affiliation_raw: Centre for Remote Health, Flinders University, Corner Skinner and Simpson Streets, Alice Springs, NT 0870, Australia

ab: Subhrendu Pattanayak and Andy Haines's important Comment1Pattanayak S Haines A Implementation of policies to protect planetary health.Lancet Planet Health. 2017; 1: e255-e256Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (14) Google Scholar outlined the inadequacy of progress towards planetary health, and noted the opportunity provided by the Sustainable Development Goals to confront challenges to planetary health. The authors argued that evidence from high-income settings cannot be directly transposed to low-income or middle-income settings, and this issue contributes to inadequate progress towards implementation of planetary health policies. Missing from the Comment was consideration of transference of evidence from low and middle-income settings to high-income ones in efforts to attain sustainable development. Action by all countries is needed to reach the Sustainable Development Goals, and some low and middle-income countries are leading in promotion of sustainable development. Examples are Bhutan, Costa Rica, Maldives, and Tuvalu in their progress towards being carbon neutral, and Ecuador whose new constitution includes the rights of nature and fostering of a good life with harmony between people and nature.2Department of Economic and Social Affairs UNSWorld economic and social survey 2013: sustainable development challenges. United Nations, New York2013Google Scholar The need to transfer evidence from low and middle-income settings to high-income settings is an important omission from the Comment. Without this consideration the opportunities for development towards planetary health are limited. Within the health sector the notion of reverse innovation, from low and middle-income countries, is emerging, and challenging the discourse that high-income countries alone lead innovation.3Ahmed F Ahmed N Briggs T et al.Can reverse innovation catalyse better value health care?.Lancet Global Health. 2017; 5: e967-e968Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (13) Google Scholar RS is a recipient of a research entry scholarship from the Vincent Fairfax Family Foundation, administered by the Royal Australasian College of Physicians. Implementation of policies to protect planetary health ‚Äì Authors‚Äô replyWe agree with Rosalie Schultz that innovation in the health-care sector could, in principle, be led by low-income and middle-income countries (LMICs) and that high-income countries can learn useful lessons from successful approaches to scaling up access to effective health care. Indeed one of us has argued that countries such as the UK should learn from the Brazilian experience of community health workers working in primary care teams.1 However, recent evidence suggests that decision makers from high-income countries may reject evidence from health services in LMICs, often perceiving it to be of little relevance to their circumstances. Full-Text PDF Open AccessImplementation of policies to protect planetary healthExtensive evidence exists that human health and civilisation depends on flourishing natural systems.1 The Rockefeller‚ÄìLancet Commission on planetary health summarised how climate change, biodiversity loss, freshwater depletion, and air and water pollution threaten to reverse advances in human health and increase health inequities worldwide.2 For example, increasing carbon dioxide concentrations and declines in animal pollinators will exacerbate micronutrient deficiencies and risks of non-communicable disease. Full-Text PDF Open Access

title: The Paris Agreement saves lives in China
display_name: The Paris Agreement saves lives in China

author.au_affiliation_raw: Center for Sustainability and the Global Environment, SAGE, the Nelson Institute and Department of Population Health Sciences, University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI 53726, USA
Department of Environmental Sciences & Engineering, University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, NC, USA
author.institution_display_name: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill

ab: The Paris Agreement to address climate change could bring substantial public health benefits from reducing air pollution, by shifting away from polluting energy resources toward cleaner alternatives. Perhaps no nation will benefit more from greenhouse gas controls than China, where a large population are exposed to severe air pollution, and where coal dominates the energy landscape. Under the Paris Agreement, China has pledged for its carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions to peak around the year 2030. Since China's emissions growth led the world over the past two decades, this pledge is an important step toward slowing global climate change. In the Lancet Planetary Health, Wenjia Cai and colleagues1Cai W Hui J Wang C et al.The Lancet Countdown on PM2¬∑5 pollution-related health impacts of China's projected carbon dioxide mitigation in the energy generation sector under the Paris Agreement: a modelling study.Lancet Planet Health. 2018; 2: 151-161Summary Full Text Full Text PDF Scopus (46) Google Scholar analysed China's nationally determined commitments (NDC) under the Paris Agreement, and concluded that 18‚Äì62% of implementation costs at the national level could be offset by the health benefits in 2030. The overall health benefits in 2050 could increase to 3‚Äì9 times the implementation costs. The reduction of fine particulate matter (PM2¬∑5) pollution in China would, on average, cause about 20 000 fewer deaths per year in 2030, and about 370 000 fewer annual deaths in 2050. The largest benefits would accrue from reducing the number of deaths from strokes, ischaemic heart disease, and lung disease. This study is consistent with similar studies, building on more than 20 years of research on co-benefits.2Working Group on Public Health and Fossil Fuel CombustionShort-term improvements in public health from global climate policies on fossil fuel combustion: an interim report.Lancet. 1997; 350: 1341-1349Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (84) Google Scholar, 3Nemet GF Holloway T Maier P Implications of incorporating air-quality co-benefits into climate change policymaking.Environ Res Lett. 2010; 5: 014007Crossref Scopus (289) Google Scholar For example, the US Clean Power Plan‚Äîa 30% reduction in CO2 emissions from the 2005 levels by 2030 to support its Paris Agreement pledge‚Äîwould result in a 25% cut in emissions of sulphur dioxide (SO2) and nitrogen oxides (NOx), and an estimated 3500 premature deaths avoided annually by 2020.4Driscoll CT Buonocore JJ Levy JI et al.US power plant carbon standards and clean air and health co-benefits.Nat Clim Chang. 2015; 5: 535-540Crossref Scopus (126) Google Scholar This outcome is comparable to Cai and colleagues'1Cai W Hui J Wang C et al.The Lancet Countdown on PM2¬∑5 pollution-related health impacts of China's projected carbon dioxide mitigation in the energy generation sector under the Paris Agreement: a modelling study.Lancet Planet Health. 2018; 2: 151-161Summary Full Text Full Text PDF Scopus (46) Google Scholar findings when considering both higher population and air pollution concentrations in China. Completely eliminating coal combustion could save far more lives, according to a US study5Prehoda EW Pearce JM Potential lives saved by replacing coal with solar photovoltaic electricity production in the U.S.Renew Sust Energ Rev. 2017; 80: 710-715Crossref Scopus (31) Google Scholar that reported that 52 000 deaths in the USA could be avoided annually. Other studies that compared the costs of greenhouse gas controls with the monetised air pollution-related health benefits also reported similar results. One lifecycle analysis in the USA found that the health benefits of a national low-carbon energy plan would offset energy investment costs by 26% to 1050%‚Äîor up to ten times.6Thompson TM Rausch S Saari RK Selin NE A systems approach to evaluating the air quality co-benefits of US carbon policies.Nat Clim Change. 2014; 4: 917-923Crossref Scopus (157) Google Scholar At the global level, West and colleagues7West JJ Smith SJ Silva RA et al.Co-benefits of global greenhouse gas mitigation for future air quality and human health.Nat Clim Chang. 2013; 3: 885-889Crossref PubMed Scopus (403) Google Scholar monetised health co-benefits from avoided mortality due to reductions in PM2¬∑5 and ozone with global averages ranging from US$50/tonne to $380/tonne of CO2 emissions avoided. Regional estimates of co-benefits are as follows: $30‚Äì600 for the USA and Western Europe; $70‚Äì840 for China, and $20‚Äì400 for India. In east Asia, these air quality-related health benefits are 10‚Äì70 times the abatement costs in 2030. Although the main conclusion from the study of Cai and colleagues1Cai W Hui J Wang C et al.The Lancet Countdown on PM2¬∑5 pollution-related health impacts of China's projected carbon dioxide mitigation in the energy generation sector under the Paris Agreement: a modelling study.Lancet Planet Health. 2018; 2: 151-161Summary Full Text Full Text PDF Scopus (46) Google Scholar was that overall health benefits substantially outweigh implementation costs of cleaner technology, they also found that air pollution initially could worsen as a result of the NDCs in the northwest of China, because the electric power system will respond to the NDCs with less coal consumption nationally, but will increase in the northwest. Such a result shows the value of subnational studies for co-benefits. The study of Cai and colleagues has some limitations. The study only considers the power generation sector and not the full economy, and it only considers PM2¬∑5 resulting from changes in emissions of NOx and SO2. Although power generation is clearly an important source of air pollutants in China, considering other sectors might also be important for the overall results‚Äîeg, because reducing fossil fuel consumption could increase biofuel use, causing possibly greater emissions.8Ou Y Shi W Smith SJ et al.Estimating environmental co-benefits of U.S. low-carbon pathways using an integrated assessment model with state-level resolution.Appl Energy. 2018; 216: 482-493Crossref Scopus (37) Google Scholar Likewise, the study does not examine the health benefits outside of China's borders, which could be substantial, especially for ozone, nor the health benefits within China of greenhouse gas reductions in other nations under the Paris Agreement.9Zhang Y Smith SJ Bowden JH Adelman Z West JJ Co-benefits of global, domestic, and sectoral greenhouse gas mitigation for US air quality and human health in 2050.Environ Res Letts. 2017; 12: 114033Crossref Scopus (35) Google Scholar Finally, other health benefits are likely to result from greenhouse gas reductions, including from the increase in exercise-promoting active transportation and potential changes in diet.10Patz JA Frumkin H Holloway T Vimont DJ Haines A Climate change: challenges and opportunities for Global Health.JAMA. 2014; 312: 1565-1580Crossref PubMed Scopus (282) Google Scholar, 11Chang KM Hess JJ Balbus JM et al.Ancillary health effects of climate mitigation scenarios as drivers of policy uptake: a review of air quality, transportation and diet co-benefits modeling studies.Environ Res Lett. 2017; 12: 113001Crossref Scopus (38) Google Scholar This study adds to the body of knowledge that reducing greenhouse gas emissions also reduces air pollution and benefits health, and does so in the particularly important context of China. This study, like others, finds that the monetised co-benefits for air pollution and health are comparable to, or might exceed, the costs of greenhouse gas reductions, even without accounting for the other health benefits of slowing the impacts of climate change, through reduced heat stress, infectious diseases, severe storms, and access to food and water.12Patz JA Campbell-Lendrum D Holloway T Foley JA Impact of regional climate change on human health.Nature. 2005; 438: 310-317Crossref PubMed Scopus (1960) Google Scholar These health benefits should be an important motivator for public health and medical professionals to speak on the importance of climate change, and for governments to act on reducing greenhouse gas emissions. This online publication has been corrected. The corrected version first appeared at thelancet.com/planetary-health on April 27, 2018 This online publication has been corrected. The corrected version first appeared at thelancet.com/planetary-health on April 27, 2018 We declare no competing interests. The Lancet Countdown on PM2¬∑5 pollution-related health impacts of China's projected carbon dioxide mitigation in the electric power generation sector under the Paris Agreement: a modelling studyOur results suggest that cost‚Äìbenefit analysis of climate policy that omits regional air pollution could greatly underestimate benefits. A compensation mechanism for inter-regional interests (including financial, technological, and knowledge support) should be established for regions that give up their human health benefits for the sake of the whole nation to realise the climate change targets. Full-Text PDF Open AccessCorrection to Lancet Planet Health 2018; 2: e147‚Äì48Patz JA, West JJ. The Paris Agreement could saves lives in China. Lancet Planet Health 2018; 2: e147‚Äì48‚ÄîThe title should have read "The Paris Agreement saves lives in China". This correction has been made as of April 27, 2018. Full-Text PDF Open Access

title: Bringing the planet into the generalist practice: a form of preventive care
display_name: Bringing the planet into the generalist practice: a form of preventive care

author.au_affiliation_raw: Department of Family Medicine, Faculty of Medicine, Tel Aviv University, Tel Aviv 6997801, Israel

ab: For the patient who presents with a clinical illness at the doctor's office, some questions are an underlying part of every consultation, although the patient rarely asks them explicitly. What caused my problem? What, consequently, can be done about it? What could I have done differently in the past and how can I prevent the problem in the future? Did the environment or society surrounding me provide me with the best chance of avoiding disease? Did my activity or inactivity, components of my nutrition, or air or water contribute to my condition? Implied in all questions is the concern about the role of environmental factors in the pathogenesis of disease. When health maintenance is part of the purpose of the encounter, the principal question posed to the physician, from a patient's perspective, is how to live to maximise one's chances of having a long and healthy life. We have been trained to consider as an integral part of our clinical work the discussion of what is conventionally termed prevention, such as known risk factors for cardiovascular or pulmonary disease and some cancers, and to conclude a consultation with recommendations for lifestyle modifications and established diagnostic tests. Although we know of many truly preventive actions, such as wearing seatbelts and helmets or smoking cessation, few clinically promoted activities deal with the actual prevention of illnesses, with most actions consisting of screening for the early diagnosis of existing problems that have yet to cause clinical symptoms.1United States Preventive Services Task ForceRecommendations.https://www.uspreventiveservicestaskforce.org/BrowseRec/Index/browse-recommendationsDate: 2018Date accessed: March 5, 2018Google Scholar The most thorough preventive actions would consist of avoiding important adverse causative factors or increasing the body's resistance to disease or injury, should exposure occur.2Introduction to preventive medicine.in: Katz DL Wild D Elmore JG Jekel's epidemiology, biostatistics, preventive medicine, and public health. 4th edn. Saunders, Philadelphia2013Google Scholar In reality, many aetiological factors, especially those that can be linked to malignancies, have not been identified, while others are suspected to be causative but cannot be unequivocally proven to be noxious to human beings.3Pr√ºss-Ust√ºn A Wolf J Corval√°n C Bos R Neira M Preventing disease through healthy environments: a global assessment of the burden of disease from environmental risks. World Health Organization, Geneva2016Google Scholar Consequently, discussing most preventable causes of disease necessarily involves uncertainty or even speculation. As a clinician, I can only take in statements like the following, from an Oncology text: ‚ÄúAlthough the causes of many human cancers remain unidentified, cumulative data support the opinion that environmental or dietary agents are the principal cause of human cancers.‚Äù4Strickland PT Kensler TW Environmental factors.in: Niederhuber J Armitage J Doroshow J Abeloff's clinical oncology. 5th edn. Saunders, Philadelphia2013Google Scholar The Precautionary Principle is described as taking preventive action in the face of uncertainty5United NationsThe Rio Declaration on environment and development.http://www.unesco.org/education/pdf/RIO_E.PDFDate: 1992Date accessed: March 5, 2018Google Scholar and is widely known since its proposal at the Rio Earth Summit 1992.6Kriebel D Tickner J Epstein P et al.The precautionary principle in environmental science.Environ Health Perspect. 2001; 109: 871-876Crossref PubMed Scopus (385) Google Scholar If we allow this principle to guide our preventive efforts, it can take the concerns of our prevention-minded patients one step further: patients should consider important factors that could improve the prospect of living a long life with an optimal life quality. Planetary health deals with prevention on a large scale. It attempts to include the important factors that determine health for humankind and other living creatures, in both short and long term. Countering planetary-scale threats requires coordinated global action by governmental and international organisations, but political action has been fragile and subject to dissuasion, especially in the past few years, rendering it essential, but not sufficient. Additional approaches are needed. Cooperation by individuals on a large scale could substantially add to efforts to safeguard planetary health. For the actions of individuals to make a difference, greatly increased awareness and motivation to act in their essential interest would be needed. As of now, in most populations, daily worries take precedence over what might happen to the world decades or centuries ahead. Therefore, if we want to facilitate understanding and motivation for planetary priorities, we should attempt to make the concept that personal behaviour contributes substantially to global development transparent to all. In the health-care sector of some countries, appeals have been published calling on health-care professionals to impress on their patients to change wasteful habits and overconsumption and to cut carbon footprints.7Guidotti TL Hancock T Bell W Physicians and environmental change: what is our role and why should anyone listen to us?.Persp in Biol and Medicine. 1998; 41: 591-604Crossref Scopus (4) Google Scholar The need for health-care professionals to acquire operative sustainable health expertise and skills has been pointed out.8Guitton MJ Poitras J Acquiring an operative sustainability expertise for health professionals.Lancet Planet Health. 2017; 1: e299-e300Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (3) Google Scholar Directions for the patient who asks about how to live a healthier life and what are the best options for effective prevention can emphasise simple and common sense messages. Next to preventive action that has a clear evidence base‚Äîsuch as cardiovascular or accident prevention‚Äîsimple, catchy explanations on the need to cut carbon footprints or to minimise exposure to pesticides or air pollution should be widely disseminated and their use encouraged.9The Lancet Planetary HealthOur polluted world: the need for a global pollution strategy.Lancet Planet Health. 2017; 1: e209Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (2) Google Scholar Simple and concise messages, as needed for the busy practitioner, have not yet been formulated. The potential to broadly propagate these universally applicable ideas will depend on keeping them straightforward. Emphasising the common sense of such ideas may contribute to preserving the planet's environment.

title: Effect of precipitation on clinic-diagnosed enteric infections in children in Rwanda: an observational study
display_name: Effect of precipitation on clinic-diagnosed enteric infections in children in Rwanda: an observational study

author.au_affiliation_raw: Emory University Rollins School of Public Health, Atlanta, GA, USA
University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences, Little Rock, AR, USA
author.institution_display_name: University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences

author.au_affiliation_raw: Florida State University, Tallahassee, FL, USA
Innovations for Poverty Action, Kigali, Rwanda
Innovations for Poverty Action, Kigali, Rwanda
Georgetown University, Washington DC, USA
Emory University Rollins School of Public Health, Atlanta, GA, USA

ab: BackgroundEnteric infections are a major cause of morbidity and mortality in low-income and middle-income countries, particularly among children younger than 5 years. Climate change projections for Rwanda predict increases in average temperature, along with increases in total precipitation and frequency of extreme rainfall events. Previous research in Rwanda has found that extreme rainfall events increase the risk of contaminated drinking water, a substantial contributor to diarrhoea in this setting. Relatively little is known about the effect of precipitation on more severe clinic-diagnosed infections in rural, low-income settings such as Rwanda. In the context of a randomised controlled trial to assess the effect of a national environmental health campaign in Rwanda, we did a substudy to assess the effect of total and extreme rainfall on enteric infections in children younger than 5 years.MethodsFor this observational study, we collected data from all government health facilities in Rusizi District, Western Province, for the year 2015. Patient data for children younger than 5 years from 150 study villages were extracted from paper-based registers. Gridded daily precipitation data were downloaded from the Tropical Applications of Meteorology using SATellite and ground based observations (TAMSAT) rainfall dataset in addition to local weather station data. We modelled the effect of total rainfall (in mm) and occurrence of an extreme rainfall event (95th percentile in the past 2 years) on daily health facility visits for enteric symptoms (diarrhoea, gastroenteritis, or vomiting), using Poisson regression with a Newey-West estimator to adjust for serial autocorrelation. We examined total and extreme rainfall within the previous 1, 2, 3, and 4 weeks, controlling for weekend day because we observed a consistent reduction in case counts on weekends.FindingsData were extracted from 46 facilities, with a study catchment area of approximately 12 812 children younger than 5 years. Preliminary results showed 3530 cases of clinic-reported enteric symptoms in 2015, with an estimated annual incidence of 276 cases per 1000 children. Number of daily enteric visits were not significantly affected by preceding total rainfall or extreme events within the past 1, 2, 3, or 4 weeks using the TAMSAT dataset, and only slightly affected by total rainfall in the past 4 weeks using the weather station dataset (incidence rate ratio [IRR] 1¬∑001, 95% CI 1¬∑000‚Äì1¬∑003; p=0¬∑037). However, using the weather station dataset, a 10% increase in daily enteric cases occurred when an extreme rainfall event had occurred in the previous 3 weeks (IRR 1¬∑121, 0¬∑994‚Äì1¬∑265; p=0¬∑064), and an 18% increase occurred when an extreme event had occurred in the previous 4 weeks (IRR 1¬∑184, 1¬∑044‚Äì1¬∑343; p=0¬∑009).InterpretationClinic data from low-income settings are a rich and underused resource, which can have broad applications for improving planetary health at the household, community, and regional levels. These data add objectivity over self-reported conditions and capture the more serious outcomes that affect health-care systems. Our results are consistent with previous studies in showing increased risk of infections from rainfall events, probably due to flushed contaminants and water supply vulnerabilities. Understanding the effects and mechanisms of precipitation on infectious diseases can help inform the design of locally relevant intervention and adaptation strategies.FundingThe Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation

title: Quantifying the health effects of climate change upon pollen allergy: a combined cohort and modelling study
display_name: Quantifying the health effects of climate change upon pollen allergy: a combined cohort and modelling study

author.au_affiliation_raw: School of Environmental Sciences, University of East Anglia, Norwich, UK
School of Environmental Sciences, University of East Anglia, Norwich, UK
School of Environmental Sciences, University of East Anglia, Norwich, UK

ab: BackgroundGlobally, pollen allergy is a major public health problem, but a fundamental knowledge gap exists on the effect of climate change on pollen allergies. The annual herbaceous plant common ragweed (Ambrosia artemisiifolia) is highly invasive; it thrives on disturbed land, with each plant producing up to 62 000 seeds per year. Ragweed is particularly harmful for public health because each plant produces up to 1 billion grains per year. Our study aims to quantify the consequences of climate change on pollen allergy in people in Europe.MethodsWe used a process-based model to estimate the change in the distribution of ragweed plants across Europe under climate change. A second model simulated plant invasion, pollen production, pollen release, and the atmospheric distribution of pollen to estimate current and future ragweed pollen levels. These findings were translated into two different measures of health burden: pollen sensitisation rates and changes in allergy symptoms. Changes in pollen sensitisation rates were estimated using a dose‚Äìresponse curve generated from a systematic review and from current and future population data across Europe (baseline 1986‚Äì2005, future 2041‚Äì60). Changes in allergy symptoms were modelled by obtaining dose-response relationships between pollen and symptoms from a cohort of 85 sensitised individuals in Croatia. These relationships were then applied to future pollen loads, which considered two different regional climate and pollen models, two greenhouse gas emissions scenarios (representative concentration pathways 4¬∑5 and 8¬∑5), and three different plant invasion scenarios. A second set of health effects (sensitisation rates and allergy symptoms) were obtained from future pollen models.FindingsWe estimated that sensitisation to ragweed will more than double in Europe, from a baseline estimate of 33 million people (1986‚Äì2005) to 77 million by 2041‚Äì60. According to our projections, sensitisation will increase in countries with an existing ragweed problem (eg, by 27% in Hungary, 26% in Croatia, and 21% in Serbia), but the greatest proportional increases will occur where sensitisation is uncommon (an increase of 235% in Germany, 292% in Poland, and 231% in France). Higher pollen concentrations and a longer pollen season might also increase the severity of symptoms.InterpretationOur quantitative estimates indicate that ragweed pollen allergy will become a common health problem across Europe, expanding into areas where it is currently uncommon. Control of ragweed spread might be an important adaptation strategy in response to climate change.FundingThis project was supported by the European Community Framework programme 7, Atopica.

title: Effects of land use on zoonotic host communities: a global correlative analysis
display_name: Effects of land use on zoonotic host communities: a global correlative analysis

author.au_affiliation_raw: Centre for Biodiversity and Environment Research, Department of Genetics, Evolution and Environment, University College London, London, UK
Centre for Biodiversity and Environment Research, Department of Genetics, Evolution and Environment, University College London, London, UK
Centre for Biodiversity and Environment Research, Department of Genetics, Evolution and Environment, University College London, London, UK
Centre for Biodiversity and Environment Research, Department of Genetics, Evolution and Environment, University College London, London, UK
Centre for Biodiversity and Environment Research, Department of Genetics, Evolution and Environment, University College London, London, UK
Centre for Biodiversity and Environment Research, Department of Genetics, Evolution and Environment, University College London, London, UK

ab: BackgroundEnvironmental trade-offs associated with land use‚Äîfor example, between food security and biodiversity conservation‚Äîare crucial dimensions of planetary health. Land use-driven biodiversity change might predictably affect disease risk if reservoir host species are consistently more likely to persist under human disturbance (ie, if ecological communities in modified habitats generally have a higher zoonotic potential than those in unmodified habitats). Such a phenomenon has been observed in specific disease systems, but with substantial change in global land use projected for this century, assessing its global and taxonomic generality would shed light on an important hypothesised driver of environmental synergies or trade-offs between conservation and public health.MethodsWe collated data on hosts of human parasites and pathogens from the published literature, and combined these with the Projecting Responses of Ecological Diversity in Changing Terrestrial Systems (PREDICTS) global database of local ecological communities and associated land use data. We analysed the effects of land use on host richness and abundance across 7330 sites globally, controlling for disease-related research effort and differences in survey methods.FindingsEcological communities in anthropogenic land uses (managed and urban ecosystems) contained a consistently higher richness and abundance of host species than did communities in nearby primary (undisturbed) sites. However, among mammal hosts of zoonotic pathogens, we found considerable taxonomic variation in host responses to land use, with abundances of rodents and bats generally increasing and those of primates and carnivores generally declining in modified landscapes.InterpretationOur results suggest that future change in global land use has the potential to drive overall increasing contact between people and ecological communities with increased shared pathogen potential (ie, more potential hosts and possible opportunities for transmission). However, the differences in host responses to modified landscapes among mammal orders suggests that these changes are unlikely to affect all zoonotic diseases consistently. This result supports arguments that, rather than expecting a consistent relationship between biodiversity change and disease, in practice, policies aiming both to conserve biodiversity and reduce human disease (eg, through establishment of protected areas) must be disease and context specific.FundingThis research was supported by a Graduate Research Scholarship from University College London (to RG), the Natural Environment Research Council (to DWR and KEJ), and a Royal Society University Research Fellowship (to TN).

title: Linking forests, deforestation, and nutritional outcomes: an observational study in nine African countries
display_name: Linking forests, deforestation, and nutritional outcomes: an observational study in nine African countries

author.au_affiliation_raw: Department of Zoology, University of Oxford, Oxford, UK
Saw Swee Hock School of Public Health, National University of Singapore, Singapore
Saw Swee Hock School of Public Health, National University of Singapore, Singapore
Department of Biological Sciences National University of Singapore, Singapore

ab: BackgroundAgricultural expansion is a leading driver of deforestation, yet malnutrition remains a significant cause of morbidity. Understanding trade-offs and synergies between forest protection and agricultural expansion, and how they vary between groups across time, could help guide socially equitable sustainable development. Forests have important roles in supporting dietary diversity and micronutrient intake, but limited empirical evidence links forests and broad nutritional outcomes. Our research explores the associations between key indicators of malnutrition and forest cover and deforestation, the mediating role of socioeconomic factors, and underlying temporal trends.MethodsIn this observational study, we explored associations between nutritional outcomes (underweightness, stunting, wasting, and overweightness) in children younger than 5 years and forest cover and loss gradients (in 10 km buffers around communities) in 61 032 African households. These households were surveyed by the Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) Program from nine countries (Burkina Faso, Cameroon, Democratic Republic of the Congo, Ethiopia, Ghana, Guinea, Kenya, Lesotho, and Liberia) between 2003 and 2014. DHS data were combined with spatially explicit data on forest cover and loss, climate, infrastructure, economy, and demography in a series of generalised linear mixed-effects models.FindingsIn urban areas, children in communities surrounded by 1 SD higher forest cover had 10¬∑8% (95% CI 3¬∑0‚Äì18¬∑0; p=0¬∑0073) lower incidence of underweightness and 11¬∑7% (1¬∑9‚Äì20¬∑6; p=0¬∑0212) lower incidence of wasting than did children in areas with the mean amount of forest cover. In rural areas, the relationship was reversed, with 6¬∑0% (1¬∑6‚Äì10¬∑6; p=0¬∑0074) higher incidence of underweightness among children in areas of 1 SD higher forest cover than among children in areas with the mean amount of forest cover. These relationships became marginally non-significant when analysing the urban and rural datasets together. Additionally, children in areas of 1 SD higher deforestation had 6¬∑7% (1¬∑4‚Äì12¬∑3; p=0¬∑0124) and 2¬∑6% (0¬∑04‚Äì5¬∑2; p=0¬∑0460) higher incidence of underweightness in urban and rural areas, respectively, than did children in areas with the mean amount of deforestation. This positive relationship between deforestation and underweightness appeared to diminish over time.InterpretationOur results provide evidence that forest cover is associated with worse nutritional outcomes in rural areas, but better outcomes in urban areas of Africa. We did not explicitly measure the contribution of forests to dietary diversity. Yet, the nutritional trade-offs between rural African forests and agriculture should be assessed alongside potential micronutrient benefits from forest foods. Furthermore, forest loss appears to be associated with worse nutrition in the short term, although unmeasured frontier migration might have a role. These results might indicate a farm‚Äìforest frontier effect, with short-term declines in nutrition during deforestation events, potentially followed by long-term improvements, although further research is required to substantiate this hypothesis. These nutritional effects should be recognised and accounted for in efforts to meet sustainable development objectives relating to health and forest protection.FundingMinistry of Education of Singapore.

title: Suicide and the natural environment: an Indigenous view
display_name: Suicide and the natural environment: an Indigenous view

author.au_affiliation_raw: Department of Anthropology, Durham University, Durham, UK
Medical Ethics and Humanities Unit, University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong Special Administrative Region, China

ab: Suicide has recently emerged as a subject of discussion under the framework of planetary health. Helbich and colleagues1Helbich M de Beurs D Kwan MP O'Connor RC Groenewegen PP Natural environments and suicide mortality in the Netherlands: a cross-sectional, ecological study.Lancet Planet Health. 2018; 2: e134-e139Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (35) Google Scholar state that municipalities with more green space could reduce their suicide rates, and that exposure to natural environments lowers suicide mortality. Chang and Gunnell2Chang SS Gunnell D Natural environments and suicide.Lancet Planet Health. 2018; 2: e109-e110Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (3) Google Scholar echo the need for further research on informed land use and urban planning to reduce suicide rates. However, exposure to green space is not always a positive factor contributing to better mental health, since nature is perceived, accessed, and used differently by people of different socioeconomic and cultural backgrounds. The rights and ownership of the state, and its governance over land, determine the accessibility of green spaces. A critique on the global environment stressed the importance of subjective and lived experiences perceived from within.3Ingold T Globes and spheres: the topology of environmentalism.in: Dove M Carpenter C Environmental anthropology: a historical reader. Blackwell, Oxford2007: 462-469Google Scholar Suicide incidents encountered during our fieldwork in Taiwan represent the complex association between suicide and the natural environment. For example, in March, 2018, a 63-year-old Atayal farmer in an Indigenous township called Wufeng, where the Atayal people have long settled, died by suicide by swallowing pesticide. In August, 2017, the farmer reportedly violated the Soil and Water Conservation Act by digging in his own land illegally and was thus required to pay a fine of NT$140 000 (approximately US$4700). The farmer was illiterate and unfamiliar with the law. Having suffered from severe gout for 20 years, he could not work but had to rent out his land to others to be farmed at a very low price. He chose to take his own life because he could not afford to pay the fine. Indigenous Atayal communities used to live in the mountains, lands that are now regulated by the state and have also become a popular leisure place for urbanites. Wufeng is one of the Indigenous townships with the highest density of campsites in Taiwan and is commonly used by residents of Hsinchu, a highly populated city known for its development of the Hsinchu Science Park. In 2017, the population of campers in Taiwan reached approximately 2 million, and the number of campsites has increased from around 800 to 1800 in the past 5 years. Exploitation of the mountains' natural resources has led to repeated landslides. The government has responded by encouraging local people to report illegal deforestation (figure). Suicide should be studied from a social, historical, and ecological standpoint.4Widger T Suicide in Sri Lanka: the anthropology of an epidemic. Routledge, New York, NY2015Crossref Scopus (14) Google Scholar Nonetheless, dissimilar theoretical frameworks of suicide reveal varying degrees of applicability to Indigenous communities.5O'Keefe VM Tucker RP Cole AB Hollingsworth DW Wingate LR Understanding Indigenous suicide through a theoretical lens: a review of general, culturally-based, and Indigenous frameworks.Transcultural Psychiatry. 2018; (published online June 4.)DOI:10.1177/1363461518778937Crossref PubMed Scopus (11) Google Scholar Unlike the image of a natural, enjoyable, and healthy environment assumed and consumed by urban people, Indigenous communities in Taiwan face a series of what Singer calls "pluralea interactions" concerning their relationship with the environment.6Singer M Pluralea interactions and the remaking of the environment in environmental health.in: Singer M A companion to the anthropology of environmental health. John Wiley & Sons, Inc, Hoboken, NJ2016: 435-457Crossref Scopus (1) Google Scholar According to Singer, this new way of looking at the environment as a dynamic system helps explain the interwoven environmental crises and their effects on health.6Singer M Pluralea interactions and the remaking of the environment in environmental health.in: Singer M A companion to the anthropology of environmental health. John Wiley & Sons, Inc, Hoboken, NJ2016: 435-457Crossref Scopus (1) Google Scholar Indigenous people in Taiwan have lived on the fringes of the country's rapid economic growth and remained poor, while Han-owned corporations continuously embezzle aboriginal land.7Simon S Scarred landscapes and tattooed faces: poverty, identity and land conflict in a Taiwanese Indigenous community.in: Eversole R McNeish JA Cimadamore AD Indigenous peoples and poverty: an international perspective. Zed Books, London2005: 53-68Google Scholar Although factors affecting mental health among Taiwanese Indigenous communities should be investigated,8Chen CS Yang MS Yang MJ et al.Suicidal thoughts among elderly Taiwanese aboriginal women.Int J Geriatr Psychiatry. 2008; 23: 1001-1006Crossref PubMed Scopus (17) Google Scholar, 9Chen YL Lai CS Chen WT et al.Risk Factors for PTSD after Typhoon Morakot among elderly people in Taiwanese aboriginal communities.Int Psychogeriatr. 2011; 23: 1686-1691Crossref PubMed Scopus (19) Google Scholar the high prevalence of alcohol use, under-diagnosed depression, trauma-related mental disturbances, and looming suicides embedded in the history of the incessant destruction of the natural environment, which constitutes their dwelling sites and habitat, can only be understood through narratives that directly show the vulnerability of these Indigenous communities. The Atayal farmer's suicide reminds us of the need for a comprehensive analysis of the worth of a human being's life within their geopolitical environment. It reflects the neglect and exclusion of Indigenous minorities alongside the state's developmental strategy to exploit natural resources. The ecology surrounding Wufeng epitomises the problems of our crowded and exploited planet. Health inequalities compel people to scramble for shrinking natural resources. There is a pressing need to systemically collect evidence in narrative form to develop a deeper and more robust understanding of why green spaces for urbanites are not necessarily beneficial for Indigenous communities, especially when it comes to suicide prevention. We declare no competing interests.

title: Global Nutrient Availability: a call for accountability and action
display_name: Global Nutrient Availability: a call for accountability and action

author.au_affiliation_raw: Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, Seattle, WA, USA

ab: Malnutrition is a major public health problem underlying global morbidity, mortality, and suboptimal child development. Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) 2 specifically aims to "end hunger, achieve food security and improved nutrition, and promote sustainable agriculture". But better nutrition is linked to each of the SDGs. Maternal and child undernutrition‚Äîincluding micronutrient deficiencies, stunting, and wasting‚Äîaccounted for nearly half of under-5 child deaths in 2011.1Black RE Victora CG Walker SP et al.Maternal and child undernutrition and overweight in low-income and middle-income countries.Lancet. 2013; 382: 427-451Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (4299) Google Scholar Furthermore, overweight and obesity are the fifth-leading risk factors for death globally, and they have had the fastest annualised rate of increase since 1990 of any risk factor.2GBD 2016 Risk Factors CollaboratorsGlobal, regional, and national comparative risk assessment of 84 behavioural, environmental and occupational, and metabolic risks or clusters of risks, 1990‚Äì2016: a systematic analysis for the Global Burden of Disease Study 2016.Lancet. 2017; 390: 1345-1422Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1650) Google Scholar The ability to track global nutrient availability and intake is essential to ensuring progress toward SDGs, and it is increasingly salient as climate change and geopolitical instability affect food availability worldwide. The Global Nutrient Database (GND) developed by Josef Schmidhuber and colleagues fills an important knowledge gap in global nutrition. This work allows the examination of global nutrient availability from 1980 to 2013 in a standardised way. While the study suggests general improvement in diets and notes increasing nutritional abundance‚Äîwhich might be associated with increasing obesity‚Äîit also highlights continued inequality in nutrient availability. According to data from the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO), global energy availability currently exceeds what is needed to hypothetically end hunger, and Schmidhuber and colleagues show that global energy availability has increased to 2710 kcal per person per day over the past three decades. However, the smallest absolute increase has occurred in low-Socio-demographic Index (SDI) countries (80 kcal per person per day). Similarly, low-SDI countries have seen relatively few increases in protein availability during the same period. High and upper-middle-SDI countries continue to have the highest availability of essential micronutrients, including iron, vitamin A, and zinc. Climate change could exacerbate these inequalities. Elevated CO2 might reduce the nutritional quality of staple crops,3Myers SS Zanobetti A Kloog I et al.Increasing CO2 threatens human nutrition.Nature. 2014; 510: 139-142Crossref PubMed Scopus (762) Google Scholar and a recent simulation study showed that CO2-related iron and zinc deficiencies are projected to disproportionately affect southeast Asia and Africa.4Weyant C Brandeau ML Burke M Lobell DB Bendavid E Basu S Anticipated burden and mitigation of carbon-dioxide-induced nutritional deficiencies and related diseases: a simulation modeling study.PLoS Med. 2018; 15: e1002586Crossref PubMed Scopus (29) Google Scholar Despite improvements in global nutrition availability, inequalities at the national level are clear, and they are persisting. This study‚Äîwith its novel application of machine-learning methods and use of detailed global data‚Äîprovides the best estimates of global nutrient availability so far. The FAO's Supply and Utilization Accounts (SUA) database (from which food balance sheets are generated) is the most comprehensive source of data on national food availability.5FAOSupply Utilization Accounts and Food Balance Sheets‚Äîbackground information for your better understanding.http://www.fao.org/economic/the-statistics-division-ess/methodology/methodology-systems/supply-utilization-accounts-and-food-balance-sheets-background-information-for-your-better-understanding/en/Date accessed: July 23, 2017Google Scholar This new study uses the FAO SUA data, the United States Department of Agriculture's (USDA) Food and Nutrient Database for Dietary Studies (FNDDS), refuse factors from USDA handbooks, national food consumption surveys, and advanced analytical methods to provide detailed and useful nutrition information for 195 countries. The study improves on previous efforts in several ways. The FAO food balance sheets used in previous studies only provide aggregated data for total energy intake and data for a limited number of macronutrients and micronutrients; the present study is the first to use the primary source SUA data. The spatiotemporal Gaussian process regression methods used are a sophisticated approach to account for the heterogeneity of data across space and time. Finally, the study team used gradient boosting for applied machine learning to optimise predictive models. Despite the advances in global nutrient intake estimation stemming from the work by Schmidhuber and colleagues, there are limitations to interpreting this work. The novel analyses were validated by comparing them with nutrient consumption data from the USA, Korea, and Ecuador, but these are high-income and middle-income countries with relatively high global food security index ratings.6The Economist Intelligence UnitGlobal food security index 2017: measuring food security and the impact of resource risks. The Economist, London2017Google Scholar The validation countries did not include lower-middle-income or low-income country contexts where industrialised livestock rearing and agriculture are less common and data collection systems are not as strong. Thus, the choice of validation countries likely overstates the validity of the global estimates. Furthermore, there are several potential sources of measurement error in these estimates. For example, FAO SUAs reflect various national datapoints, all of which are prone to error. Previous work comparing FAO estimates to national or regional dietary intake data has identified significant heterogeneity by region, as well as by age, sex, and data collection period.7Del Gobbo LC Khatibzadeh S Imamura F et al.Assessing global dietary habits: a comparison of national estimates from the FAO and the Global Dietary Database.Am J Clin Nutr. 2015; 101: 1038-1046Crossref PubMed Scopus (90) Google Scholar Furthermore, Schmidhuber and colleagues' methods assume standard nutrient content (based on US data) and standard inedible food proportions across countries. The data reflect neither homestead agriculture production, nor micronutrient fortification programmes. While this new work might provide the best-yet estimates of nutrient availability, it does not provide data on global nutrient intake data, which is based on food affordability, availability, and quality.6The Economist Intelligence UnitGlobal food security index 2017: measuring food security and the impact of resource risks. The Economist, London2017Google Scholar Finally, national estimates mask significant inequality at the subnational level. Future research should address these limitations. Given the importance of malnutrition in global health and development, as well as the paucity of national data regarding dietary intakes and micronutrient deficiencies, the GND represents a major advance. The GND provides a standardised method for assessing changes over time and across countries. This is essential for tracking global progress in reaching SDG 2, and for monitoring food security in the context of climate change and geopolitical instability. Furthermore, these results highlight opportunities to fill existing macronutrient and micronutrient gaps through food system interventions. These range from large-scale food fortification to targeted production of livestock or staple crops and improvement of the food safety net.8Masters WA Rosettie K Kranz S et al.Priority interventions to improve maternal and child diets in sub-Saharan Africa and South Asia.Matern Child Nutr. 2018; 14: e12526Crossref PubMed Scopus (9) Google Scholar Nutrition, health, agriculture, and climate change stakeholders should consider these data and analyses as an opportunity to ensure targeted action and accountability to improve nutrition globally. I declare no competing interests. The Global Nutrient Database: availability of macronutrients and micronutrients in 195 countries from 1980 to 2013Our global nutrient database provides a picture of the supply of various nutrients at the country level and can be useful to assess the performance of national food systems in addressing the nutritional needs of their population. Full-Text PDF Open Access

title: Creating and supporting a healthy food environment for type 2 diabetes prevention
display_name: Creating and supporting a healthy food environment for type 2 diabetes prevention

author.au_affiliation_raw: Department of Epidemiology, College of Public Health, University of Iowa, Iowa City, IA 52242, USA
Department of Epidemiology, College of Public Health, University of Iowa, Iowa City, IA 52242, USA
Department of Epidemiology, College of Public Health, University of Iowa, Iowa City, IA 52242, USA

ab: The widespread epidemic of type 2 diabetes mellitus in many countries1Zheng Y Ley SH Hu FB Global aetiology and epidemiology of type 2 diabetes mellitus and its complications.Nat Rev Endocrinol. 2018; 14: 88-98Crossref PubMed Scopus (2221) Google Scholar, 2Xu G Liu B Sun Y et al.Prevalence of diagnosed type 1 and type 2 diabetes among US adults in 2016 and 2017: population based study.BMJ. 2018; 362: k1497Crossref PubMed Scopus (244) Google Scholar renders the prevention of this condition a global priority for public health. Key modifiable risk factors for type 2 diabetes include obesity, an unhealthy diet, and a sedentary lifestyle. Individual-level interventions to promote a healthy diet and lifestyle have been proven to effectively reduce or delay the onset of type 2 diabetes.3Haw JS Galaviz KI Straus AN et al.Long-term sustainability of diabetes prevention approaches: a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized clinical trials.JAMA Intern Med. 2017; 177: 1808-1817Crossref PubMed Scopus (169) Google Scholar Dietary and lifestyle choices are ultimately an individual matter and are determined by one's knowledge, attitude, beliefs, and skills. However, other factors at the family, community, and society levels could have profound effects, but these factors have not been thoroughly considered. Successful changes to promote healthy behaviours at an individual level might be best achieved with multi-level interventions that consider factors at interpersonal, organisational, community, and public policy levels (figure).4McLeroy KR Steckler A Bibeau D Glanz K The social ecology of health promotion interventions.Health Educ Q. 1988; 15: 351-377Crossref PubMed Scopus (4460) Google Scholar At a community level, evidence increasingly suggests an association between the local food environment and diabetes.5Mezuk B Li X Cederin K Rice K Sundquist J Sundquist K Beyond access: characteristics of the food environment and risk of diabetes.Am J Epidemiol. 2016; 183: 1129-1137Crossref PubMed Scopus (39) Google Scholar The neighbourhood food environment can affect the perceived availability of, access to, and exposure to foods and beverages. In their Article in The Lancet Planetary Health, Chinmoy Sarkar and colleagues6Sarkar C Webster C Gallacher J Are exposures to ready-to-eat food environments associated with type 2 diabetes? A cross-sectional study of 347 551 UK Biobank adult participants.Lancet Planet Health. 2018; 2: e438-e450Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (14) Google Scholar analysed large-scale cross-sectional data from 347 551 adult participants in the UK Biobank to examine the associations of exposure to ready-to-eat food environments (such as fast food takeaways, pubs and bars, and restaurants and cafeterias) with the odds of type 2 diabetes. The authors defined ready-to-eat food environments by use of a modelled and linked built environment database and objectively measured these environments within 1-km catchment areas of the residential streets of participants. Sarkar and colleagues found that the density of ready-to-eat food environments within a 1-km street catchment was associated with higher odds of type 2 diabetes. The associations were not appreciably changed after adjustment for potential confounders, including demographics, socioeconomic status, dietary and lifestyle factors, and body-mass index. This study benefited from use of a large and well characterised cohort that represented participants from 21 major cities of UK, which provided a high statistical power to detect the associations. Socioeconomic status is a potential confounder when assessing the association between a food environment and health outcomes. It has been assumed that people in areas that comprise many individuals of low socioeconomic status have less access to resources than their affluent neighbours. Such populated areas with poor access to nutritious and affordable food are often termed so-called food deserts. However, in the study by Sarkar and colleagues,6Sarkar C Webster C Gallacher J Are exposures to ready-to-eat food environments associated with type 2 diabetes? A cross-sectional study of 347 551 UK Biobank adult participants.Lancet Planet Health. 2018; 2: e438-e450Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (14) Google Scholar the associations persisted when several variables relevant to socioeconomic status (such as educational attainment, employment status, and income) were adjusted for, indicating that the association could not‚Äîor at least could not solely‚Äîbe explained by socioeconomic disadvantage. Exposure to ready-to-eat food environments can increase the frequency of dining out and consuming ready-to-eat foods. Ready-to-eat foods are usually high in total fat or saturated fat and added sugar, which are associated with higher risk of type 2 diabetes.1Zheng Y Ley SH Hu FB Global aetiology and epidemiology of type 2 diabetes mellitus and its complications.Nat Rev Endocrinol. 2018; 14: 88-98Crossref PubMed Scopus (2221) Google Scholar In terms of cooking methods, frying is more commonly used in ready-to-eat food environments than at home. Another important but usually neglected food component when inferring the associations between food and health is unwanted contamination by environmental chemicals. People who dine out more often have increased exposure to obesogenic environmental chemicals, such as phthalates,7Varshavsky JR Morello-Frosch R Woodruff TJ Zota AR Dietary sources of cumulative phthalates exposure among the U.S. general population in NHANES 2005‚Äì2014.Environ Int. 2018; 115: 417-429Crossref PubMed Scopus (59) Google Scholar which are associated with an increased risk of type 2 diabetes.8Sun Q Cornelis MC Townsend MK et al.Association of urinary concentrations of bisphenol A and phthalate metabolites with risk of type 2 diabetes: a prospective investigation in the Nurses' Health Study (NHS) and NHSII cohorts.Environ Health Perspect. 2014; 122: 616-623Crossref PubMed Scopus (3) Google Scholar More research questions warrant further investigation. First, the population-attributable risk of type 2 diabetes that is associated with exposure to ready-to-eat food environments remains to be determined. The magnitude of the observed associations in the study by Sarkar and colleagues6Sarkar C Webster C Gallacher J Are exposures to ready-to-eat food environments associated with type 2 diabetes? A cross-sectional study of 347 551 UK Biobank adult participants.Lancet Planet Health. 2018; 2: e438-e450Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (14) Google Scholar was relatively small; for example, participants in the highest exposure categories to composite ready-to-eat outlets had 11% higher odds of type 2 diabetes than those with no exposure. However, given the large number of people living close to a ready-to-eat food environment, the population-wide health effects of exposure to these food environments would be substantial. Second, like other observational cross-sectional studies, the study by Sarkar and colleagues6Sarkar C Webster C Gallacher J Are exposures to ready-to-eat food environments associated with type 2 diabetes? A cross-sectional study of 347 551 UK Biobank adult participants.Lancet Planet Health. 2018; 2: e438-e450Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (14) Google Scholar could not infer temporality and causality of the association between proximity to a ready-to-eat food environment and the odds of type 2 diabetes. Carefully designed randomised controlled trials are needed to demonstrate the effects of modifying the local food environment, as a population-based approach, on the prevention of type 2 diabetes. Third, so-called unhealthy food environments also sell some healthy foods. The distribution of healthy and unhealthy food sources could change over time and vary by dynamic population characteristics. The association of changes in the local food environment with the risk of type 2 diabetes needs to be characterised. Finally, beyond access to various foods in a certain food environment, food prices, marketing, product advertising, perceptions of food quality and safety, and cultural habits can all serve a role in consumption behaviours. A major challenge to change food choices might be how to increase motivation to access healthier foods and the ability to do so. In summary, this large study by Sarkar and colleagues6Sarkar C Webster C Gallacher J Are exposures to ready-to-eat food environments associated with type 2 diabetes? A cross-sectional study of 347 551 UK Biobank adult participants.Lancet Planet Health. 2018; 2: e438-e450Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (14) Google Scholar shows the need for creating and supporting a healthy food environment in multi-level intervention efforts for prevention of type 2 diabetes. Understanding the effects of food environment on human health could provide the information and evidence necessary for top-down approaches, such as public policy and legal solutions, to improve the health and wellbeing of populations.9Lytle LA Measuring the food environment: state of the science.Am J Prev Med. 2009; 36: S134-S144Summary Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (193) Google Scholar We declare no competing interests. Are exposures to ready-to-eat food environments associated with type 2 diabetes? A cross-sectional study of 347 551 UK Biobank adult participantsAccess to ready-to-eat food environments was positively associated with type 2 diabetes. Top-down policies aimed at minimising unhealthy food access could potentially reduce unhealthy consumption and risks of chronic diseases. Further long-term studies are needed to effectively guide such interventions. Full-Text PDF Open Access

title: Mining the USA
display_name: Mining the USA
ab: On June 20, US President Donald Trump announced his intention to open up large areas of Minnesota's Superior National Forest to industrial activity, a move likely to benefit the mining company Twin Metals Mining Minnesota, which has previously expressed interest in this region. More precisely, Trump's plan is to undo one of his predecessor Barack Obama's final acts as president, a 20-year ban on industrial activity across about 234 000 acres of the national forest while studies on the potential environmental impacts of any mining-related activity are completed. The Trump administration has so far been a mining-friendly one: last December, Trump took similar steps to open up parts of Grand Staircase-Escalante National Monument in Utah to mining, and on June 13, Glacier Lake Resources announced that it was ready to begin the process of reopening the Colt Mesa copper mine which formerly sat within the bounds of this protected area. More worrying than this expansion of possible mining sites is the loosening of regulations on how these sites will be managed and cleaned up. In December, 2017, then US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Administrator Scott Pruitt rescinded proposed Obama-era legislation requiring hardrock mining companies (ie, those mining hard minerals such as gold and copper) to prove that they were financially capable of cleaning up future pollution (even if they were to go bankrupt), and in February, 2018, he announced that the EPA would not be taking a role in the oversight or regulation of the hardrock mining industry. Arguing that these decisions will push the cost of cleanup on to taxpayers, the EPA is now being legally challenged by allied environmental groups. Supporting the EPA are states with significant mining interests, who argue that their own regulations governing how mines are run and maintained are sufficient to prevent major environmental damage. Opposition to new mines and calls for stricter regulation are nothing new, and not without reason. The environmental impact of an improperly managed mine can be catastrophic. Apart from the physical disturbance of the land in and surrounding a mine, the most common problems are related to water pollution. The process of mining and extracting minerals uses huge quantities of water, which can leak into groundwater or other nearby water sources. This leakage may contain toxic compounds used in the mining process, heavy metals leached from waste rock, sediment that can potentially clog rivers and smother aquatic habitats, or sulphuric acid, which is produced when naturally occurring sulphides in the rocks are exposed to air and water. All of these by-products have the ability to harm both the environment and the health of people living within their range. These problems do not just occur while a mine is in operation; problems can also arise from the huge amount of waste material produced during mining. This waste will need to be managed carefully for many decades, or even longer, after a mine has been closed. Improper waste management has been the cause of some of the most attention-grabbing mining accidents, such as the Mount Polley mine disaster in British Colombia, Canada, when a collapsing dam sent 24 million m3 of water and mining waste flooding into nearby rivers and streams and swamping large areas of forest. New mines do not necessarily mean new disasters, and mines, when managed responsibly, can bring major boons to local economies, such as with Western Australia's ongoing iron ore boom. Use of new technologies can and have made mining a less environmentally harmful practice as companies begin to realise that, when it comes to handling dangerous waste, prevention is better than a cure. However, the erosion of federal oversight of the industry in the USA under the Trump administration is more troubling. In his announcement on opening up Superior National Forest to mining, Trump promised to move carefully and to only act if the plans ‚Äúcould pass muster‚Äù‚Äîalthough according to whose standards is not clear. While individual states have their own regulations for mines operating within them, it is‚Äîfrom the short-term economic perspective at least‚Äîin their interests to keep the industry happy. Without the backing of the EPA, state governments could be put under increasing pressure from industry lobbyists, while the industry might lack sufficient incentives to adopt sustainable, but more costly, practices. As with so many environmental challenges, what is needed is for stakeholders to realise that mines are not short-term prospects; putting in the effort to minimise their environmental impact now could significantly reduce cleanup costs yet to come. Coal mining and coal use: the European perspectiveThe Lancet Planetary Health addressed the issue of coal mining in the USA and the need for a fast reduction in intensive coal use.1,2 It should be noted that the USA and the EU are adopting different policies concerning coal mining incentives and coal use. The EU has adopted a general framework to reduce emissions of carbon dioxide by 2050, including decreasing extraction and burning of coal. Some countries, such as the UK and Italy, have set their withdrawal from coal use even earlier (by 2025). Full-Text PDF Open Access

title: Promoting planetary health through culture
display_name: Promoting planetary health through culture
ab: Land, culture, and health are inextricably entwined in many Indigenous societies, but the intensity of depth of spiritual connection to land‚Äîcolloquially called country‚Äîis unique to Australia's Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples. Relationship to country defines identity, kinship, and language group, and permeates every aspect of health and wellbeing. Historically, languages define familial relationships through highly complex and variable structures of kinship across more than 120 language groups, knowledge of foods, bush medicines, and craft skills. Oral history‚Äîencapsulating such culture‚Äîhas been passed through generations of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people for over 65 000 years, elucidated through art, song, and storytelling. Since the European invasion of Australia in 1788, displacement of Indigenous people has been near-continuous. Dispossession and repeated misguided government policies have forcibly separated Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people from their land, with frontier wars, sanctioned massacres, and resettlement policies with resultant stolen generations. Concurrent with such violence, relocation of Indigenous people to missions, government settlements, and amalgamated townships comprising overlapping language groups across rural Australia was common until the late 1970s. In spite of this, many dispersed communities have maintained their language or elements of their language (although 120 currently spoken Indigenous languages is fewer than half those spoken in 1788), thus reclaiming cultural history. Non-sacred aspects of culture have also become widely accessible in the past 60 years, in part through internationally lauded art movements emerging from multiple groups‚Äîincluding Yolngu, Pitjantjatjara, and Warlpiri speakers. Some groups have also had language, stories and cultural knowledge and belief systems recorded by anthropologists and linguists. Much of this work is being reclaimed and reinstated by diverse groups‚Äîincluding the Wiradjuri (language) and the Yorta Yorta (language and environmental management). Culture has long been understood by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people as the bedrock of health and wellbeing, but epidemiological data to support this on a large scale do not exist‚Äîdespite repeated calls by Indigenous peoples, and a national Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander health policy with culture central to its approach. Contemporary Indigenous health is often described through high levels of alcohol and substance abuse, suicide rates, and levels of incarceration. But how cultural connections might interact with and reduce these phenomena remains anecdotal. In November, 2018, a team from the Australian National University led by Aboriginal (Wongaibon, Ngiyampaa) epidemiologist, Associate Professor Ray Lovett, launched a longitudinal study to understand the relationship between culture and health. Mayi Kuwayu: the National Study of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Wellbeing is designed by and with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, and will gather comprehensive data to examine these links‚Äîan unprecedented goal among studies of Indigenous health from around the world. Through a postal survey, data collection is underway from an initial 20 000 Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people registered in Medicare, extending to 200 000 early next year. The study is designed to explore how culture affects health longitudinally, and pilot phases have shown promising results. Dr Lovett told The Lancet Planetary Health, ‚ÄúAlthough small scale, we have found positive significant relationships between Aboriginal Ranger work (a proxy for cultural participation) and improved general health, family wellbeing, and life satisfaction. The positive results remained after individual adjustment for education, employment, financial status and taking into account health conditions.‚Äù Australian government Acts and racist policies have aimed to shatter cultural continuity with alarming frequency, leading to intergenerational trauma, and creating and exacerbating inequitable health outcomes. Mayi Kuwayu is intended for Australian use, but aspects of the methods could potentially be generalisable to other nations' Indigenous communities in deepening understanding of culture and health. Against the backdrop of evolving human civilisation and the changing state of planetary health, evidence of connections between land, culture, and health might also offer far wider insights into how human societies could thrive in better harmony with our planet, ultimately promoting planetary health through culture. For the Mayu Kuwayu Study see https://mkstudy.com.au/ For the Mayu Kuwayu Study see https://mkstudy.com.au/

title: Can Europe lead the transformation of the plastic pollution crisis?
display_name: Can Europe lead the transformation of the plastic pollution crisis?
ab: Plastic production around the world has grown faster than that of any other material since the 1950s. More waste has been generated in the first decade of this millennium than in previous years. This has largely been due to the increasing manufacture of plastic products that are meant to be discarded after one use, so-called single-use plastics. Single-use plastics can be very useful, for example as low-cost hygienic medical plastics. However, its durability also presents significant challenges for the planet we are living in, posing many threats to human health.
